Indeed, family studies, segregation analyses and twin studies have shown that genetic factors play an important role in disposition towards migraine but could not explain the entire aetiopathogenesis.	0.5184101522258856
The influence of extragenetic factors, however, remains mostly unknown.	0.43594041473885825
Recent linkage analyses have provided evidence for genetic heterogeneity.	0.37510273805602445
A locus for Familial Hemiplegic Migraine (FHM), the only known type of migraine that follows autosomal-dominant transmission, has been linked to chromosome 19p13 but genetic heterogeneity has also been shown, i. e. different types of migraine could be excluded from this locus.	0.5937578740171231
Further investigations should concentrate on identifying the FHM gene on chromosome 19p13, on linkage analyses with markers for different susceptibility genes, and on genomic analyses of highly informative pedigrees.	0.5667685028059176
This would lead to further clues to the pathogenesis underlying migraine and, thus, to therapeutic developments.	0.6754803716001954

The von Willebrand's Disease affects about 1-3 % of the population and it is undiagnosed in most people.	0.6917386735604456
Originally described by the Finish physician Erik von Willebrand in 1926 this disorder is associated with mucous membran bleeding including epistaxis, hypermenorhoea and excessive bleeding from surgery and dental procedures.	0.3712255690921762
In von Willebrands disease the patients have a quantitative or qualitative abnormality in the von Willebrand Factor (vWF) which has two major functions: it serves by bridging between platelets and injury site in the blood vessel wall, and it circulates as a complex with factor VIII, protecting it from rapid degradation.	0.6396068808755815
More than 20 different types and subtypes of vWD have been described but almost all patients can be classified as having 1 of the 2 most common types of vWD.	0.7024447548063998
About 70 % of patients have type 1 and about 10-20 % present themself with type 2A and 2B vWD type 3 in about 10 %.	0.647772609452703
By taking a clinical history of bleeding it is important to think about vWD and to make the appropriate diagnosis.	0.626645844759705
If the vWD is suspected diagnostic tests should include an activated partial thromboplastin time, bleeding time, factor VIII:C, Ristocetin cofactor, and vWF antigen.	0.44438393334120596
Additional testing of ristocetin induced plattlet adhesion (RIPA), the multimeric structure and collagen binding test and gen-analysis allow diagnosing the different types of v. Willebrand Disease.	0.44937957087977753
The treatment of choice in mild forms is the synthetic agent desmopressin.	0.6287515341161343
In patients with severe type 1, type 2B, 2N and type 3 or in people who do not response to desmopressin, the appropriate treatment is a factor VIII concentrate that is rich of vWF.	0.6471856056919767
Until now no recommendations in the orthopaedic literature have been found regarding diagnosis and treatment of vWS patients.	0.5736974476168994
Based on the experience with 43 orthopaedic patients presenting vWD over the last 15 years a contemporary guideline for the successful perioperative management of vWD in orthopaedic surgery is presented.	0.5500502005355572
In a close collaboration between the orthopaedic surgeon and the specialized haemostaseologist every invasive procedure in patients with vWD can be undertaken without the risk of excessive bleeding.	0.4933816181131454

According to Rao [13], a reduction of this risk is possible when patients are monitored invasively and all haemodynamic parameters are kept within the physiological range.	0.580854126082821
In most institutions it is not feasible to treat patients as Rao recommended: this would overstrain both hospital structure and financial resources.	0.6192516504347116

These autoantibodies are thought to play an important role in the blister formation of CP.	0.44580983586780615

A smaller group of patients with CP have autoantibodies to laminin 5.	0.5001905385496481

The described molecules are part of the hemidesmosomal adhesion complex.	0.36462395431870614

When the relative metabolic (synthetic/repair activity) of these human cartilages was compared, it was demonstrated that in osteoarthritis (OA) and rheumatoid arthritis (RA) cartilages synthetic activity was diminished by approximately 50% as compared with N cartilages.	0.6931385862589294
However, the turnover rate of matrix was not significantly different between Non-arthritic and OA, but was very substantially increased in RA cartilages compatible with the activity of inflammatory cells and proteolytic enzymes released from pannus.	0.6515839993894803

3 of these NSAIDs were also studied in terms of their effect on cartilage collagen synthesis.	0.42000840987132865
Consideration of the results in this study and from published material, led to the suggestion that NSAIDs may be divided into 3 categories in respect of their in vitro action on the extracellular matrix of human arthritic cartilages:   1.	0.7256980144363517
Those such as Aceclofenac, Tenidap and Tolmetin which can stimulate matrix synthesis 2.	0.33313066813681735
Those such as Piroxicam, Tiaprofenic Acid and Aspirin which appear to be without significant effect on matrix synthesis and, 3.	0.5008430819635442
Those like Naproxen, Ibuprofen, Indomethacin, Nimezulide which significantly inhibit matrix synthesis.	0.2847928088745244

Physiologically, angiogenesis in adults is a controlled process which plays a role, for example, in wound healing.	0.6305860590059532
Pathological angiogenesis is observed in tumor formation and represents a multifactorial process, in which specific angiogenic factors, as well as growth factors, extracellular matrix proteins and cell adhesion molecules are involved.	0.6009687620256571
Tumor growth is characterized by an imbalance in favor of angiogenic over angiogenesis-inhibiting factors.	0.45017812438732724
Some of the most frequently examined angiogenic factors are vascular endothelial growth factor, acidic/basic fibroblast growth factors and the platelet-derived endothelial cell growth factor.	0.6240195791986962
The most important angiogenesis inhibitors are angiostatin and thrombospondin.	0.4422916312578898
To date, the clinical relevance of tumor angiogenesis has been shown for several human tumors.	0.8256030965886532
For most urological tumors, the grade of tumor vessel formation, measured as microvessel density, has been associated with metastases, tumor growth and clinical course.	0.6569913524677068
The prognostic value of this feature of malignant growth seems to be higher than that of most of the classical and newer prognostic factors.	0.6269892068928755
Systematic investigations of tumor angiogenesis are becoming increasingly relevant for diagnostic and therapeutic strategies and offer opportunities for the development of new specific therapeutic approaches in clinical oncology.	0.7056985657848531

Psychoanalysis is regarded to be mainly disorderoriented.	0.2597952861928181

During the last few decades, traumatic injuries of the hip joint have significantly increased in number, and traffic accidents have also increased.	0.8045230676384868
Depending on the speed, direction of the forces and the position of the femur at the moment of impact, different patterns of injury occur.	0.6523207127691577
Basically, they are classified as hip dislocations, dislocation fractures and acetabular fractures.	0.545870336153814
These injuries have in common a high rate of concomitant lesions.	0.4260746607750927
Several classification systems have been developed for these injuries.	0.6395600172689415
Commonly, Stewart and Milford's or Levin's classification is used for dislocations and dislocation fractures.	0.37956692264285313
For acetabular fractures, Judet and Letournel's classification and its newer version developed by Helfet (AO classification) are generally accepted.	0.46868439824071395
Fractures of the femoral head, though included in these classifications, are typically described by separate classifications like the one presented in 1957 by Pipkin.	0.6162478570169452
The multitude of injuries occuring in the hip joint requires vast knowledge of various operative approaches.	0.4616478506836916
No single approach exists that would permit the treatment of all injuries in an ideal fashion.	0.4908097435834394
Approaches are either considered limited (Kocher-Langenbeck, ilioinguinal iliofemoral) when they permit access only to a restricted segment of the joint, or extended (extended iliofemoral, Maryland, Ruedi) when they allow all-around visualization of the hip joint.	0.5542186195680453
The choice of the best approach for an individual patient depends on the type of injury and also on patient variables like age, preexisting disease, and concomitant injuries.	0.7018254105778433
The decision is further influenced by the timing of surgery, the kind of fracture stabilization intended and by complications typically seen with certain approaches.	0.554421792051248
The indication for extended procedures is only seen in patients with complex injury patterns involving both the anterior and the posterior column or in delayed cases undergoing surgery more than 3 weeks after trauma.	0.6259321590390752
Extended approaches permit excellent visualization of the fracture, but the extent of the soft tissue trauma is reflected in a high rate of postoperative complications.	0.9140550703619194
After a phase in which extended procedures were favored, recently a trend towards more limited approaches can be recognized because of their lower complication rate.	0.5002755538192282
This is facilitated by modern fracture-reduction methods using indirect techniques.	0.320778547118189

The goal of this prospective, randomised and double-blind pilot-study was to investigate the analgesic potency and the side-effects of tramadol enantiomers in clinical practice.	0.7213153524388403
One hundred patients recovering from orthopaedic surgery with a postoperative pain intensity of more than 50 on a visual analogue scale 0-100 mm (Table 1) were recruited for the study.	0.715224998317952
They were treated in a randomised, double-blind way with a maximal dose of 150 mg i.v.	0.5394580030993907
(+)-, (-)-tramadol, racemate, or 15 mg i.v.	0.8314950904954416
morphine or saline in the placebo group (5 groups, 20 patients each).	0.6757404684491158
The primary criterium of efficacy was the number of responders defined as patients with a pain reduction of at least 20 on VAS after 40 min.	0.5782976587945272
In case of pain, responders were allowed to continue with the double-blind drug up to six hours.	0.5389232501249985
The non-responders were treated with morphine as the rescue analgesic.	0.578984455297298
The secondary criterium was the incidence and severity of side-effects.	0.6004149733845373
Six patients terminated the study prematurely.	0.26373975842622677
One patient was excluded because of an allergic reaction to morphine, one patient could not be treated sufficiently with morphine, four were excluded because of protocol violations.	0.7739861816757426
There were 8 responders in the (+)-tramadol-, 6 in the (-)-tramadol- and 6 in the racemate group, 16* (P<0,05) in the morphine group, and 5 in the placebo group.	0.9242653689639349
Pain intensity after 40 min was reduced by 20 (p<0,05), 17 (p<0,05), 17 (p<0,05), 36 (p<0,01 vs placebo, p<0,05 vs (+)-, (-)-tramadol, and racemate group) and 5 mm on the VAS in the (+)-, (-)-, (+/-)-tramadol-, morphine- and placebo-group, respectively.	0.8857778836690349
Thirty eight adverse events like nausea, vomiting, PCO2-increase, and urinary retention occurred in 20 patients, most frequently in the (+)-tramadol- and morphine group.	0.7197480904420804
Sedation was significantly less profound in the (-)-tramadol group 1-4 h postoperatively.	0.8461880915762745
There were no side-effect in the tramadol racemate group.	0.6786369000764565
The enantiomers were equal to the racemate in analgesic potency, but inferior by far to morphine.	0.5764540055157282
They showed more adverse events and, hence, can not be preferred to the racemate in postoperative pain therapy.	0.6345298739657813

They typically present as a solitary tumor, but may occur in multiple sites (e.g.	0.6193557448681584
multiple endocrine neoplasia type I) or as a malignant disease in 10 % of cases and rarely as nesidioblastosis or islet cell adenomatosis.	0.7025743431679004

MR spectroscopy is the only method for non-invasive detection of various aspects of cardiac metabolism in humans.	0.6614490913148524
While the 1H nucleus of water and fat molecules is the signal source for MR imaging, the MR spectroscopic technique allows for the study of a number of other nuclei, such as 13C, 19F, 23Na, 31P, 39K and 87Rb.	0.5175440446986651
Clinical applications presently are confined to the 31P nucleus.	0.32664027719913324
31P-MR spectroscopy allows the non-invasive study of cardiac high-energy phosphate metabolites ATP and phosphocreatine.	0.5012957419632066
The phosphocreatine/ATP ratio is considered an index of the energetic state of the heart.	0.5453639220680456
Possible clinical indications include heart failure, valve disease and coronary artery disease.	0.44496970500792904
In heart failure, the phosphocreatine/ATP ratio is reduced and correlates with clinical severity, ejection fraction and prognosis.	0.5382177024187843
In mitral and aortic valve disease, a reduced phosphocreatine/ATP ratio may indicate the optimum timing for valve replacement.	0.5513885801464896
In coronary artery disease, a regional decrease of phosphocreatine during stress ("biochemical ergometry") may indicate local ischemia.	0.6669155102114213
Furthermore, absolute quantification of high-energy phosphates may allow diagnosis of myocardial viability.	0.5930665313847254
Major technical developments, leading to improved spatial and temporal resolution will be necessary to establish MR spectroscopy as a routine clinical tool.	0.5767964389158255
A retrospective and partly prospective study was conducted to analyse both clinically and cephalometrically the craniofacial growth pattern of patients with isolated and syndrome-related premature craniosynostosis after standardized fronto-orbital and midface advancement.	0.5150097732877168
The file data of 293 children with fronto-orbital advancement were evaluated over an average period of 4.4 years.	0.6239118227520037
In addition, lateral teleradiographies of 117 patients from this group were cephalometrically analysed.	0.41446915490439756
Moreover, late results of 36 children and  8 adults with midface-advancement with an average follow-up period of 4.5 years were assessed.	0.7973361660582566
In contrast to linear craniectomy and so-called lateral canthal advancement, in only 8.2% of cases (24 out of 293 patients) were relapses requiring reoperation found in this study after fronto-orbital advancement.	0.7991406842663548
The evaluations indicate that with simple forms of craniosynostosis such as trigonocephaly and plagiocephaly predominantly very good or good growth can be observed.	0.4059235259108396
Cephalometric evaluation confirmed the limited potential of growth in the area of the anterior skull base and in the midface in the presence of syndrome-related faciocraniosynostoses.	0.6501497467501937
In such cases the cephalometrically confirmed maxillary hypoplasia, which increases in severity in the following order of syndromes `Saethre-Chotzen-Crouzon-Apert-Pfeiffer', could be influenced only to a limited degree by fronto-orbital advancement.	0.5612743308637748
For this reason midface advancement is of secondary importance in children with very severe anomalies.	0.636676113036372

The introduction of Perfluorochemicals into medicine and especially into the treatment of severe lung injury is a fascinating scientific task.	0.5823827459568377
Many recall the famous experiments from Clark et al.	0.2418627738680445
in 1966 when he demonstrated "liquidventilation with perfluorocarbons" in the mammal species for the first time.	0.5140503222438619
After this hallmark, perfluorocarbons were subsequently introduced in research of acute lung injury by the techniques of Total- and Partial-Liquid-Ventilation (TLV; PLV).	0.49938963603387876
Perfluorocarbons (saturated organofluorids) have unique chemical and physical properties which made them attractive substances for intraalveolar application.	0.41332609746452836
The strong C-F bindings in the perfluorocarbon molecules are responsible for their chemical stability, biochemical inertness, high capacity to dissolve respiratory gases, low surface tension and high vapor pressures.	0.5160699718580938
Furthermore, the high density of the PFC lead to radio-opacity and their distribution to dependent lung areas.	0.5372870283649381
The efficacy of PFC liquid, applied by TLV/PLV has been demonstrated in numerous animal studies using different models of acute lung injury.	0.5176851155644924
Currently, several mechanisms of action of perfluorocarbon fluids in acute lung injury are discussed: recruitment of atelectatic alveoli, prevention of endexpiratory collapse of alveoli ("liquid PEEP"), redistribution of perfusion, oxygen transport, surfactant like effects and decrease of inflammation.	0.5855853574615755
Since total liquid ventilation has been used only in experimental models of lung injury, partial liquid ventilation has been introduced successfully into clinical trials (phase I-II).	0.616337485611855
However, the results of the first randomised, controlled study of PLV in 90 adult patients suffering from severe respiratory failure (ALI/ARDS) showed no differences between PLV and conventional treatment.	0.821260649789737
Furthermore, the instillation of relatively large amounts of liquid into the lungs poses several technical challenges and may be associated with complications such as liquithoraces, pneumothoraces and hypoxia.	0.48071845731978297
Since mammal lungs are evolutionary specialised to gas exchange using atmospheric oxygen, the application of liquids, even if they transport respiratory gases very well is not physiologic.	0.5056535746337565
To overcome these unwanted side effects, we developed a technique of perfluorocarbon vaporisation in analogy to the application of inhalation anaesthetic agents.	0.5125471613261654
After resolving some technical issues, this application technique was used successfully in an animal model of acute lung injury.	0.5703488824776444
Vaporisation of perfluorohexane in a concentration of 18 Vol.% of inspired gas improved significantly oxygenation and lung compliance.	0.5033399182836508
Though these results are promising, mechanisms of action, dose-efficacy relation, surfactant-perfluorocarbon interaction or anti-inflammatory effects of vaporised perfluorohexane are still unclear.	0.5649635499121848
These questions need to be clarified before this technique can be applied clinically.	0.5725007080785981
However, the inhalation of vapor, a technique already familiar to anaesthesiologists should avoid risks of large amounts of fluids in the bronchoalveolar space.	0.5374184911927296
Furthermore, this technique can be administered by established anaesthetic equipment with the advantage of exact dosing, continuous monitoring, and demand application in a way near to clinical routine.	0.6512845697761168
VDD pacing using a single pass lead for complete heart block is well described in adults but there are few reports of its use in children.	0.515104975034991
We have used 6 different standard adult size single pass leads and 5 different pacemaker generators in 21 children and adolescents aged 3.7-17.2 years (mean 9.9 years) and weighing 13.5 to 76 kg (mean 34.3 kg).	0.7727773199816523
Congenital complete heart block was present in 14 patients (with associated heart disease in 2 of them), surgical complete heart block in 6 patients and 2:1 AV block of uncertain cause in 1 patient.	0.7322222723496249
In 10 patients, the VDD system was their first pacing system.	0.6315765880489256
In 11 of the patients, 1-6 previous systems had been used and simultaneous extraction of ventricular leads (10) and/or atrial leads (5) was performed.	0.8578699410134146
All leads were introduced via a subclavian vein puncture (using the extraction sheath when present) and the atrial dipole was placed low in the right atrium to provide slack for further growth while maintaining atrial sensing.	0.6069077197907174
Ventricular thresholds ranged from 0.2 to 0.8 V. The minimal atrial amplitude was 0.7 to 4 mV and the maximum amplitude was 2.5 to 8 mV.	0.865316845462426
There was one early micro-displacement and the lead was repositioned.	0.43030756341208043
Over a follow-up period of 2-64 months (mean 32 months), all but 1 of the patients have maintained low ventricular pacing thresholds and adequate atrial signals for reliable pacing at rest and with exercise.	0.7865996552290195
During this time some have undergone considerable growth.	0.4060452566468706
In 1 patient, atrial sensing was lost after cardiopulmonary bypass for additional cardiac surgery at 24 months and the pacemaker was programmed into VVIR mode.	0.5542592513256183
One patient with coexisting congenital heart disease died suddenly at 3 years but the pacing system had no fault at autopsy.	0.45967825951306646
The standard adult size single pass lead provides a simple means to enable reliable atrial synchronous ventricular pacing in growing children with complete heart block.	0.43348330408447144

The internal fixation is routinely achieved by the use of plates and screws.	0.6116426219527258

Interventional duct occlusion is increasingly performed with detachable coils.	0.310585331882569

They are not securable but can be implanted in a simple manner.	0.694747355540559

This review presents data supporting the involvement of the dopaminergic system in depressive illness.	0.5199933543624724

Athletes who need high endurance capacity often use training at moderately high altitude (1500-3000 m) to improve oxygen delivery and utilization because of a hypoxia-induced increase of the red blood cell volume and adaptations at the muscular level.	0.5599525865117287
As maximal heart rates decrease at high altitude and plasma lactate levels for a given workload change during prolonged exposure to high altitude, it can be difficult to control and adapt the intensity and duration of the work-outs.	0.6185718022394787
Furthermore, maximal performance capacity decreases and therefore training intensity at high altitude is usually reduced compared to training at sea level.	0.45497094326321713
To avoid these disadvantages at high altitude a concept of living at moderately high altitude and training at lower elevations, termed "live high - train low" evolved, opposing the conventional concept of "live high - train high".	0.5484022095128132
A third option using a hypobaric chamber ("live low - train low") is hardly used anymore for training athletes.	0.6601593361436054
Studies on the effects of conventional high-altitude training for the improvement of athletic performance often lack a rigorous controlled design and yield controversial results.	0.4496476606110062
Regarding the new concept of "live high - train low" there is only one controlled study on college athletes and it shows a minor advantage of this new approach compared to conventional high-altitude training.	0.6471380861889862
However, training concepts are especially important for elite competitive athletes, and controlled studies with such individuals are very difficult to perform.	0.6654016207792725
Therefore, it appears that today we cannot answer the question of whether altitude-specific physiologic factors or non-altitude-related benefits of training camps account for the success of individual athletes.	0.6656745108130782

It differs from to the more common form of childhood trichotillomania in that predominantly female adolescents are affected and its incidence is related to quite severely pathologic psychodynamics, often with a disturbed relationship to female sexuality.	0.48334431611112305
The treating physician should be more guarded in assessing the prognosis; hair plucking often continues for years.	0.4123882676978547

Economic evaluations have become more and more important in the somatotherapeutic field.	0.5231756053277755
This survey's objective was to examine if the current economic evaluation techniques can be applied to psychotherapy.	0.609509234624452
8 data banks, 17 key words from the psychotherapeutic field and 14 economic key words were used, the identified original studies were classified in accordance with Drummond, the methodical quality of each study was assessed at a score between 0 and 10 points.	0.5729584823475434
21 studies were found: 16 cost- benefit analyses, 4 cost-effectiveness analyses and one cost-utility analysis.	0.5826333992462192
The quality of the representation of the clinical results (mean value 8.6) was better than that of the economic results (mean value 6.1).	1.0199453414633384
It was perfectly possible to evaluate psychotherapeutic interventions with regard to economic aspects by means of the current techniques but in most cases there was a considerable lack of quality in both representation and calculation.	0.6441407313677294
Furthermore the evaluation type of cost-utility analysis, which is the only one that takes quality of life aspects into consideration and therewith seems to be the most appropriate approach regarding the psychotherapeutic field, has been greatly ignored.	0.7783911708263536
As a net effect of ACE-inhibitors and AT1-receptor antagonists on the renin-angiotensin system (RAS) cardioprotection due to vasodilative (reduction of blood pressure, afterload reduction), antiproliferative (reduced cell growth, reduction of "vascular" andor "ventricular remodeling", reduced formation of extracellular matrix), as well as antiadrenergic actions and due to the stimulating effect on natriuresis, reduction of blood pressure, preload reduction can be expected.	0.5447852735759211
These aims of therapy have mostly been confirmed for the action of ACE-inhibitors by experimental and clinical studies but except for the treatment of arterial hypertension and few preliminary reports concerning the treatment of cardiac dysfunction, no comparable data are available for AT1-receptor antagonists.	0.6961155657270638
To date, an antithrombotic and profibrinolytic action could only be demonstrated for ACE-inhibitors.	0.5331787309334702
This effect has been discussed to be responsible for the improvement of long-term prognosis in patients with coronary artery disease.	0.7257941845440463
Despite the similar spectrum of action there exist important differences between ACE-inhibitors and AT1-receptor antagonists that might underline the need of an individual use of these drugs: the dual action of ACE-inhibitors on the RAS and the kinin system bears many benefits but has been also shown to be accompanied by side-effects, mainly chronic dry cough, in a relatively high percentage of patients thus leading to discontinuation of therapy in 8-14%.	0.6716557232965186
This respective side-effect can be prevented by the use of AT1-receptor antagonists.	0.5493088240164068
It has been discussed whether the incomplete action of ACE-inhibitors on AT1-receptor-mediated effects is at least in part responsible for the efficacy of this drug which is relatively high (75-80%) as compared to other substances.	0.8043586413103399
Due to their direct action, AT1-receptor-blockers might also be of high effectiveness for the treatment of severe heart failure.	0.6369871118203707
A combination of the ACE-inhibitor-mediated activation of the kinin-system with the more specific blockade of AT1-receptors by AT1-receptor antagonists might be of benefit and is currently under investigation.	0.5997706803452606
Finally, it has been discussed that the incresed AT II concentration in case of AT1-receptor-blockade activates AT2-receptor-mediated mechanisms thus leading to an additive vasoprotective effect.	0.6831016912493831

Data from animal experimentation show that an interruption of the system by spinal cord cooling leads to (1) increase in ongoing activity,  (2) lowering in stimulation threshold, and (3) increase in response magnitude in nociceptive dorsal horn neurons.	0.6682849620508104
The influence of the descending system was stronger on the responses to input from deep nociceptors than to input from cutaneous nociceptors.	0.506368590147186

Numerous publications have established that hyperosmolar saline solution can restore arterial blood pressure, cardiac index and oxygen delivery as well as organ perfusion to pre-shock values.	0.5173559587117768
Most prehospital studies failed to yield conclusive results with respect to a reduction in overall mortality.	0.43541743360076907

The utility of electron beam computed tomography (EBT) to estimate cerebral blood volume (CBV) and cerebral blood flow (CBF) was evaluated.	0.666188844976437
Eleven patients with suspected acute cerebral ischemia were investigated.	0.5825038309586187
The EBT was performed with an acquisition time of 50 ms per slice at eight parallel levels.	0.4813908107830771
To compare signal/noise and contrast/ noise ratios the data from the EBT investigation were compared to a similar examination on a spiral CT.	0.5712735488456084
The signal/noise ratio with EBT was about 30%, the contrast/noise ratio 25% of that with spiral CT.	0.6746640683319148
The absolute values of CBV were 4.9 +/- 1.2 ml/100 g (EBT); CBF was 50.5 +/- 7.0 ml/100 g/min in normal contralateral brain tissue.	0.6272203399659532
In four patients with proven infarcts on follow-up, the ischemic areas had a CBV ranging from 1.7 to 3.8 ml/100 g, while CBF ranged from 9.4 to 24.5 ml/100 g/min.	0.8025294826627668
Using a bolus injection of contrast material, calculation of absolute CBV and CBF is feasible using EBT.	0.4202584153356537
Advantages of EBT are the absolute measurements possible and it's multislice capability.	0.43280796488317863

She was found unconscious, without measurable blood pressure; the electrocardiogram (ECG) showed bradycardia of 30/min and the rectal temperature was 23.7  °C.	0.6768799775853743
The patient received mechanical ventilation, fluid therapy, warmed gastric lavage, and, unfortunately, inotropic medication.	0.6065479633001056
She was transferred to a department of cardiac surgery in order to continue the therapy with cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB).	0.5136254889722415
On arrival, the patient had a rectal temperature of 27.3  °C, the ECG showed an absolute arrhythmia with a frequency of 70/min, and the blood pressure was 63/43 mm Hg.	0.921731385693829
We decided to use a rapidly available but not highly invasive venovenous hemofiltration technique for slowly rewarming the patient.	0.38932027855838325
Vascular access was achieved by percutaneous femoral vein cannulation with a Shaldon catheter.	0.41967387215341073
The hemofiltration system (Gambro AK-10, Gambro AB, Sweden) was instituted with a blood flow rate of 200 ml/min.	0.5681886065497289
The hemofiltration monitor controls the pumps for filtering and substituting fluid volumes and allows the infusion solutions to be heated up to 40  °C.	0.34711085173376655
Sinus rhythm resumed without antiarrhythmic medications at a temperature of 29.5  °C, and within 8 h the patient was rewarmed to 35.5  °C.	0.7871180893641232
After treatment of the adult respiratory distress syndrome caused by pneumonia, she was discharged from the intensive care unit to complete treatment with no evidence of any permanent organ damage.	0.7110515645556432
We conclude that hemofiltration may be the method of choice for rewarming deeply hypothermic patients when their circulation is preserved.	0.5392749527257409
Under these circumstances, it is preferable to external rewarming techniques, as it avoids the disadvantages of temperature afterdrop and rewarming shock.	0.6563252045596584
Rewarming rates of 1.5  °C/h seem to be adequate.	0.8551109990451276
Hemofiltration systems are more widespread, less invasive, and easier to handle compared to CPB techniques, which should be preferred in situations of prolonged unsuccessful cardiopulmonary resuscitation with cardiac arrest and deep core temperatures.	0.6629617626698098

The original reason for using the German "Habilitation" degree to mean that a candidade had qualified and could conduct research and teach at a university is no longer really valid, as this is being threatened by its importance to further careers.	0.5269502527330014
Medical faculties must discuss how this development can be curtailed.	0.3378401391907035
In order to check the current situation, the Habilitation degree systems of 36 medical faculties of German universities were compared with the aid of a scoring system.	0.6270021777347068
Conformity existed only in the demand for a doctoral dissertation, scientific publications and a lecture on approval.	0.48086411315840555
Concerning other criteria for qualification there was decreasing consensus in the following order: Habilitation thesis, commitment to teaching, further professional education, participation in congresses, inaugural lecture, qualification to teach, scientific activity, broad background in the discipline, and introduction to the faculty.	0.5178882050177017
Application of the scoring system with a maximum of 33 score points resulted in a mean value of 15.2 points and a range from 6 to 29 points.	0.7023997523734995
A significant decrease in the score values occurred with increasing age of the Habilitation degree (P = 0.002).	0.6177268990465165

Molecular atmospheric oxygen contains two unpaired electrons in the unreactive triplet state and thus has to be activated in order to react with other biological molecules in the singlet ground state.	0.3837863289758955
These processes of activation include very reactive intermediates.	0.25188150306407137
Therefore, aerobic cells must cope with - and to some extent also adapt to - oxidative stress provoked for example by infection or intoxication, where reactive intermediates of oxygen activation accumulate.	0.7144299389429491
Depending on the strength of these impacts, several symptoms indicate the deviation from normal, steady-state metabolism.	0.4917174019420477
Most of these visible or measurable symptoms are connected with oxygen activation where principally a transition from heterolytic reactions (two-electron transitions) to increased homolytic reactions (one-electron transitions) is observed.	0.5763248007464421
Homolytic reactions produce free radicals, which are generally counteracted by a parallel increase of intrinsic radical scavenging processes or by compounds administered with food, thus warranting metabolic control within certain limits.	0.5354507880808946
At advanced states of stress, control may be gradually lost and chaotic radical processes dominate.	0.3694961020028221
Finally, cellular decompartmentalizations yield apoptotic, lytic and/or necrotic processes.	0.3520126761285579
Every episode during this cascade is characterizable by the balance between pro- and antioxidative capacities.	0.45084666490048647
Antioxidants, which in many cases are free radical scavengers or quenchers of activated states, comprise a wealth of classes of organic molecules including phenolics, probably as the most prominent ones.	0.6382060739590761
In this article, mechanisms of oxygen activation and protection from oxidative damage are discussed.	0.4599227087491862
Furthermore, examples of antioxidative functions of a few important natural products are reported.	0.421076295256769

After implantation all specimens were evaluated again by CAT and CCT and AT angle were documented again.	0.37771616865309254
The preoperative CCD angle was 126.7  ° (SD = 4.0) in the manual group and 127.8  ° (SD = 4.3) in the robodoc group.	0.7562572941801128
Postoperatively the angle averaged 131.9  ° (SD = 0.8) in the manual group and 133.2  ° (SD = 1.9) in the robodoc group.	0.7714762773356926
Significant differences were found for the AT angle in both groups.	0.7016584698587255
The preoperative AT angle in the manual group was 31.3  ° (SD = 8.8), decreasing to 20.5  ° (SD = 9.5) after implantation.	0.7398957384990247
In the robodoc group this angle was 30.9  ° (SD = 8.0) before and 31.3  ° (SD = 8.7) after implantation.	0.7323246118757526
The difference between pre- and postoperative AT angle averaged 10.8  ° (SD = 6.4) in the manual group and only 0.4  ° (SD = 0.9) in the robodoc-group.	0.9015681837056174
Conclusion: With the technique used, preoperative planning in hip alloarthroplasty is much more accurate than with the conventional technique with plain X-ray.	0.7269382256942397
The virtual preoperative planning can be transferred to the intraoperative setting with high precision.	0.4743933297953315
These factors may lead to an increase in outcome quality.	0.5349518933542258

The incidence of methadone-related fatalities has increased in the last two years.	0.8709885074868715
The highest incidence was found in 1995 when methadone was detected in the blood of about 20% of all drug-related fatalities.	0.8822739471579587
Lethal monointoxications or combined intoxications with a dominant role of methadone were experienced rarely (about 1% of all drug-related fatalities).	0.6308545841648495

Morbus Parkinson is a progressive degenerative disease of the human central, peripheral, and enteric nervous systems.	0.6373800983874792
In the course of the disease, not only the substantia nigra, but also extranigral components of the motor system, as well as numerous limbic system and autonomic centers undergo serious damage.	0.6872667120166847
Accordingly, Parkinson's disease is a multisystem disorder.	0.5977494789428902
Only specific types of projection neurons fall victim to it.	0.2476522166173152
The first manifestation of the pathological process which causes the disease are abnormalities of the neuronal cytoskeleton.	0.5967236197493012

Non-specific endogenic osteomyelitis represents the most frequent form, followed by the specific form caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.	0.6583841282343958

and at Ward's triangle were made in a total of 100 patients.	0.4841765112358499
The subjects were repositioned between measurements.	0.25285549038340643
In order to be able to determine the influence of various diseases, four groups of 25 patients each were formed: three with the diagnosis osteoarthrosis, osteoporosis and rheumatoid arthritis and one control group.	0.6774656031416462
The mean percentual difference and coefficient of variation were calculated as the measure for reproducibility.	0.3888187269063832
Mean percentual differences of 0.18 to 2.6% were found in the four groups at the three measurements sites.	0.9256066653924662
After calculation of coefficient of variation, a value between 1.2 and 2.7% was found for LWS p.a., between 7.1 and 15.7% for LWS lat.	0.9271542429065944
and between 4.1 and 9.9% at Ward's triangle.	0.8160282989983767
It was also conspicuous that the difference in coefficient of variation in osteoporosis patients was nearly double that in the control group in all measured areas.	0.5917485221743964

The diagnosis of tracheal rupture was confirmed by fiberoptic bronchoscopy.	0.5074790106271514

The liver is the major site for biotransformation of most opioids.	0.5096595530407487
The major metabolic pathway is oxidation.	0.24078476876934993
Exceptions to this are morphine and buprenorphine, which undergo primarily glucuronidation, and remifentanil which is cleared by esther hydrolysis.	0.5413003242240824

Even if Ignaz Philipp Semmelweis has not found the true aetiology of puerperal fever - bacteria were identified as pathogens only after his observations - he was the first to consequently use epidemiological methods in order to elucidate connections and influencing factors in the spread of nosocomial infections, to draw the right conclusions from his observations on the transmission of childbed fever and to draw the right consequences by implementing preventive measures, especially the hand disinfection.	0.6475912026685505

Results of a longitudinal study about the transition to retirement are presented.	0.5518699336037493

In adults, infectious spondylitis is a rare but severe disease, caused by a bacterial thrombus in tissue of reduced resistance.	0.6861059823426365
In conventional radiographs initial findings are a narrowing of the intervertebral space, local osteoporosis and poorly defined erosive borders of the vertebral endplates.	0.6263534775552564
These changings can be found at least three to six weeks after the onset of disease.	0.7788738269695037
However, in Szintigraphy and MRT pathologic alterations are evident after ten to twelve days.	0.48052992364280933
Thus, early diagnosis and treatment becomes possible.	0.8221109947926759
In early stages of the disease a localized lysis surrounded by a reactive sclerosis appears in predisposed areas of the vertebral body (subchondral, anterobasal, ventral, central).	0.5881185985362236
Apparently, a soft tissue tumor is associated.	0.6302838134017802
Sclerosis and reduction of the soft tissue tumor are the first signs of repair processes.	0.6270394464514045
After at least 12 weeks, computed tomography can reveal typical sintering of the vertebral body and occasionally the development of a bony sequester.	0.5835516946240952
In addition, MRT as well as CT can be helpful in the detection and localization of complications as abscesses or affection of the vertebral canal.	0.6687342744198874
The tuberculous spondylitis can sometimes cause difficulties in differential diagnosis.	0.22239500527174885
Clinical findings, affection of several vertebral bodies, large soft tissue tumors with appearance of calcification as well as not typical locations are strongly suggestive of tuberculous spondylitis, but these findings are not specific of the disease.	0.6313039076457199
Degenerative disorders such as erosive osteochondrosis or changings due to chronic dialysis (e. g. amyloid or crystal arthropathies) may cause even more problems in differential diagnosis.	0.5127718700616438
Typical for a blastomatous process is the integrity of the interverebral disc space, which is a rare finding in spondylitis.	0.7820611410591383

An essential parameter for the incorporation of drugs and narcotics into head hair is the content of hair pigment (melanins).	0.451583805881264
Toxicological studies of hair should therefore take the colour of the hair into consideration.	0.5359692884705622
As the available vocabulary for verbal characterisation is small and the description depends on the subjective opinion of the viewer, it was the purpose of this study to investigate if colorimetric measurements allow objectivation of hair colour.	0.6819412069782966
The natural hair colour of 17 subjects was described subjectively in words and by comparing it with a hair colour chart (Wella, Darmstadt, Germany).	0.44876141828792243
Subsequently the colours of the hair and the samples of the hair colour chart used for comparison were measured by colorimetric analysis and the CIEL*a*b* values were determined.	0.5961428698454181
The descriptive categorisation of the hair colours (e.g.	0.371710626683632
blonde, brown, black) could often not be recognised in the colorimetric results.	0.5020740785451444
Sometimes considerable differences were also found between the colour values of the natural hair samples and the specimens used for comparison.	0.6928379219074441
When the colour measurements were repeated at intervals of several days the results were found to be reproducible.	0.6805427905781171
We measured the ventilatory pattern and additional work of breathing (WOBadd) at three different levels of inspiratory pressure support [IPS 5, 10, 15 mbar above positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP)] and in a new ventilatory mode, automatic tube compensation (ATC), in nine operative patients without lung injury nine patients ventilated for several following acute respiratory insufficiency (ARI).	0.6513426631133011
In ATC, endotracheal tube resistance is compensated automatically by means of closed-loop control of the calculated tracheal pressure.	0.5268589854707217
Pressure support in this mode, i. e. airway pressure above PEEP, is equal to the actual flow-dependent pressure drop across the endotracheal tube (ETT).	0.5951980229085196
Airway pressure rises at the beginning of inspiration and falls towards the end.	0.37510543584493206
As the tube resistance of ETT seriously hinders expiration and can cause desynchronization between ventilator and patient, airway pressure is reduced below PEEP during expiration in the same way as it is increased during inspiration.	0.5074889824092548
The result is a near-constant tracheal pressure at PEEP both during inspiration and during expiration.	0.45224535657412573
This mode could be best termed as "electronic extubation".	0.3576666125120707
The most striking difference between the postoperative patients and the ARI patients was their minute ventilation (17.8+/-1.85 l/min in ARI patients vs 7.3+/-3.1 l/min in the postoperative patients).	0.8696643499848321
In the postoperative patients augmentation of IPS from 5 to 15 mbar induced a steady increase in tidal volume (VT) and a consecutive decrease in respiratory rate (rr) compared with ATC (VTATC,postop= 463+/-78 ml; rrATC,postop =16+/-4 min-1; VTIPS5,postop = 505+/-79 ml; rrIPS5,postop = 15+/-4 min-1; VTIPS10,postop = 562+/-86 ml; rrIPS15,postop =14+/-4 min-1; VTIPS15,postop=660+/- 151 ml; rrTPS15, postop = 12+/-4 min-1), whereas the augmentation of IPS of 5 and 10 mbar in the ARI patients could not compensate for the increase in rr and the decrease in VT, after switching from ATC to IPS (VTATC,ARI 724+/-308 ml, rrATC,ARI = 24+/-6 min-1; VTIPS5,ARI = 649+/-315 ml; rrIPS 5,ARI = 27+/-8 min-1; VTIPS10,ARI=653+/-353 ml; rrIPS10,ARI = 25+/-8 min-1: Even IPS 15 was not able to reestablish VT at the values observed during ATC (VTIPS15,ARI =680+/-312 ml).	0.609696372621619
During ATC WOBadd was small in both postoperative and ARI patients (WOBadd,ATC,postop = 93+/-36 mJ/l, WOBadd,ATC,ARI =116 +/-72 mJ/l).	0.5553365736568707
In the postoperative patients, an inspiratory pressure support of 5 mbar was not sufficient to compensate WOBadd compared with ATC.	0.7002782962360968
However, IPS 10 and 15 mbar were able to compensate for WOBadd (WOBadd.ATC5,postop WOBadd,IPS5,postop =189+/-77 mJ/l; WOBadd,IPS10,postop = 55+/-30 mJ/l; WOBadd,IPS15,postop = 21+/-11 mJ/l).	0.567834154363608
In the ARI patients an IPS 5, 10 or 15 mbar was not sufficient to compensate for WOBadd (WOBadd,IPS 5,ARI = 1126+/-262 mJ/l; WOBadd,IPS 10,ARI 863+/-253 mJ/l; WOBadd,IPS 15,ARI 763+/-298 mJ/l).	0.5748761458510692
Under ATC, WOBadd was only 15% of WOBadd under IPS of 15 mbar.	0.6114895720463259
All but two patients were successfully extubated after the investigation.	0.5785521361602803
These two patients were not extubated because they were dependent on an FIO2 >0.5.	0.6234984502626537
Our results strongly indicate that ventilatory dependence in ARI patients may be caused by the ETT rather than by mechanical dysfunction of the lung.	0.617653148532158
ATC is a very helpful mode to use in distinguishing between ventilatory failure caused by ETT and real ventilatory dependence.	0.5179056394135637
The preoperative localization of pharmaco-resistent focal epilepsies before surgery and the prognosis concerning seizure outcome are both of importance.	0.5378050187808341

In 55 consecutive patients with the same dual chamber pacemaker (Relay, Intermedics) and different pacing leads, the influence of different safety margins for pacing on battery current was investigated.	0.675174438688931
2.8 +/- 0.9 years after implantation, atrial and ventricular pulse-width thresholds (tRS) (ms) were determined at 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0 V, and the charge delivered at threshold was telemetered.	0.9161359434194848
If tRS was <1.50 ms at 0.5 V, an amplitude of 1.0 V was programmed in the atrium and the ventricule; if tRS was <1.50 ms at 1.0 V, then an amplitude of 2.0 V was chosen.	0.7159768475085421
Two times the charge threshold (2x QRS), two times the voltage threshold (2x URS), and three times the pulse-width threshold (3x tRS) were programmed as the safety margins for pacing.	0.671976570636447
With every safety margin, battery current (IRS) (µA) was averaged from 5 telemetric readings in D00 mode with 70 bpm.	0.5231038829125596
IBat was significantly lower with 2x QRS as compared with 2x URS (13.43 +/- 1.0 vs. 14.20 +/- 1.2 µA, p<0.01) and as compared with 3x tRS (13.99 +/- 1.2 µA, p<0.05).	0.6747065091320197
Pacemaker longevity derived from these current data was significantly longer with 2x QRS (112 +/- 8 months) as compared with 2x URS (106 +/- 9, p<0.01) and as compared with 3x tRS (108 +/- 8, p<0.05).	0.6928128691717013
If current consumption is compared intraindividually in dependance on the programmed amplitude, battery current is significantly lower at 1.0 V as compared with 2.0 V resulting in a mean reduction of 0.63 µA (-4.9%, p<0.05) and an average gain in longevity of 5 months.	0.7855217677102343
This applies to every safety margin tested.	0.33021689203784016
Differences in battery current caused by the safety margins will translate into a greater gain in longevity in future pacemaker models with reduced internal current consumption.	0.4472808285831171
Any medical procedure must be legally authorized by the patient, giving informed consent.	0.554423663281514
This prerequisite is based on the right to self determination.	0.7702097169273014
Otherwise a medical procedure is considered as physical injury.	0.5273919600109621
Thus, the way, how a specific procedure is performed, predominantly depends on the patient's will.	0.8325249621971228

Before the procedure the physician has to have a confidential talk with the patient.	0.6495741517920632

In 25 patients additional subcutaneous patch or array electrodes and in 2 patients additional epicardial patch electrodes were implanted.	0.49969994037869886
Implantation site was in 92 patients abdominal and in 248 pectoral.	0.37521334998100714
Over a period of 7 years 34 lead-related complications occured in 33 patients (9.7%), after a median of 2 months after implantation.	0.7725271157088865
Diagnosis was made by routine chest x-ray in about 55% of lead-related complications, by clinical presentation (inadequate therapy, pain) in 24%, and by electrical parameters in 21%.	0.8327283966023912
In patients with an abdominal implantation site, lead-related complications occurred in 20%, in contrast to 6% in patients with a pectoral implantation site.	0.9618006921904363

There were no differences in clinical parameters between patients with pectoral vs abdominal and between single vs dual-chamber ICD.	0.5661058639557909
Several new approaches are available for early defibrillation.	0.5356105070759287
One example is semiautomatic defibrillators used by the first arriving emergency staff.	0.48198225633256125
The recommendations for introducing emergency medical technician (EMT) defibrillation in Germany are based either on the results in cities with so called doctor-manned-ambulances or the experiences of the German multi-center-study.	0.5953075983557695
This analysis intends to contribute data to an EMT defibrillation program in cities with a so called rendezvous-system.	0.44153034806947167
Methods: In a prospective study a EMT-defibrillation group (= DG) was compared with a standard group (basic life support by EMTs and defibrillation by emergency physicians) (= SG) and a control group (emergency physicians starting resuscitation alone or together with EMTs) (= CG).	0.7993866858841853
In the DG semiautomatic defibrillators from Laerdal (Heartstart 3000) were used.	0.5589372085690126
Successfully resuscitated patients were followed up with the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), the Pittsburgh Brain Stem Score (PBSS), and Pittsburgh Cerebral (CPC) and Overall Performance Categorie (OPC).	0.5816063136009962
Results: Over 13 months 43 patients were included, primarily presenting with ventricular fibrillation (VF).	0.5307139952550045
Depending on the first arriving emergency staff the patients were allocated to the DG (n = 12), to the SG (n = 18) or to the CG (n = 13).	0.6934807345426574
DG and SG did not differ significantly concerning the primary survival rate or the long-term prognosis (primary successful 8.3% vs. 38.9%, definite successful 0% vs. 27.8%).	0.5945552159867113
The primary survival rate in the DG was significantly lower than in the CG (8.3% vs. 61.5%).	0.7127413227672685
In the long term survival rate there were no significant differences.	0.6987247080182586
In the DG significantly less patients received bystander CPR (8.3%) than in the other groups (55.6% and 69.2%).	0.8116678549626796
Neither the variable "witnessed collapes" nor "bystander CPR" had a significant influence for the outcome of the patients in this study.	0.7704973587229421
The average response time for the first arriving rescue team was 5.5 +/- 2.4 min, without a significant difference between the groups.	0.8840809984624567
Conclusions: A comparison of this study with American, European and German recommendations for EMT defibrillation programms revealed some deviations.	0.6177140455635385
Bystander CPR seems to be of special importance as well as the time interval between defibrillation and the arrival of the emergency physician.	0.7720117862915387
A benefit of EMT defibrillation could not be demonstrated in our "rendezvous-system", possibly because the time interval was less than 4 min (3.5 min).	0.8203937280653495
Since the result is in accordance with the German multi-center-study, a critical consideration of a EMT defibrillation program seems to be necessary in "Rendezvous-systems".	0.7162835231236816

Sole Mepivacain-HCl treatment had significant less pain reduction compared to the other treatment modalities.	0.5443974700083892

Taking into account that patients increasingly prefer ethnomedical modalities of treatment our study gains importance for practising  orthopaedists.	0.43658156837341744
This paper concerns advances in the integration of psychotherapy in psychiatric education and clinical practice and whether they go along with increasing research activities.	0.5473917037630351
To find answers, a survey on psychotherapy research was carried out in all German psychiatric hospitals and departments by means of a questionnaire.	0.6176281009878285
The results indicate that psychotherapy research is done nearly exclusively in university hospitals.	0.39741650175378307
About half of them had already published psychotherapy studies and two thirds of them are presently carrying out studies, mostly including prospective, randomized clinical trials.	0.6481562418546036
These studies cover the whole spectrum of psychiatric disorders: substance abuse, schizophrenic and affective disorders, anxiety, and obsessive compulsive and personality disorders.	0.4951683224208318
To improve psychotherapy research conditions further, efforts are necessary to increase scientific exchange, financial support, and the integration of institutions outside the universities.	0.6437087996824192
There is little to suggest that the course of preeclamsia can be substantially affected by drug treatment.	0.5538712539133959
The vast majority of randomized studies do not indicate beneficial effects of antihypertensive treatment on proteinuria, fetal heart rate abnormalities, abruptio placentae and the incidence of preterm birth.	0.48404862815117566
There is also no definite effect on the development of superimposed preeclampsia, HELLP syndrome, renal failure or eclampsia.	0.5948139211280046
Moreover, blood pressure lowering agents fail to improve uteroplacental perfusion but may have adverse effects on fetal growth.	0.5397300625997237
Antihypertensive treatment is only indicated in severe hypertension ( > 170/110 mm Hg) to reduce the risk of cerebral hemorrhage.	0.7657376567550839
Dihydralazine injections may result in reduced placental blood flow and fetal distress.	0.46812316598378556
Oral nifedipine offers some advantages in view of more potent vasodilator actions on uterine and fetoplacental vessels and a lower incidence of fetal distress.	0.4582587253050422
Increasing evidence suggests that the mechanism of eclamptic seizure is cerebral vasoconstriction with resultant ischemia.	0.45685047757992336
Cerebral vessels are particularly sensitive to magnesium, which works by reversing cerebral vasoconstriction with resultant improvement in blood flow.	0.4924463468326065
Controlled trials have shown magnesium to be superior to both placebo and phenytoin for the prevention of eclampsia.	0.4274442037726476
Furthermore, magnesium has been found to be more effective than diazepam and phenytoin in preventing recurrence of seizures in women with eclampsia.	0.615264233789746
Also the neonatal outcome favors magnesium, which is now generally accepted as the drug of choice for the prevention and treatment of eclampsia.	0.7105821837027022

The subjective and objective results were evaluated with a questionnaire and a clinical examination and sonography (follow-up: 95 %).	0.719522153589774
All patients were examinated before surgery, sonography and X-ray of the knee were performed.	0.7761760759361653

Arthroscopy was performed in all secondary forms of Baker's cyst.	0.5972863773056047
Postoperative complications were two reinterventions due to one hematoma and one effusion.	0.4317513676303654
Patient's evaluation of operation result was "excellent" in 61 % and "good" in 39 % of cases.	0.8388210362407192
All knee joints had a full range of motion.	0.43733118186131953
There was only one case of a recurrent cyst.	0.8420615536130871
The primary form of Baker's cyst has always to be extirpated, according to our clinical experience.	0.4959385078189628
The extirpation of the secondary Baker's cyst and the relevance of arthroscopy and treatment of the basic disease have to be discussed.	0.7208530030322214

Classic and HIV-associated Kaposi's sarcoma (KS) are predominantly found in male Caucasians.	0.6115543945784043
It is unclear why KS is so rare in women.	0.3851384308909069
At the Department of Dermatology, University of Frankfurt, epidemic KS was diagnosed in 299/751 (40%) male and 5/72 (18%) female HIV-infected patients.	0.5467105332685701
To detect common parameters regarding immunodeficiency, hormonal disturbances, abnormalities in clinical course, or sexual practices, data of eight women with KS (five HIV+, three HIV-) were compared.	0.7632167950260417
In HIV+ women KS is more aggressive than in HIV- women and more aggressive than in HIV+ men.	0.5123149414180576
Early and frequent visceral involvement and no preference for the lower extremities are found.	0.4966125065582027

All women with KS investigated for sexual hormones (7/8) showed abnormalities: 7/7 had low oestrogens, 4/6 low LH and 3/5 low progesterone.	0.6629844265703129
Controls (n=11, HIV+ without KS) showed a clear trend for higher serum levels of sexual hormones, but the difference was not significant.	0.7204499316217736

There was no correlation between sexual practices (anal or oral-faecal contacts) and the manifestation or aggressiveness of KS.	0.6129623089407806
The aim of the study was the assessment of left ventricular (LV) systolic function and left ventricular mass following aortic valve replacement (AVR) due to aortic valve stenosis as well as the influence of regression of LV hypertrophy in patients with normal and impaired LV systolic function prior to surgery.	0.6845556176426032
74 patients with severe aortic valve stenosis (29 female, 45 male, mean age 66  +/-  18 years) were divided into 2 groups according to LV ejection fraction (EF): Group 1 with EF > 50% (n = 40); Group 2 with EF <= 50% (n = 34).	0.8026055576555131
Furthermore, patients were differentiated into a group A without (n = 53) and a group B with aortic regurgitation (<= II °, n = 21).	0.8266199261203312
All patients were examined by transthoracic echocardiography before and 1 month after surgery.	0.8804064079103994
There was a significant decrease of LV enddiastolic and endsystolic valume indices following AVR in group 2 and group B.	0.6185425514316127
Patients with preoperatively lower EF (group 2) showed an increase in LV ejection fraction from 39  +/-  10% before AVR to 47  +/-  11% after AVR (p < 0.001), whereas patients with preoperative normal EF (group 1) showed a significant decrease in EF (from 62  +/-  8% to 57  +/-  10%, p < 0.05).	0.7578066002476357
Also patients with combined aortic valve disease before AVR had an increase of EF after surgery (from 45 %plusmn; 14% to 56  +/-  14%, p < 0.03).	0.6481718600903389
There were significant decreases of interventricular septum thickness and LV posterior wall thickness in group 1 and group A, whereas a significant decrease of LV anddiastolic diameter index was noted only in group B.	0.6330572622955591
Improvement of the NYHA functional class could be demonstrated in group 2 from 2.8  +/-  0.7 before to 2.2  +/-  0.6 after AVR, as well as in group B from 2.9  +/-  0.7 before to 1.9  +/-  0.7 after surgery.	0.8761439511122365
In conclusion, patients with impaired LV function or combined aortic valve disease showed a significant improvement of left ventricular systolic function after AVR, while patients with normal LV function presented a slight decrease of EF.	0.7357249861231367
There was a significant regression of left ventricular muscle mass in all groups independent of the left ventricular functional status.	0.8685291660823105
Cardiomyocytes lose the ability to proliferate after birth.	0.2787334382010088
Subsequently, irreversible cellular damage, e.g., during myocardial infarction, causes loss of functional properties and cell replacement by fibrotic tissue.	0.5531192584743057
It is, therefore, not surprising that cell replacement strategies such as cardiomyocyte transplantation in damaged myocardium or scar tissue has gained widespread interest.	0.4497257116458609
In other species such as mice, rats, and dogs, the technical feasibility of skeletal myoblast-, satellite cell-, and fetal cardiomyocyte engraftment into normal and diseased myocardium has been demonstrated by simple injection methods.	0.5977087803601849
Repeatedly, it has been shown that transplanted cells may survive for weeks within host myocardium and build intercellular connections such as grap junctions and desmosomes.	0.5551650817911138
In contrast, grafthost connections have not, as yet, been convincingly demonstrated.	0.5161635904312152
Hypothetically, cell transplants might exhibit the following functional properties: stabilization of diseased tissue to prevent structural remodeling; carrier for recombinant proteins, growth factors or drugs to induce molecular alterations of host myocardium; and improvement of regional and global myocardial function due to active contractility.	0.48725314932279906
However, clear evidence of coordinated contractility of transplanted cells, and, thus, of a clinically relevant therapeutical use of cardiomyocyte transplantation as a replacement strategy for damaged host cardiac cells, remains to be demonstrated.	0.6478627138060715

The continuous high frequency stimulation of basal ganglia is the newest technic; it is highly adaptable to the patient's need and carries a low morbidity profile.	0.6346298586136663
Thalamic stimulation is used for the treatment of tremor.	0.6147218160427205

The Medtronic Thera/Thera-i (and Kappa 400) pacemakers utilize a mode switching algorithm that switches from the DDD/R mode to the DDIR mode in the presence on an atrial tachyarrhythmia.	0.45640652464995746
To accomplish this, the pacemaker keeps track of a mean atrial rate (MAR) which is a weighted index of the atrial rate.	0.7631316883857301
Once the MAR is greater than the programmed mode switch rate the pacemaker mode switches to the nontracking mode.	0.3458540384321328
Because the algorithm weights faster atrial rates more heavily than slow atrial rates, the algorithm is sensitive to a wide variety of atrial tachyarrhythmias, including those with varying amplitudes.	0.6405297504959503
Additionally, the algorithm provides a long PVARP and a rate adaptive (RA) AV interval.	0.48309462954559473
These not only help ensure that a wide range of atrial rates will be detected, but may also limit the time the patient tracks at the upper rate before mode switching.	0.5959149597802313
In order to assess the effectiveness of the algorithm, the Thera-i provides detailed diagnostics which provide information on the date, time, duration, and rate of the mode switch episodes.	0.7607007810065534
Additionally, more detailed beat-to-beat information is provided for each episode which can help determine its appropriateness and can assist in making programming changes.	0.5605039182000845

Large B-cell neoplasms represent one of the most frequent groups of non-Hodgkin-lymphomas (30-40%).	0.6906021329255552
They are characterised by an aggressive clinical course.	0.4412945862083136
These lymphomas may evolve either de novo or secondary during the course of a less aggressive lymphoma.	0.3981718534365368
In addition to primary nodal, a primary extranodal manifestation is rather common.	0.6738376460402687
The neoplastic cells, even within one given case, show a broad morphological spectrum.	0.6380722955420757
Several findings of the last two decades have revealed that the large B-cell lymphomas represent an inhomogeneous group.	0.7425375159443364
This fact has been taken into account by the new WHO classification of malignant lymphomas.	0.5874312198688694
There are two groups identified, that of the variants and that of the subtypes.	0.8546784883091346
The various variants (centroblastic, immunoblastic, anaplastic, T-cell/histiocyte-rich) correspond to lymphomas without reproducible discriminating criteria lacking characteristic clinical, immunophenotypical and genetic findings.	0.42173802817187367
In contrast, the primary mediastinal, the intravascular, the primary effusion and primary central nervous system lymphomas represent distinct disease entities.	0.6944117709237555

In a control group, the proprioception of 30 healthy volunteers with clinical and anamnestic inconspicous knee joints was examined.	0.5710449581252196
We tested the proprioceptive capability of the subjects with a passive angle reproduction test.	0.41872534249978355
Additionally, all knee joints were measured with and without an elastic knee bandage.	0.6313802586192153
The patient group showed significant deterioration of angle reproduction capability (13.2  °  +/-  6.1  °) compared to the control group (7.8  °  +/-  2.8  °).	0.8695968392551996
After applying an elastic knee bandage, the angle reproduction capability significantly improved to 9.2  °  +/-  4.5  °.	0.8525312861583673
Proprioception of the contralateral, noninvolved knee joint in the patients (11.6  °  +/-  6.3  °) was worse compared to the control group.	0.9271789819949823

Atrial fibrillation is the most commonly encountered sustained arrhythmia in men.	0.7565884308354814
It is associated with a two-fold mortality risk and an increased cost for health care providers.	0.6378274484493877
The relative inefficacy and the risks of pharmacologic approaches to atrial fibrillation therapy have contributed to increasing efforts to address atrial fibrillation with curative ablative strategies.	0.4676975919972555
Ablation approaches for atrial fibrillation focus on two alternate strategies: ablation of the substrate for initiation and ablation of the substrate for maintenance of atrial fibrillation.	0.45325841923308424
It has been demonstrated that atrial fibrillation may be initiated by repetitive atrial premature beats originating from a single focus.	0.6872529542281572
These ectopic foci can be mapped and ablated, thereby removing the substrate for initiation of atrial fibrillation.	0.4379523844415152
Most often, these atrial premature beats arise from the pulmonary veins.	0.7110383404967316
A challenge in trying to ablate the trigger is actually having enough spontaneous activity from the said focus throughout the electrophysiologic study.	0.3479194642023434
To sidestep the need of mapping, pure anatomic approaches are currently under investigation to electrically isolate the pulmonary veins from the atrial myocardium by circumferential lesions.	0.4858367547859632
In patients without a defined trigger for atrial fibrillation, efforts were made to ablate the substrate for maintenance of atrial fibrillation.	0.5744626896096415
Strong evidence exists that atrial fibrillation is the result of multiple coexisting reentrant wavelets requiring a critical myocardial mass to perpetuate.	0.4721298503898298
Several working groups demonstrated that intraoperative compartmentalization of the myocardial tissue by surgical incisions or radiofrequency pulses is highly effective in preventing atrial fibrillation.	0.3871059386196658
Currently, attempts were made to reproduce the surgical technique using transveneous, catheter-based approaches.	0.5682864849686007
Though our knowledge of ablation techniques and technical prerequisites is continuously increasing, the difficulty to produce complete linear lesions in the left atrium and local thrombus formation at the ablation line are problems that are still not solved.	0.6364911911912517
Using a time-budget method in a 3 year longitudinal study with a control group design, substantial reductions in the engagement of non-obligatory instrumental, social, and leisure activities could be found in a group of mildly to moderately demented patients.	0.6122908054894141
Controlling these changes for differences in baseline paramters, the dementia-specific reduction was about 1,5 hours compared to a non-psychiatric control group.	0.593874691041096
These clinically relevant changes in activity levels underscore the importance of these activity domains with regard to the development of diagnostically useful indicators at the early stages of dementia.	0.48777550758850907
Time-budget methods seem to be particularly useful to close the diagnostic gap with regard to the assessment of everyday competence indicators especially at early stages of the dementia illness.	0.6174306125156579
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a disease with different etiological, morphological, functional, clinical and therapeutic aspects.	0.778119048852201
Recent investigations indicate that HCM is considerably widespread in the population (1:500).	0.6148339691356902
The causes seem to generate from familial or sporadic abnormalities (mutations).	0.36325577974944195
Depending on the clinical aspect, the complaints, and on the basis of morphologic and hemodynamic investigational results, we mainly have to consider two types of medical and surgical management.	0.8102992863917979
Atrial fibrillation is in 20-50% the most frequent dysrhythmia after coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and a possible cause for hemodynamical complications and prolongation off the medical treatment in patients.	0.842773272731107
Therefore, the effect of -blocking with metoprolol for prevention of supraventricular arrhythmias (SVA) was investigated in a prospective and randomized trial.	0.8506604258313918
200 patients after CABG were randomized in a drug and control group (average age 63.2 years, 154 male, 46 female).	0.5867749426091255
Patients of the drug group (n=100) were treated with metoprolol (1mg/kg/BW) beginning on day one after operation, whereas patients of the control group (n=100) received therapy only in case of occurrence of atrial fibrillaton.	0.7097300079606295
ECG, blood pressure, and electrolyte concentrations were measured regulary until the tenth day after surgery.	0.5959855409973371
Reasons for exclusion were an ejection fraction (< 30%, SA- and AV-block or simultaneous application of epinephrine and metoprolol.	0.6804834044500951
There were no significant differences between the patients of drug and control group with respect to age, sex ejection fraction, previous medication, number and type of bypass grafts, cardiopulmonary bypass time, and perioperative ischemic events.	0.7598231661203156
However, a statistically significant difference was seen in the occurrence of supraventricular arrhythmias in both groups, 4 patients of the therapy group (4%) in contrast to 37 patients of the control (37%) developed supraventricular arrhythmias during the postoperative observation period (p<0.0001).	0.8890226821876485
Both groups differed in total time of hospital stay by 1.5 days (control group: 9.83 +/- 2.88 days; drug group: 8.42 +/- 2.81 days), which was statistically significant (p<0.05).	0.7140972359822793
All patients of the drug group could be discharged with a stable sinusrhythm, whereas 7 patients of the control group were discharged with persistent atrial fibrillation.	0.7584718858383732
The difference was statistically significant as well (p<0.01).	0.42918539295908664
Neither typical side effects of metoprolol, nor AV-blocks, bradycardia (f<60/min) or symptoms of low blood pressure could be observed.	0.5901617439920835
The conclusion of this trial is a recommendation for a preventive application of 50mg metoprolol/day after coronary artery bypass surgery, which can reduce the incidence of SVA as well as the hospital stay statistically significant.	0.6954680891704732
Especially by using the "Functional Muscular Diagnostics" described by Janda specific muscular imbalances can be found.	0.5158040069152621
The method is easy to apply and should be used during and before the championship season.	0.6914455704462634

Paclitaxel, a potent anti-tumor agent, shifts the cytoskeleton equilibrium towards assembly of altered and extraordinarily stable microtubules.	0.4247857676417833
These cellular modifications lead to reduced proliferation, migration, and signal transduction.	0.5731866832787217
It is highly lipophilic, which promotes a rapid cellular uptake, and has a long-lasting effect in the cell due to the structural alteration of the cytoskeleton.	0.9069586966061451
This makes paclitaxel a promising candidate for local drug delivery intended to address the proliferative and migratory processes involved in restenosis.	0.3914277190122542
In this article, results of our in vitro and in vivo studies with paclitaxel are presented.	0.6639453170928915
Cell culture experiments with monocultures of human arterial smooth muscle cells as well as cocultures with human endothelial cells showed that paclitaxel leads to an almost complete growth inhibition within a dose range of 1.0-10.0µmol/l, even after a short (20 min) single dose application.	0.6942361751127396
The comparison of an active, semi-active, and passive delivery system (porous balloon, microporous balloon, and double balloon) favored the double balloon for the following in vivo experiments.	0.623116249364011
Tubulin staining and electron microscopy enabled visualization of paclitaxel-induced vessel wall alterations.	0.3656266564527854
In the rabbit model, locally delivered paclitaxel resulted in reduced neointima formation and enlargement in vessel size; in the pig model, however, after stenting, this inhibition was not significant.	0.5770919814767026
Both reduced proliferation and enlargement in vessel size contribute to a preservation of vessel shape and are likely to be caused by a structural alteration of the cytoskeleton, which is also supported by vascular contraction force experiments.	0.6392384467257559

Between January 1995 and January 1997, we therefore obtained bladder catheter urine samples in 31 female allograft recipients when voided urine samples repeatedly showed pyuria (>=10 WC per microscope field (x40)) and significant bacteriuria (>=;105/ml) combined with vaginal contamination (plenty of squamous epithelial cells, mixed bacterial growth).	0.6132457694792108
Results: In 55 % (17/31), diagnosis of urinary tract infection was confirmed by single bladder catheterization; in 26 % (8/31), urinary tract infection could be excluded, and in 19 % (6/31), bladder colonization without pyuria was found.	0.8569644504767429
Thus, 45 % of the patients with abnormal voided urine samples did not need antimicrobials.	0.825365998255897
After single dose antibiotic therapy with 500 mg Ciprofloxacin, given immediately after catheterization, no infectious complications occurred.	0.542235228361814

Most people with the Metabolic Syndrome die from thrombotic complications superimposed to degenerative arterial vascular lesions, mostly myocardial infarction.	0.4439705420200996
Type-2-Diabetes is a risk factor per se for such complications, but often clusters with dyslipoproteinemia, hypertension and obesity.	0.6883933409717202
This is referred to as "Metabolic Syndrome" and often operates on a genetically programmed susceptibility which accelerates the pathogenesis of coronary artery disease in front of a much wider diabetes specific cardiopathy.	0.6230199036605105
From a pathophysiological point of view none of these associated risk factors explains the pathogenetic series of events leading to the precipitation of an occlusive thrombus at sites of complicated coronary plaques.	0.49226845594773794
In patients with the Metabolic Syndrome the coagulation system is switched towards a prethrombotic state, involving increased plasmatic coagulation, diminished fibrinolysis, decreased endothelial thromboresistance and predominantly platelet hyperreactivity ("diabetic thrombocytopathy").	0.5472826134108492
Some of these factors are associated with an increased coronary risk (e.g.	0.6270120816734738
fibrinogen, PAI-1, platelets), but are also directly linked to the pathogenesis of "atherothrombosis".	0.6561604863252084
Altered cardiac remodelling together with adhesion and coagulation mechanisms appears suitable to explain decreased functional performance of infarcted organs, decreased success of acute (reduced fibrinolytic response, no reflow phenomenon) and longterm intervention strategies for vessel patency (PTCA, CABG) in Diabetes.	0.5976307564355788
Glucose adjustment alone will not adequately neutralize these complex mechanisms, but in the situation of myocardial infarction eumetabolization with parenteral glucose-insulin-potassium infusion appears mandatory similar to non-diabetics.	0.581175953435205
On the longterm a multidimensional interventional repertoire is required particularly in patients with the Metabolic Syndrome including antihypertensive, antidyslipoproteinemic and antithrombotic drugs, customized according to the individual patients needs as assessed by early diagnostic measures ("early secondary prevention").	0.6009133223126157

The posterolateral fusion in situ is a safe procedure, but the deformation remains and in spondyloptosis plastic deformation of the fusion mass can lead to further dislocation.	0.6589523869151265
With the external fixator as an instrument for reduction and the internal fixator for stabilization the reduction of even serious spondyloptosis and the recovery of a normal spine alignement and posture is possible, with an acceptable neurological risk.	0.6972498583041089
Therefore a concept of treatment is suggested, which as a rule is aiming at the anatomical reduction of the dislocated vertrebra beside stabilization and nerveroot decompression.	0.6797228101280645
Depending on the extent of the slip, reduction and stabilization is to be performed in one, two or three stages.	0.9116727825105251
An anterior or posterior fusion is sufficient in grade I dislocation.	0.46307120363593074
