Objectives: Due to its low solubility and negligible metabolism, desflurane is assumed to be especially suitable for application by low-flow anaesthetic techniques.	0.6238694894889254
The aim of this clinical investigation was the development of a standardised dosing scheme for low-flow and minimal-flow desflurane anaesthesia.	0.7845340429856519
Methods: One hundred six ASA status I-II patients were assigned to six groups according to the duration of the initial high-flow phase, fresh gas flow, and fresh-gas desflurane concentration.	0.7107687076047748
The median age, height, body weight, and constitution of the groups was comparable.	0.6788096295135564
After an initial high-flow phase using 4.4 l/min, the fresh gas flow was reduced to 0.5 l/min (minimal-flow anaesthesia) or 1.0 l/min (low-flow anaesthesia).	0.8301743099101675
Inspired nitrous oxide concentrations were maintained at 60% to 70%.	0.5704058305364696
Using different standardised schemes of vaporizer settings, inspired desflurane concentrations were applied in the range from 3.4% to 8.7%, i.e., between 1 and 1.5 MAC.	0.8045065183330493
Inspired and expired desflurane concentrations were measured continuously by the side-stream technique and recorded on-line.	0.5161406280122707
Venous blood samples were taken immediately prior to induction and 45 min after flow reduction for measurement of carboxyhaemoglobin (COHb) concentration).	0.44213952494568903
Results: In the 10- to 15-min initial phase during which a high fresh gas flow of 4.4 l/min was used, the inspired desflurane concentration reached values in the range of 90%-95% of the fresh gas concentration.	0.8273811896092145
In low-flow anaesthesia this concentration could be maintained without any alteration of the vaporizer setting, whereas in minimal-flow anaesthesia with flow reduction the fresh gas concentration had to be increased by 1% to 2%: The quotient calculated by division of the inspired desflurane concentration by its fresh gas concentration (Q=CI/CF) ranges between 0.65 and 0.75 in minimal-flow and between 0.80 and 0.85 in low-flow anaesthesia.	0.7657345794139689
If use was made of the wide output range of the desflurane vaporizer, the inspired concentration could be increased rapidly by about 5% in 8 min, although the flow was kept constant at 0.5 l/min.	0.7131325435532588
Compared with its value prior to induction (2.13 +/- 1.05%), the COHb concentration decreased statistically significantly by about 0.7% during the 1st hour of minimal-flow anaesthesia (1.42 +/- 1.01%).	0.7428274690849556
In no case was a COHb concentration observed that exceeded threatening or even toxic values, although the soda lime was changed routinely only once a week.	0.5024519045816016
Conclusions: The pharmacokinetic properties of desflurane, resulting in especially low individual uptake, and the wide output range of the vaporizer facilitate the use of low-flow anaesthetic techniques in routine clinical practice.	0.6814053511788949
Even in minimal-flow anaesthesia, the duration of the initial high-flow phase can be shortened to min.	0.6352090545397068
If the flow is reduced to 1 l/min, the inspired desflurane concentration achieved in the initial high-flow phase can be maintained without any alteration of the vaporizer setting.	0.6128810227607837
In minimal-flow anaesthesia, however, with flow reduction to 0.5 l/min, the fresh gas concentration has to be increased to a value 1%-2% higher than the inspired nominal value.	0.8053945945809138
Due to the wide dialling range of the desflurane vaporizer, the amount of vapour delivered into the breathing system can be increased to about 110 ml/min even at a flow of 0.5 l/min.	0.6543186953486433
The large amount of agent that can be delivered into the system even under low-flow conditions, together with the very low individual uptake, results in a time-constant that is sufficiently short for the clinically required rapid increase in inspired desflurane concentrations.	0.625571107133547
The short time-constant of low-flow desflurane anaesthesia improves the control of the anaesthetic concentration.	0.7296540344122233
If all measures are taken to safely avoid inadvertent drying out of the soda lime, there is no evidence that low-flow anaesthesia with desflurane is liable to increase the risk of accidental ca	0.6880281113309359

Her husband and a general practitioner living in the neighborhood initially performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation.	0.46738877316175603
A prehospital emergency physician found ventricular fibrillation when he arrived after 20 minutes.	0.30753775936190836
It was impossible to achieve stable rhythm by 42 attemps of defibrillation.	0.32836081804972655
Therefore, the patient was carried to our clinic under ongoing cardiopulmonary resuscitation.	0.7932844213022114
A cardiologist was informed with radio signal.	0.1591315010630781

After 10 hours of support pCPS was explaned.	0.3187507168097273
IABP was needed for three days.	0.27727712254878967
The patient was discharged from hospital without any relevant neurological deficits after nine weeks.	0.5718293220562846
By using pCPS it is possible to stabilize the patient's hemodynamic situation and to perform diagnostic and therapeutic procedures if other means of resuscitation do not suffice.	0.6460928869758491

Viral hepatitis is also very important in health care workers.	0.5084551220213291
Today viral hepatitis can be differentiated from type A to type E (G) based on immunological and molecular assays.	0.5396668388265969
While enterally transmitted hepatitis type A and type E only induce acute and rare fulminant disease, hepatitis type B, C and D often induce chronic progressive disease including liver cirrhosis with typical complications due to the portal hypertension and with a high rate of association with the development of primary liver cancer (HCC).	0.5913573128472007
This review focusses on viral hepatitis-related surgical problems, including liver transplantation.	0.5166338019105363
Hypertensive diseases in pregnancy (HDP) are one of the most frequent causes of maternal death and perinatal mortality.	0.6503687462920843
However, chronic hypertension without complications has a more favorable prognosis than preeclampsia.	0.5830844940529921
Apart from a familial predisposition, mutations of various genes may also be responsible; among these, APC resistance is of particular clinical significance.	0.5866918137992023
The insufficient endovascular invasion of trophoblast in the spiral aterioles is still considered to represent the pathogenetic basis of preeclampsia.	0.3865337979248902
Increased lipid oxidation, deported membrane components of syncytiotrophoblasts, and increased invasion of fetal cells in the maternal circulation triggering immunological reactions are discussed as the causes.	0.6044982710488728
The result is an endothelial imbalance between vasoconstrictory-aggregating and vasodilatatory-antiaggregating compounds.	0.3910277908472117
The results of studies on the relevance of NO synthase are controversial.	0.6086346418629561
Currently, neither reliable methods for the early detection nor certain preventative measures to avoid the disease are available.	0.6747648487962156

When the pregnancy is continued defined guidelines for its termination for maternal or fetal indications must be taken into consideration.	0.3477980247779823

Acanthosis nigricans is a hyperkeratotic mucocutaneous eruption of heterogenous etiology which is characterized by hyperpigmentation, velvety cutaneous thickening, intensified skin markings and development of verrucous excrescences typically involving the intertriginous areas.	0.38307744338548616
Malignant acanthosis nigricans is most often associated with an abdominal adenocarcinoma frequently unresectable at the time of diagnosis.	0.6367164062822412
We report on the rare association of acanthosis nigricans with a transitional cell carcinoma of the urinary bladder.	0.5868677275828316

The goal of this evaluation study is to analyze the effects of a new gerontopsychiatric institution, the gerontopsychiatric center (GC: a combination of a home-based outpatient service, a day-hospital and a consulting office for elderly with mental disorders) on the reorganization process of the treatment system from intramural toward extramural structures, as experts of the government of the FRG have been demanding for a long time.	0.7572952122509851
Based on data of cross-sectional and longitudinal studies two regional catchment areas - the city of Bielefeld (without GC, control region) and the district of Gütersloh (with GC) - are compared and analyzed, whether changes within the gerontopsychiatric system (subsystem A), the system of general medical treatment (subsystem B), or within the elderly care system (subsystem C) occurred.	0.7950439960090222
Concerning subsystem A the results are that the GC has a strong impact on the intended shift from intra- to extramural structures, without selecting patients by diagnosis nor by severity degrees of their mental disorders in extramural treatment facilities.	0.5931830622711547
The home-based outpatient treatment is especially successful for elderly with a functional psychic disorder.	0.5271146247464328
These patients had the highest scores in improvement of psychiatric symptoms as well as in reduction of their self-care deficits within one year Effects of the GC on subsystem B were evident soon after its establishment, for example, by the increasing cooperation between the gerontopsychiatric health services and general hospitals in the region with GC, in which (hospitals) two fifths of all clinical gerontopsychiatric patients with a mental disorder as the main diagnosis (ICD-9) are treated.	0.8064755792776167

One approach to verify these interactions can be seen in stress research.	0.45116432643473936
While the phenomenon of stress-induced changes in immunological processes is widely accepted, more recent studies focus on possible moderators and mechanisms of these responses.	0.590514650494725
Within this research strategy it became evident that catecholamine increases upon stress are of a major importance for the frequently observed mild leukocytosis.	0.49793287116846124
The present study was conducted to investigate whether the often observed stress-induced increases in the number of peripheral lymphocyte subsets depends on the amount of epinephrine or norepinephrine release.	0.6294453905258005
Moreover, the question was addressed whether high or low catecholamine release is related to subjective ratings on discomfort.	0.5210595851883838
Using a "public speaking paradigm" we were able to replicate previous findings of high increases in the absolute number of CD8+ and CD56+ cells in peripheral blood.	0.46006744241189146
Moreover, when dividing subjects into high and low catecholamine responders, the amount of change was significantly larger in catecholamine responders irrespective of whether norepinephrine or epinephrine was used for grouping the subjects.	0.5224331913646287
However, high and low catecholamine responders did not differ with respect to subjective ratings on discomfort.	0.5683769425762437
The data are discussed with respect to underlying mechanisms in catecholamine-induced lymphocyte migration and possible reasons for the mismatch between objective and subjective indicators of stressor efficacy.	0.4436599701270639

A 34-year-old male (190 cm/100 kg) was scheduled for surgery of the nasal septum.	0.7464541791867784
He had had uneventful anaesthesia for appendicectomy 14 years earlier: following 600 mg thiopentone, 180 mg suxamethonium and up to 2 vol.% halothane for 20 min had been used and no symptoms of malignant hyperthermia (MH) were recorded.	0.5453913643039022
Following oral premedication with 2 mg flunitrazepam at 7.00 a.m. anaesthesia was induced with a priming dose of atracurium at 8.45 a.m. followed by 0.2 mg fentanyl, 500 mg thiopentone, and 100 mg suxamethonium.	0.6260502135198447
Endotracheal intubation was accomplished easily [9], and the patient was ventilated manually in a semi-closed circle system until spontaneous ventilation resumed.	0.631743392971958
Enflurane (1.5% for 5 min, 1.0% for 10 min, and 0.8% until the diagnosis of MH was suspected) was given in 33% O2/66% N2O.	0.9145660506674524
Seventy minutes after induction it was noted that the spontaneous respiratory rate and minute volume had risen continuously from 10/min and 6 l/min, respectively, to 20/min and 12 l/min.	0.6061721477149566
Attempts at deepening anaesthesia with repeated doses of fentanyl up to a total dose of 0.95 mg failed to reduce the hyperventilation.	0.5673283055255959
In spite of a high fresh gas flow of 6 l/min and assisted manual ventilation, the FIO2 started to fall from 0.34 to 0.28 at 10:20 a.m.	0.6489955224294242
The O2/N2O ratio was changed to 1 : 1, but the FIO2 remained at 0.3.	0.8081113178608703
MH was suspected, enflurane was discontinued, and an arterial blood gas analysis was done (Table 2).	0.7780540716714803
When marked acidosis and hypercarbia were found, dantrolene 2.5 mg/kg was given, the operation was terminated, and the patient's trachea was extubated and he was monitored closely in the intensive care unit for 24 h. Vital signs were stable (Table 3) and no further complications were observed.	0.7784230118714539
The patient did not mention pain or uneasiness postoperatively.	0.31420727610791055
About 6 months later, a muscle biopsy was done according to the European MH Protocol [5] and the patient was found to be MHEh.	0.7722606296690551
In this case five main reasons for the hypercarbia and mixed acidosis must be considered (Table 1).	0.6762557518870368
Firstly, hypoventilation does not seem to be reasonable as the patient was ventilated with 8 to 12 l/min, which is within the range of 80 - 120 mg/kg - min.	0.8369608395320466
Secondly, we can exclude shock and hypoperfusion because the patient had a normal blood pressure and heart rate (within 65 - 90 beats/min), his fingertips and skin were well perfused, his body temperature was 37  °C, and there was no sign of muscle rigidity.	0.6765594261389146
Thirdly, a defect of the CO2 adsorber as well as CO2 admixture to the N2O and O2 ventilation gases can cause hypercarbia.	0.48772261803027916
We use two absorbers in sequence of which one is changed every day, and found neither a change in colour of the indicator nor an abnormally raised temperature of the absorbers [11].	0.5131896527374661
A postoperative check of the ventilator showed no defect in the O2/N2O supply and a correctly functioning anaesthesia apparatus.	0.4223232640321817
A malfunction of both CO2 absorbers resulting in intraoperative hypercarbia could not explain a postoperative mixed acidosis lasting for more than 6 h. Anaesthesias performed at the same time using soda lime from the same canisters were totally uneventful.	0.5901937000431613
It is concluded that the hypercarbia and mixed acidosis were caused by hypermetabolism.	0.445789492791158
A thorough postoperative examination by an internist did not reveal any thyroid, pulmonary, endocrine, or circulatory reason for our intra- and postoperative findings.	0.6989555424418257
Iatrogenic factors like superficial anaesthesia or systemic side effects of adrenaline admixture to local anaesthetics can cause hypermetabolism without striking clinical signs, but they do not cause mixed acidosis lasting longer than 6 h (Table 2).	0.5568015155614879
The most suitable explanation in this case is an abortive form of MH.	0.6891566741181256

Definition of the problem: Is it the brain that makes a human being a person?	0.445099957007588
This anthropological question has been raised because of the findings of modern human brain research, and there are severe ethical consequences anew: If the appropriate anthropological answer is yes, then all invasive research would be problematic, because one would touch the basis of human essence.	0.6522804973210399
The problem is that the two major philosophical paradigms that offer an answer to the anthropological question, dualism and monism, have opposing concepts.	0.5492464104445925
Arguments: This paper argues that the error of these two paradigms is that they understand the human body and the human mind as 'res' - as things.	0.7711950347525887
The explanation of the human being as an interactive unit of body and mind is impossible in both paradigms.	0.5662984730001434
A third anthropological view that tries to make that understandable is the anthropology of the Hebrew Bible.	0.3098523494463406
It does assume the category 'thing' while speaking about humans, it presumes the category 'aspect'.	0.47326050486231047
There is no Hebrew word for 'mind' in contrast to 'body' or vice versa.	0.42880651890805244
The biblical language only knows terms for the unity of human beings seen under a certain aspect.	0.36815577766122565
Conclusion: Here, the body and thus the brain are important and necessary condition for human essence, but this is not a sufficient explanation for the human personality.	0.7949060394643059
Invasive research on the human brain is here neither generally forbidden nor tolerated - one has to demonstrate in every single case whether the planned operation touches regions that are crucial for the personality of the human subject.	0.6080334382643071

Therefore, we reviewed the records of 41 children who underwent a pyeloplasty in our department.	0.728050710269382

The mechanical response in terms of deformation was found to depend mainly on gross geometrical properties and to a minor extent on the various other variables.	0.5476768001807119
At all positions the maximum principal strain was tensile, the minimum principal strain was compressive, and the absolute strain values were correlated with the magnitude of the applied force.	0.6491695535683956
CT-based FEM analysis revealed the utility of mathematical models to approximate simulated data our experimental results.	0.34277789338852993
Hence, FEM analysis is a non-invasive tool in the prediction of biomechanical behaviour of individual mandibles and therefore may help in trauma reconstruction and treatment planning.	0.6156273604757003

The efficacy of radiotherapy is dose dependent.	0.368728407432704
Based on an analysis of published data a dose of more than 50 Gy is recommended, resulting in a high morbidity rate with external beam radiotherapy alone.	0.7445760613607663
The use of intraoperative radiotherapy allows locally restricted dose escalation without increased perioperative morbidity.	0.3917908330291157
In adjuvant and in primary treatment, local tumor contol was improved (70-90 %).	0.6205610771924218
With palliative intent, pain relief was obtained rapidly in over 60 % of patients and led to improved patient performance.	0.8036716337625254

Ionizing radiation is only one of these factors.	0.6879589549322851

Registration of fetal heart beats was generally successful from the 20/21th week of gestation onwards.	0.48986086372794957
In a few cases, fetal heart beats could be registered as early as in the 16th week.	0.7121661004765895
Cardiac time intervals and amplitudes of fMCG increased concordantly with fetal growth.	0.2776761153681547

Acute gastrointestinal bleeding is a life threatening disease with a mortality rate of 10%.	0.7735350135380724
Upper gastrointestinal bleeding occurs more frequent (85%) and more severe compared to lower gastrointestinal bleeding.	0.6668835846993356
The medical history may be helpful in the diagnosis of the bleeding source.	0.8555914632772306

Joints are innervated by nociceptive nerve fibres (nociceptors), which are only activated by tissue-damaging stimuli.	0.5649986350882998
This activation causes pain in conscious humans.	0.22361104250634734
The sensory terminals of many nociceptors in the tissue are sensitized by inflammatory processes.	0.38508929134086445
Under these conditions, normally innocuous and non-painful stimuli are sufficient to activate nociceptors and to elicit pain.	0.39610463008635044
The effect of inflammatory mediators such as bradykinin and prostaglandins is important for the process of sensitization.	0.5255279078598881
In addition to their sensory function, many nociceptors have an efferent function.	0.6275442043077942
They evoke a neurogenic inflammation by the release of neuropeptides such as substance P and calcitonin gene-related peptide into the tissue.	0.3683895563205404
The efferent function of nociceptors contributes to the generation of inflammatory lesions of the tissue.	0.5028896806810075

Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are established drugs for the treatment of patients with heart failure and hypertension.	0.5140897634303391
There is mounting evidence to suggest that ACE inhibitors may be used for different indications as well.	0.5415258407485942
The rational for the use of ACE inhibitors is to block the vasoconstrictive effects mediated by angiotensin II.	0.428723384639426
The hemodynamic profile of ACE inhibitors is modified by additional effects such as interference with the degredation of bradykinin and accumulation of prostaglandin and nitric oxide (NO).	0.39655155163667544
Thus ACE inhibitors may be successful in preventing the negative effects of vasoconstriction on regional circulation.	0.45284895978404466
Since vasoconstriction, particularly of the mesenteric vasculature appears to be largely mediated by the renin-angiotensin-axis, ACE inhibitors are assumed to be effective in treating or avoiding gut mucosal hypoperfusion.	0.5291755537164008

Intravenous preparations of ACE inhibitors may broaden our therapeutic armamentarium for these patients.	0.4628746574678702
However, several questions about the exact mechanisms of ACE inhibitors, such as the ideal substance and the optimal dose, are still open.	0.7824895823290329
Moreover, further work needs to be done to definitely determine whether ACE inhibitors may be helpful to prevent or treat (micro-) circulatory catastrophe in these patients.	0.6389406869951444
The pharmacologic properties of ACE inhibitors provide an exciting stepping stone for future research in this field.	0.48420515719163976

It was the goal of this prospective study to compare 6 common risk scores with regard to the predictive value for mortality in individual patients.	0.7047299624242456
Between September 1998 and February 1999 all adult patients undergoing heart surgery were prospectively scored according to the following scores: initial Parsonnet, Cleveland Clinic, French, Euro, Pons, and the Ontario Province Risk score.	0.5393405325370565
Early lethality was assessed within 30 days postoperatively.	0.2823340058534276
Follow-up was completed in 504 patients.	0.6453625228500419
With the exception of the Ontario Province Risk score, lethality in the high risk group was overestimated by all scores, whereas lethality in low to moderate risk groups was underestimated by several scores.	0.6190168980186584
Mean scores of surviving and deceased patients showed a broad overlap with high standard deviations.	0.44784181048506483
Preoperative risk scores are effective tools for stratification of patient populations and the analysis of surgical outcome.	0.43767926875811447
With the aid of risk scores, operative risk can be sufficiently predicted for patient populations or subpopulations.	0.6051629023000636
The Euro score best predicted the outcome of our patients.	0.5280091247071027
However, when the indication for surgery is to be determined in an individual patient, risk scores should be only considered as an orientation in the decision process.	0.8969266754050368
Background and objective: A complicated course of erysipelas is not uncommon.	0.5227682337112901
Bullous, haemorrhagic, necrotic and purulent lesions may be encountered.	0.3012357806421327
Today no reliable data exist as to which constitutional factors renders a patient at risk for developing complicated erysipelas though several risk factors, particularly diabetes mellitus, are often suggested.	0.561766513263721
Based on the analysis of patients with erysipelas at the Department of Dermatology in Graz, factors determining the risk for complicated erysipelas should be identified.	0.7155893784501638
Patients/Methods: In a retrospective case-control study clinical data sheets of 766 in- patients treated at the department were evaluated with respect to the course of the erysipelas and with respect to potential risk factors.	0.7805160850268532
Results: General risk factors for local complications were location at the lower extremities, pre-existing hepatic or renal disease, hyperuricaemia, and diabetes mellitus.	0.6844418921368148
Hepatic and renal disease and - to a lesser extent - diabetes particularly predisposed for bullous and haemorrhagic lesions, while vascular occlusive disease enhanced the risk for ne- crotic lesions.	0.661218434097522
Conclusions: Location and hepatic and renal disease are the most important risk factors, while diabetes is probably of less significance than previously suggested.	0.7012799928825595
Patients with end-stage liver disease frequently develop combined coagulopathies due to increased procoagulant and fibrinolytic turnover as well as thrombocytopenia.	0.45205505522594125
The onset of clinical symptoms of a haemorrhagic diathesis requires balanced substitution of coagulation factors, since fresh frozen plasma alone does not always maintain a sufficient haemostatic potential in these patients.	0.572358875247265
This substitution commonly follows standard rules based on the assumption that 0.5 - 1 IU of a coagulation factor or inhibitor concentrate given per kg body weight will increase its endogenous activity by 1%.	0.6008943645213838
We set out to investigate the validity of this standard regime in patients with end-stage liver disease scheduled for orthotopic liver transplantation.	0.5423021092807311
Fifty-one adult patients were prospectively studied.	0.477476940306249
In 37 patients with antithrombin III (AT III) activity <70%, an AT III preparation (Kybernin, Behring, Marburg, Germany) was given preoperatively (mean dose 2616 +/- 207 IU) following standard calculations in order to increase endogenous activity to 80%.	0.6615928132792057
Twenty-seven of the patients had chronic hepatic failure (CHF group) with histologically proven cirrhosis and 10 had acute hepatic failure (AHF group).	0.7197229389277627
Blood samples were drawn prior to a 15-min infusion of AT III concentrate and 30 min thereafter.	0.6391174983694665
In 14 patients with prothrombin time (PT) <40%, AT III levels had been corrected earlier during the clinical course to achieve activities >70%.	0.7335844568577514
Prothrombin complex (PPSB, Beriplex, Behring, Marburg, Germany) was substituted (mean dose 2304 +/- 289 IU) to increase procoagulant activity to PT >60%.	0.5819526620349971
Blood samples were drawn in the same fashion as in the AT III group.	0.7189469385146441
The amounts of AT III and PPSB concentrates ( AT III, [IU/kg];  PPSB [IU/kg]) required to increase AT III activity and PT, respectively, by 1% were calculated.	0.8656679036751523
Standard calculations for AT III substitution indicated AT III recovery in all 37 patients who received AT III concentrate.	0.5270684153327692
However, there was a statistically significant difference between patients with CLF and ALF.	0.8521588841898766
In patients with CLF,  AT III was found to be 0.8 IU/kg ( +/- 0.1 SEM) and in those with ALF it was 1.5 IU/kg ( +/- 0.1 SEM) (P<0.05,  t-test).	0.8718394623310837
In patients treated with PPSB concentrate,  PPSB was 1.6 U/kg ( +/- 0.2 SEM) for both CLF and ALF groups.	0.8074860729739846
In patients with end stage liver disease standard rules for substitution with AT III-concentrate are adequate only for patients with CLF.	0.6139192436852844
In patients with ALF higher AT III doses are required to achieve the expected effect on endogenous AT III activity.	0.5761278468974469
Procoagulant activity, as reflected by PT, can be increased by 1% when 1.6 IU/kg PPSB concentrate is given.	0.7158999982590151
However, this study shows the effects of coagulation concentrates only 30 min after administration.	0.7827583008650191
An increased volume of distribution and increased turnover may explain the poor recovery of AT III activity in the ALF group, indicating that the dose of coagulation concentrate should be estimated against the background of the patient's clinical symptoms and diagnosis.	0.723723485116014

Rapid exhaustion and reduced exercise tolerance leads to difficulties in maintaining a normal daily life for many patients.	0.3240114659072785
Regular resting and short breaks can help to compensate this to a  certain degree.	0.4426753612121476

The common clinical feature is a erythematous plaque surrounded by a hyperkeratotic border.	0.4129697709821665

The pathogenesis, taking in account especially the clonal hypothesis and premalignant nature of porokeratosis, is discussed.	0.5039602826271875
With the introduction of the non-benzodiazepine hypnotics zopiclone and zolpidem it was expected to have hypnotics without side effects and risks characteristically seen with benzodiazepines.	0.5254578965410349
We report two cases with high-dose usage and dependency of non-benzodiazepine hypnotics.	0.5684975831062613
Both patients were prescribed the drugs to treat sleep disturbances occuring during a depressive episode.	0.45788899812839445
While one patient had a polysubstance abuse there was no evidence for an abuse history in the other patient.	0.681002107028105
To reduce withdrawal symptoms long-acting benzodiazepines were given to both patients.	0.41707460155746834
Thus, it seems that not only patients with a history of substance abuse but also patients with a psychiatric disorder are at risk for abuse of non-benzodiazepine hypnotics.	0.7746349349101813

Fractures of the proximal radius in children may lead to deformities of the radial head and functional disturbance of pro- and supination.	0.7616730178054479
However, traumatization is not only caused by the injury itself, but may also occur secondary to surgical reduction, manipulation of fracture fragments and excessive physiotherapy.	0.6882048691663142
In a prospective long-term follow-study (2-20 years after trauma) of 38 children with displaced proximal radius fractures we found functional disturbances in 11 % of children only.	0.8515597418981008
These were not caused by radial head deformities, which were present on 83 % of follow-up radiographs.	0.8060597878610615
Functional impairment was mainly seen after open reduction or secondary growth disturbances.	0.43016057154911036
On follow-up radiographs all conservatively treated fracture angulations up to 60  ° had corrected themselves spontaneously.	0.5088986697134993
In view of the high complication rates after open reduction and the poor functional results, as well as the inconvenience for the pediatric patient and the economic aspects, we recommend a primary conservative treatment concept of proximal radius fractures in children.	0.7926041035071129
Patients who have undergone cardiac surgery with use of extracorporeal circulation frequently reveal marked hypovolaemia in spite of a highly positive fluid balance.	0.5649262720053982
This is thought to be due to transient microvascular damage and extravascular fluid shift.	0.37750145973347815
Further volume replacement to achieve haemodynamic stability in the postoperative period may cause fluid overload and congestive heart failure.	0.4889905158988162
The present study was designed to investigate whether this fluid overload could be avoided by using a hypertonic-hyperoncotic solution (group I: HHL, 10% hydroxyethylstarch 200/0.5 in 7.2% saline) instead of two different standard colloid solutions (group II: HA, 5% albumin; group III: HES, 6% hydroxyethylstarch in 0.9% saline).	0.7649571443658338
Purpose: The temporomandibular joint is a place of motion where release of proinflammatory cytokines like interleukin-1 (IL-1) induces cartilage destruction via production of nitric oxide (NO).	0.5150468622692776
The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effects of continuous passive motion in the form of cyclic stretch on the synthesis of inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS).	0.471690489706968
Methods: Articular chondrocytes were harvested from rabbit cartilage slices and cultured in F12 medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum.	0.42042160120093214
Subsequently, cells (105/ml per well) were transferred to Flexercell plates, grown to 90% confluency, and subjected to one of the following regimens: (1) no mechanical strain (10 Hz, 20% elongation rate); (2) rhIL-1 (1 ng/ml); (3) mechanical strain; (4) mechanical strain and rhIL-1.	0.7279637583558777
The cells were exposed to cyclic stretch for 24 h. Thereafter, cells were trypsinized and centrifuged on microscope slides in a cytospin centrifuge.	0.4011220405805335
The presence of iNOS was determined by indirect immunoperoxidase staining using polyclonal rabbit anti-iNOS as primary antibodies, and goat anti-rabbit IgG conjugated with horseradish peroxidase (HRP) as secondary antibodies.	0.5034254485495746
Diaminobenzidine was used as substrate for HRP.	0.3613482877030649
Total NO production was spectrophotometrically measured in the supernatants of cultures using Greiss reaction.	0.2910012610198119
All experiments were done in triplicates and the statistical significance was analyzed by Student's t-test.	0.49101616395346315
Results: Cells with treatment 1 and 3 did not exhibit presence of iNOS.	0.5330654387223267
IL-1-treated cells in group 2 exhibited intense peroxidase staining.	0.7705877711995265
Cells in group 4 exposed to IL-1 and mechanical stress showed staining with considerably less intensity.	0.5306875326436867
Control cells treated with normal rabbit IgG as a primary antibody did not exhibit peroxidase staining.	0.5086530648412894
The data were further confirmed by measurement of statistically significant differences of NO levels in supernatants assessed in the four different treatment groups.	0.581846991109728
Conclusion: Our findings suggest that continuous passive motion exerts anti-inflammatory effects on chondrocytes, downregulating the quantity of iNOS -positive cells.	0.5183912998563754
Since NO acts as an intracellular, transcellular, and cytotoxic molecule, it has a basic importance for proper post-traumatic and postoperative TMJ function as well as the course and therapy of inflammatory TMJ diseases.	0.7332187340761329
Recently, we presented an implantable piezoelectrical hearing aid transducer.	0.5463956856276423
Its characteristics make it suitable for implantation in patients with sensorineural hearing loss.	0.4040497759569174
The transducer transmits micromechanical vibrations instead of sound into the hearing organ.	0.32297709963934457
Efficiency of the transducer implant was investigated in ten cat ears.	0.6218347562068737
After determining preoperative (acoustical) BERA threshold, the middle ear was opened and the piezoelectrical transducer coupled to various ossicles or the perilymph.	0.5128755035410597
BERA responses were recorded following stimulation of umbo, long incus process, stapes head, stapes foot plate, and vestibulum.	0.5613988166596473
By comparing the acoustical and mechanical threshold, a correlation was found between the stimulus level of acoustical and mechanical stimulation.	0.612412892995083
An electrical transducer voltage of 1 Vrms* was equivalent to sound-pressure levels between 100 and 128 dB SPL at the tympanic membrane.	0.41008483356760733
To judge hearing impression, stimulus-dependent latencies of the early acoustically and mechanically evoked potentials (waves P1 to P5) and their thresholds were analyzed.	0.5255115507094021
After coupling the piezoelectrical transducer to the long incus process, latencies corresponded well to stimulation.	0.41386045633911794
They were almost completely similar when the equivalent sound-pressure level of 100 dB SPL was achieved by the transducer voltage level.	0.5091546644659123
Pyoderma gangrenosum was first described in 1930 by Brunsting, Goeckermann and O'Leary.	0.33012390170351624
Nevertheless we found some illustrations in an atlas on dermatology, published by Marie-Nicolas Devergie in the first half of the 19th century, which appear to be pyoderma gangrenosum.	0.5307986310475645
In addition to discussions of typical syphilitic affections of the skin, Devergie's "Clinique de la Maladie Syphilitique" includes illustrations of gangrenous ulcers, which appeared unexpectedly after local and systemic therapy with mercury.	0.5197373836238034
Devergie interpreted those enlarging ulcers as a side effect of mercury therapy.	0.33802722110296746
Thus we were able to find evidence of pyoderma gangrenosum more than 100 years before first description in 1930.	0.4092114694979891
The etiology of this clinical picture is still unsettled.	0.708129713143463
The favorite postulate has been a bacterial genesis which was the subject of numerous publications until the 1960s.	0.5169769474097666
Multiple-system atrophy (MSA) is characterized by progressive autonomic failure with cerebellar, pyramidal and extrapyramidal signs.	0.459978385359451
In MSA patients laryngoscopy often reveals unilateral or bilateral abductor vocal fold palsies.	0.3053555250243923
However, assessment of sites of obstruction and their severity is needed.	0.4394888551362929

Endoscopy while awake demonstrated an incomplete abductor vocal fold palsy.	0.28147833398384886
Polysomnography confirmed heavy snoring with arousals (11.1/h) and an RDI of 1.4/h.	0.857785335704599
Sleep efficiency was low (51.9%) due to long intermittent awake periods.	0.4808681691978188
Sleep videoendoscopy of the upper airway proved the entire pharynx to be open during REM and non-REM sleep.	0.5181116377061872
During inspiration fluttering movements of the vocal cords caused the snoring.	0.39920443704631325
This was regularly terminated by arousals.	0.24395741022894765
The further treatment is discussed.	0.4047611258668713
In general, glottic snoring without daytime stridor is rare and has only been described in MSA patients.	0.5413179720533562
However, certain of these patients will also be pharyngeal snorers.	0.7185552328747774
The source of the sound and site of obstruction can only be diagnosed by sleep videoendoscopy.	0.6155046694564278

The second part of this review decribes the following techniques: laterofracture, submucous turbinectomy, concho-antropexy, partial turbinectomy, anterior turbinectomy, inferior turbinoplasty, total turbinectomy, and vidian neurectomy.	0.607917215367414

Acute oxalosis is an important disorder causing serious abnormalities.	0.4949189616469153
Acute oxalosis may come about by ethylene glycol poisoning; in recent years iatrogenic cases of acute oxalosis have also been described following iv treatments of naftidrofuryl, a vasodilator.	0.6100849818472855
Furthermore, chronic asymptomatic intestinal oxalosis may turn symptomatic by a superimposed major load of oxalate.	0.43865116633774276
Acute oxalosis results in acute renal failure; in addition oxalate-induced angiopathy may be associated with necrosis of affected tissue.	0.5873301269457415
The diagnosis of acute oxalosis requires a demonstration of oxalate crystals in the urine and in other affected tissues.	0.6210246352826515
In terms of therapy, hemodialysis should be used promptly in cases of ethylene glycol poisoning and a worsening of the renal function.	0.5520132231057463
In cases of a secondary chronic intestinal oxalosis prophylactic measures such as maintaining an elevated urinary flow rate and prescribing oral calcium supplements will be helpful.	0.48588326101572316
Generalized granuloma annulare is a rare variant of granuloma annulare affecting the trunk and extremities with a multitude of lesions.	0.5592003781383258
In contrast to localized granuloma annulare, generalized granuloma annulare occurs in older patients, shows a stronger association with diabetes, and is characteristically chronic.	0.6967679556173053
Like our 55-year-old patient, most patients present with papules and annular plaques; less often, macular or non-annular lesions may be encountered.	0.5575679552401622
Histology often fails to show necrobiotic or necrotic connective tissue changes demarcated by a palisading granuloma.	0.30683968493657676
Instead, there are diffuse dermal, band-like or nodular aggregations of histiocytes intermingled with some multinucleated giant cells and a predominantly lymphocytic infiltrate in the periphery.	0.45951765555174184
Because of its special characteristics, it has been suggested that generalized granuloma annulare might constitute a separate disease entity and that it should be classed among the primary cutaneous histiocytoses as a diffuse dermal histiocytosis.	0.6651739248513792
Using immunohistochemistry to determine the macrophage phenotype of the lesional histiocytes, we have shown that generalized granuloma annulare is not a cutaneous histiocytosis.	0.744964967185208
Neither MS-1 high-molecular-weight protein, a new specific marker for cutaneous non-Langerhans cell histiocytoses, nor CD1a, the well-known marker for Langerhans cells and Langerhans cell histiocytoses, is expressed by the lesional histiocytes of our patient.	0.6195589965726063
In contrast, the antigen expression pattern was diagnostic for non-infectious granulomas and was highly similar to that in localized granuloma annulare.	0.5569873848031066
In contrast to the successful treatment of localized granuloma annulare reported with intralesional interferon -1, systemic treatment with interferon -2b (9x106 units three times a week) was ineffective.	0.7526176237753237
The aims of the study were: (1) to predict reversal time from intensive atracurium blockade; and (2) to determine the optimal time of neostigmine administration during recovery from atracurium blockade, i.e., the time at which the administration of neostigmine results in the shortest total recovery time (time from administration of last supplemental dose of atracurium to train-of-four [TOF] ratio 0.70), and at the same time results in the shortest time from administration of neostigmine to TOF ratio 0.70.	0.7504345105353243
The spontaneous and neostigmine-facilitated recovery in 52 healthy women anaesthetised with thiopentone, fentanyl, droperidol, and nitrous oxide was followed.	0.43919026417513773
Post-tetanic count (PTC) of TOF stimulation of the ulnar nerve and mechanomyography were used for monitoring neuromuscular transmission.	0.6261261103285345
The neuromuscular blockade was induced with atracurium 0.6 mg/kg and supplemental doses of 0.15 mg/kg were given when the first twitch response in the TOF (TH1) had recovered to 20%.	0.6576047593701924
Neostigmine 0.036 mg/kg body weight was given at different levels of neuromuscular blockade to 37 of the patients.	0.5784184806216555
Multiple regression analyses including pre-reversal time (time from administration of the last atracurium dose to neostigmine administration), PTC, weight, and age of the patients suggest that pre-reversal time is the best predictor of reversal time: reversal time=27.3 min-(0.89xpre-reversal time [min]; (SEE=6.0 min).	0.681816431620128
If pre-reversal time is unknown, PTC can be used: reversal time=24 min-(4.5xln PTC) at time of reversal); (SEE=6.8 min).	0.7366832385569702
Total recovery time was 47 min (SEM=2.0 min, n=15) in the patients allowed to recover spontaneously, and 29 min (SEM=1.2 min, n=29) in the patients reversed by neostigmine; the difference of 18 min (SE diff 2.0 min) was significant (P<0.0005).	0.7949083170694098
The level of blockade indicated by PTC (1 - 24) at the time of reversal had no influence on the total recovery time.	0.7744454203725364
The spontaneous recovery times from reappearance of TH1 and TH1=10% to TOF ratio 0.70 were 29.2 min (SEM=1.7 min) and 24.4 min (SEM=2.6 min), respectively.	0.62914947898365
The results suggest that pre-reversal time is the strongest predictor of reversal time when neostigmine is administered during intense atracurium blockade.	0.4367262451950174
To achieve the optimal time-saving effect, neostigmine must be given 18 min (the time saved by giving neostigmine) plus 7 to 11 min (needed for neostigmine to reach its peak effect), giving a total of 25 to 29 min before TOF ratio 0.70.	0.5912883747925406
As TH1 is between 1% and 10% 25 to 29 min before TOF ratio 0.70 is reached during spontaneous recovery, the optimal level of neuromuscular blockade for neostigmine administration in atracurium blockade is when TH1 is between 1% and 10%.	0.600383369313281
Reversal time can be predicted as 27.3 min-(0.89xpre-reversal time (min), and the optimal time of neostigmine administration in atracurium blockade appears to be when TH1 is 1% - 10%.	0.795914608544986

Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is generally associated with ulcerative colitis (UC).	0.5266931308471724
The disease typically progresses slowly, but ultimately, and leads to cirrhosis, liver failure or bile duct cancer.	0.6695515530327968
PSC patients with simultanous ulcerative colitis are also at higher risk for colorectal cancer.	0.37272026285112697
At the present time, there is no effective treatment for PSC, although preliminary data show encouraging results after treatment with ursodeoxycholic acid.	0.6632071336435712
However, there are no data concerning the delay or prevention of progress of the disease with this drug, because follow-up time is not yet long enough.	0.9503019245364106
Isolated bile duct strictures should be treated endoscopically.	0.478129768633772
The possible effect of proctocolectomy on the course of PSC is controversial.	0.3343827984276706
Liver transplantation is the therapy of choice for PSC in its final stage.	0.5975029718948439
The 5-year survival rate (89 %) is significantly better than after transplantation for other indications.	0.7692987641578446
Patients with ulcerative colitis have to be followed up by lifelong colonoscopy.	0.553255167416033

Innervation of the head and neck differs from other regions of the body in certain respects.	0.647200450531164
In particular, besides the external cuneate nucleus, thick-calibre neck muscle afferents project directly, to the vestibular nuclear complex.	0.5080483316598933
This projection is most prominent in segments C2 and 3 and is sparse or absent in more caudal segments.	0.42028661918630855
Thus, proprioceptive neck muscle afferents gain direct access to vestibulospinal, vestibulooculomotor and other secondary or even higher order vestibular neurons that receive labyrinthine input.	0.35542975650759656
Proprioceptive input via indirect spinovestibular pathways is also most prominent from C2 and 3 compared to more caudal levels.	0.3442866018070646

Macular amyloidosis (MA) and lichen amyloidosus (LA) are the two major variants of the primary cutaneous amyloidoses which present with severe and therapy resistent itching.	0.7271816999868891
Various therapeutic modalities such as antihistamines, intralesional injection or topical application of corticosteroids, etretinate, UVB irradiation and dermoabrasion have been employed with variable success.	0.41879506750816436
Recently, in a few case reports authors have observed encouraging beneficial clinical effects by using topical dimethyl sulphoxide (DMSO).	0.6170732595144279
In our study 10 patients with either MA or LA or biphasic amyloidosis were treated with a 50% solution of DMSO in water.	0.7038192790981499
9 of them showed marked clinical improvement at the end of 6-20 weeks of treatment.	0.5370698072354485
Degranulation and depletion of the mast cells by DMSO is the most probable explanation for the rapid improvement of itching beginning within the first week of therapy.	0.680662931399645
Remarkable flattening of the lichenoid papules which was obtained within 11 weeks of treatment is interpreted as a result of the improvement of itching and the related scratch effect.	0.6850093934617212
Histological examination after treatment revealed no disappearance of amyloid deposits in the papillary dermis.	0.5191157325785689
In the follow-up period relapses of itching and papules were observed.	0.5686847185762123
Therefore further studies are needed to find out the optimal procedure of therapy.	0.5018663942326848
As early as 1974, Brian advocated the prone position for ventilated patients [5].	0.4202849152857686
He suggested that this position might enhance ventilation of the dorsal parts of the lungs, thereby improving oxygenation.	0.628636599789868
These considerations have been confirmed by several experimental and clinical studies [1, 6, 13, 17].	0.6985590919175743
Better secretion removal, decreased intrapulmonary shunting, and an increased FRC are thought to be responsible for the observed improvement of oxygenation.	0.717661248772081
However, the prone position never became very popular in the clinical treatment of the adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).	0.6083757555364309
Routine performance of thoracic CT scans in ARDS patients demonstrated preferential distribution of pathological densities in the dependent lung areas.	0.39585081290670265
The prone position therefore could possibly benefit these patients, as shown by two recent studies [8, 11].	0.6201026362826483
The aim of our study was to evaluate the influence of repeatedly turning the patient to the prone position on gas exchange and thoracic CT findings in multiple-trauma patients.	0.601527824867712
Seven ventilated intensive care patients with severe ARDS (Murray Score >2.5 [9], Quotient >0.7 [4], mean airway pressure >18 cm H2O, thoracic CT scan showing dorsal atelectases) were included in the study.	0.8633642777927638
Patients were turned from the supine to the prone position at 12-h intervals using an air-cushion bed (Mediscus, Austria).	0.40016785149057943
Redistribution of dystelectatic or atelectatic dependent lung areas was verified by means of repeated thoracic CT scans (Figs.	0.39154757439780413
The patients were intermittently turned for 6.5  +/-  1.1 days.	0.9448009150446568
The course of gas exchange is shown in Figs.	0.513684540615435
Initially, improvement of the respiratory quotient could only be achieved during prone positioning, from the 2nd day in the supine position as well.	0.7466945154705182
Intrapulmonary shunting showed a similar trend (Figs.	0.29378763112604256
No significant changes in cardiovascular parameters could be observed.	0.4729415224504603
Control thoracic CT scans showed uniform reduction of atelectases in dependent lung areas (Figs.	0.43550598130799384
The inspiratory fraction of oxygen could be reduced significantly as of the 2nd day (Fig.	0.5749829570828939
Constant levels of positive end-expiratory pressure and tidal volume were associated with decreasing mean and plateau airway pressures (Fig.	0.431920320368171
Repeatedly turning the patient to the prone position produced long-lasting improvement of arterial oxygenation, which persists up to the end of the weaning process.	0.6709694975643545
This is in good accordance with other studies [1, 2, 6, 8, 11, 13, 17], however, this is the first study to report an observation period of more than 6 days of repeatedly turning the patient.	0.7533073194253566
These positive effects on gas exchange can be attributed to sudden improvement of the ventilation-perfusion ratio within the lung areas that become dependent after turning to the prone position.	0.4609641342822402
Due to reduced hydrostatic pressure [11] and relative hyperventilation [7, 16], previously collapsed alveoli are recruited in the lung areas that become non-dependent after turning to the prone position.	0.48571219871450455

Heparin-associated thrombocytopenia (HAT) type II was diagnosed.	0.45557574695244335
Because of contraindications against thrombolysis a cava-filter was implanted, heparin therapy was stopped, and anticoagulation with recombinant hirudin was started.	0.5071935691903589
Inspite of this, an arterial thrombosis of the A. femoralis superficialis developed and had to be treated surgically.	0.7004770725716499
From this time on, no further thromboembolic complications were noticed.	0.5533608303335691
Overlapping coumarin therapy was begun.	0.19814683545213488

A second course of hirudin resulted in complete restitution of the coumarin-necrosis without the need for re-operation.	0.41729197902512727
Subsequent coumarin-therapy, which was gradually increased over two weeks, was without further complications.	0.7088895338533546

A prospective process-analysis evaluating organizational, medical and medical-technical alterations and real-time-documentation during out-of-hospital resuscitations (n=71) was performed due to the definitions of the "Utstein-Style".	0.6123630282153142
The gaseous radical nitric oxide (NO) is catalyzed by conversion of L-arginine to L-citrulline by one cytokine inducible form (iNOS), which becomes active only within hours after the inducing event, and by two constitutively expressed forms, endothelial (eNOS) and neuronal (nNOS), which are regulated by the cytosolic concentration of free Ca2+.	0.6080811832921783
Brain nNOS is physiologically present in discrete populations of neurons, which are all excited by glutamate via the ionotropic N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor, which controls a Ca2+ channel.	0.5077170198077017
After its diffusion into the extraneuronal space, NO may activate in neurons, which as a rule do not stain for NOS, soluble guanylyl cyclase and formation of cGMP as an intracellular messenger.	0.5216455030228813
Beyond that, NO is important as a feedback regulator of glutamatergic excitation.	0.5043007956674634
NO as a nitrosylating agent enhances disulfide bonding of vicinal sulfhydryl (thiol) groups of the redox modulatory site of the NMDA receptor complex and thereby down-regulates its Ca2+ channel activity.	0.3526916872454176
Histochemically studies have revealed the presence of large number of NOS containing neurons in the magnocellular and parvocellular subdivisions of hypothalamic nuclei.	0.361279059693962
Numerous studies conform to the view that NO participates in the control of many different neurosecretory processes, especially of the corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) neurosecretory system.	0.566142734685682
The redox-modulatory site of the NMDA receptor appears, therefore, as a critical structure in the control of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenocortical (HPA) axis.	0.5336182120901477
Moreover, glucocorticoids augment neuronal excitotoxicity by increasing the expression of glutamate receptors and inhibition of glutamate reuptake.	0.38351604089710567
In attempting to explain the many conflicting results obtained in studies with NO, it may be worthwhile to consider that the actual redox-environment of distinct loci of the brain may determine the final function of NO, acting either as a transmitter or neuromodulator or, in the worst case, causing neurodestruction.	0.6390217029889627
It seems likely that any kind of stress by altering the ratio of reduced vs oxidized thiols within the central nervous system influences neuronal excitability, with NO working either as an amplifier or as a feedback regulator of neuronal excitation or inhibition, which may alter acutely or chronically, among others, the homeostasis of a given neurosecretory system.	0.5914158975357255

Discoid meniscus is one of the commonest anatomical variations of the meniscus.	0.4294221456980549
There is at the moment no consensus on the aetiology of discoid meniscus.	0.590702833123269
According to Watanabe three types can be differentiated: the complete form, the incomplete form and the hypermobile Wrisberg form.	0.6059528820487831
Discoid meniscus frequently remains asymptomatic and thus requires no treatment.	0.276153054455971

Fifty-nine cases of humeral fractures treated with intramedullary nailing (Seidel/Marchetti-Vicenzi/Prévot) from January 1991 to December 1995 (44 fractures after trauma, 11 pathological fractures, 3 pseudarthroses, 1 re-fracture).	0.6289817496550687
Closed reduction in 55/59 cases.	0.2879571040642427
One infection (soft tissue); 2/48 pseudarthrosis (indication for nailing: pseudarthrosis!).	0.47419174063011105
No iatrogenic palsy of the radial nerve.	0.4828845468833809
Functional postoperative treatment in all 44 cases of humeral fractures after adequate trauma.	0.4370295029696596
One poor functional result: periarticular ossification after retrograde nailing, possibly connected with long-term respiratory treatment after trauma.	0.43626122370329523
Treatment of humeral shaft fractures by intramedullary nailing is favoured in our clinic (low complication rates, excellent or good functional results, limited approaches, small scars).	0.6612771535265138
Proximal fractures should be treated by the Seidel nail (stable interlocking of the proximal fragment); very distal fractures need Prévot nailing (reaming of condylar canals).	0.5253971873322858
All other fractures of the humeral shaft can be treated by each of the implants used in our clinic.	0.8279439390867956

In polytraumatized patients the rate is even 10 %.	0.4652839663304243

Penetration or blunt vascular trauma result either in acute blood loss, ischemia or compartmental compression.	0.3946662174117304
Reperfusion syndrom leads to vital threat of patient.	0.2332075945309169

In most cases autogenous vein graft is required.	0.3839587260142995

The microphone was positioned beneath the skin of the auditory canal such that it completely covered the microphone membrane.	0.46894798529183374

The microphone and transducer were electrically connected with an external battery-driven signal amplifier.	0.44556419216443394

One patient declared the music to be "a little of unnatural."	0.43982845545372024

An amplification factor that can be technically realized in an implantable hearing aid was necessary for one of the patients with sensorineural hearing loss to perceive music at a pleasant volume.	0.6202035150093523
On the basis of this study, essential requirements for the construction of a fully implantable hearing aid are fulfilled.	0.7710745381290555

An essential feature of the known procedures for the analysis of the ECG signal is the splitting of the ECG into individual parameters which are subsequently processed in defined decision trees, neuronal networks or statistical procedures to diagnostic information.	0.5561909935851241
The correctness of the diagnostic statements thus substantially depends on the suitable selection and the exact determination of the individual criteria.	0.6274497372364022
The analysis algorithm and the expert knowledge are closely linked due to the procedure.	0.45275661338434436
This paper presents a new procedure or the evaluation of signals of medical sensor systems by the example of the ECG.	0.581854469661086
Unlike the methods used up to now, this procedure is not based on an ever more profound splitting of the ECG signal into individual features.	0.7310950044893099
Furthermore, analysis algorithm and knowledge base are separated from each other.	0.5191476838731545
The consideration underlying the procedure is that two ECGs whose leads show identical or very similar signal patterns indicate identical or at least very similar cardiological diagnoses.	0.45729439190447874
As this assumption is the basis of medical experience, it should be possible to compare the signal patterns of the leads of an unknown ECG with those of the leads of the reference ECGs from a database and to draw conclusions for the diagnosis of the unknown ECG.	0.7066301957008421
For this purpose, those ECGs are searched in an ECG database whose leads show greatest agreement with the signal pattern of the unknown ECG.	0.5028482325557763
The function of the method was established with the aid of the ECG signal database CARDIODAT with 249 ECGs for the diagnostic groups: infarcts and healthy reference persons from a data inventory of 550 ECGs.	0.552866258822477
It can be seen from the results that the presented procedure which is based on signal pattern recognition is a new approach to deriving diagnostic information from the ECG signal at least for the diagnostic group of myocardial infarcts.	0.717686467451321

During a 4-week ambulatory cardiacc rehabilitation program, 262 patients with coronary artery disease (CAD), 235 men and 27 women, 53.6+/-10.2 years, performed 30.5+/-2,9 exercise units.	0.6893517547525913
Before and after the rehabilitation program exercise, capacity was assessed by bicycle ergometry.	0.6651270329248273
There was a significant (p<0.001) increase in the maximum exercise capacity at the end of the program (105.3+/-32.3 vs. 121.9+/-37.3 W).	0.6499601035189516
Physical work capacity on the 2.0 mmol lactate level improved (p<0.001) from 72.2+/-23.5 to 86.4+/-25.8 W, on the 2.5 mmol/l level (p<0.001) from 83.5+/-23.2 to 97.4+/-26.4 W, and on the 3.0 mmol/l level (p<0.001) from 93.1+/-23.0 to 106.6+/-26.1 W. Despite enhanced performance, heart rate remained unaltered on the 2.0, 2.5, and 3.0 mmol/l lactate level.	0.7707846530966672
Furthermore, ergometric performance on predefined heart rate levels was significantly (p<0.001) increased: 85/min: from 56.0+/-24.1 to 65.8+/-24.5 W; 90/min: from 62.0+/-27.3 to 71.2+/-26 W; 95/min: from 67.2+/-26.4 to 77.5+/-27.6 W; 100/min: from 71.1+/-29.6 to 80.6+/-28.1 W; 105/min: from 69.8+/-26.2 to 81.9+/-28.2 W and 110/min: from 73.6+/-28.9 to 90.4+/-29.4 W. The results demonstrate that physical performance in patients with CAD was improved by our novel ambulatory cardiac rehabilitation program.	0.6707093606434013
This improvement included an increase in maximum as well as endurance work capacity; furthermore, this increase was accompanied by a decrease in resting and exercise heart rates.	0.5252497751434548
The results demonstrate an absolute increase of physical performance, more importantly an increase of physical performance at defined lactate levels in the presence of unchanged heart rates mediated by the rehabilitation program.	0.6176503656149168
Thus, this increase was independent of motivational factors in the patients and/or the investigators during the re-exercise test.	0.7719242599719237
On the contrary, our data demonstrate that it is based on an improvement of aerobic endurance capacity associated with a therapeutically beneficial significant decrease of heart rate for a defined workload.	0.7082684159507241
The effects were independent of pharmacological influences (e.g., -receptor antagonists).	0.7259547372043295
These findings are of clinical importance with respect to reduction of myocardial oxygen consumption in patients with CAD.	0.7193310991245235

The separation of whole blood into components is the state-of-the-art in transfusion of allogeneic blood.	0.5770890111749435
The main reasons are the negative effects of the buffy coat and the need for FFP.	0.6392042178718907
Nevertheless, especially in Germany whole blood is being rejected more and more even as autologous blood.	0.561295474478297
However, most of the negative effects of the buffy coat do not apply to autologous blood.	0.5802834978391854
Additionally, these patients usually do not develop coagulation disorders and therefore do not need plasma as a hemostatic component.	0.5877417143210073
On the other hand, separation into components of autologous blood leads to an increase of costs and to logistic problems that restrict autologous blood predeposit to a few institutions.	0.5166046702961116
Therefore, we have reviewed the literature in order to find a scientific basis for this.	0.7974038773880795
We analysed all articles listed by MEDLINE during the last 12 years that dealt with the quality of whole blood or red cell concentrates.	0.5802425873133914
In addition, all references were included that contributed relevant information to the topic.	0.5091096133574068
A total of 135 original articles, abstracts, reviews, letters or editorials were analysed that referred to standard preparations and storage media.	0.35298155906033346
In 48 papers the in vivo red cell survival was studied.	0.4631934200821329
28 of which fulfilled the prerequisites to be included into a meta-analysis.	0.5392615421289975
The following in vitro parameters were also evaluated: pH, potassium load of the units, ATP and DPG concentration of the red cells.	0.5765134732319602
Whole blood (resuspended in CPDA-1) and red cell units (stabilized in CPDA-1 or additive solutions) with a different buffy coat or leucocyte content have comparable pH values and red cell 2,3-DPG and ATP concentrations at the end of the approved storage time.	0.5286632722625034
The potassium load of a whole blood unit appears to be higher than red cell concentrates, but this is to some extent caused by the higher plasma content of whole blood and is not thought to be a clinically relevant problem for patients receiving only a few units.	0.7917292366007539
A number of studies demonstrate that dependent upon the leucocyte content of a red cell unit, leucocyte metabolites and enzymes are released and accumulate during storage.	0.40909301425974753
A detrimental influence on the integrity of the red cell membrane was found in several in vitro studies.	0.6789145580029123
Nevertheless, a significant improvement in red cell survival by leucocyte reduction was detected by only one group.	0.7622481022482477
Undoubtedly, non-hemolytic febrile transfusion reactions (NHFTR) are generally caused by an antibody-antigen interaction due to the transfusion of allogeneic buffy coat.	0.5572939273571335
On the other hand, there is some evidence that non-specific immunological mechanisms such as the release of histamine or cytokines are also capable of causing NHFTR.	0.5620967610310242
Thus, these reactions are expected to occur in autologous blood transfusion.	0.6552946250733248
However, so far, there are no data about the frequency and severity of these reactions and whether they are more likely to emerge after transfusion of blood units with a particular preparation.	0.8248954517175534
Blood transfusions can cause septic complications due to bacterial contamination of the transfused units.	0.412569204411586
These fatal but rare complications may be reduced by pre-storage filtration of blood, but there is no indication that buffy coat reduction is effective.	0.6367378806618625
Three cases with septic complications have been reported after autologous transfusion, in two of which red cell concentrates (at least one was free of buffy coat) had been used.	0.9196683427201164
Thus, there is no justification for the conclusion that the risk of septic complications is increased by transfusion of whole blood.	0.6678188513978919
After all, whole blood and red cell concentrates exhibit only minor differences in relevant in vitro parameters.	0.5314707167137595
Hence, a higher incidence of adverse effects following the transfusion of autologous whole blood compared to autologous red cell concentrations is unlikely.	0.5281162156399555
Therefore, the 24 h in vivo recovery is considered to be the most valid criterion to assess the quality of red cell preparations.	0.6615716043880872

It is accompanied by progressive pathological alterations of the cytsokeleton which are traceable to an abnormal phosphorylation of the microtubule associated tau protein.	0.3936541067115756

These cellular inclusions display a typical cortical as well as subcortical distribution pattern.	0.36246609727344575

The benefits of epidural analgesia are well known, but it is not well understood which types of urologic surgery benefit most from epidural analgesia.	0.6838350643996763
In this study, the effects and side effects of prolonged epidural analgesia are prospectively examined and analysed on 172 adult patients in three different operation groups.	0.6459205147809518
An epidural infusion of local anaesthetic combined with an opioid and adrenaline was given for a period of 5-7 days.	0.753741436294147
There was no difference between the groups with respect to the effectiveness of the analgesia and patients' perception of the treatment.	0.8176057752859948
Mobilization differed, as expected, between the groups, however even after the most major surgery (e. g. cystectomy with bladder substitution), mobilization was impressively unproblematic.	0.7588529199668841
Retarded return of regular intestinal function after the transperitoneal operation and partly after lumbotomy compared with the extraperitoneal operation depended on which operation was performed and the amount of analgesia given.	0.5082367370687396
The side effects such as sedation, nausea and pruritis were conditional partly on the opiate and partly on the intervention.	0.4817119791819415
Up to 11 % showed slight muscular weakness of the lower limbs as a specific side effect of the local anaesthetic.	0.9107171564736141
Complications: One patient died of cerebral hypoxy due to an initially undetected subdural catheter placement complicated by severe pre-existent carotid stenosis.	0.5728408981352507
In four patients, the epidural analgesia had to be stopped because of catheter migration.	0.7006726111544362
There was no clinical evidence of hematoma, abscess or permanent neurological damage.	0.5450121313031012
Epidural analgesia works well in terms of analgesia, mobilization and patient satisfaction, bearing in mind the potential side effects and complications.	0.5465691456364519

High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) provides excellent contrast between osseous structures, air and soft tissue in conjunction with high spatial resolution.	0.508195419418296
Therefore, thin-section HRCT with bone window setting is the method of choice for the examination of the middle ear structures.	0.6637406704213551
The indications are acute and chronic inflammatory changes, cholesteatoma and tumor, the "postoperative middle ear", and malformations.	0.673638277159012
In most cases, HRCT enables differentiation between inflammatory changes, cholesteatoma, and tumor.	0.5679679603745532

In addition, HRCT enables excellent depiction of reconstructions of the ossicles or prosthesis of the ossicles.	0.5007634399768126
Although HRCT is the first method of choice, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) may provide additional information and lead to a more accurate diagnosis in some cases.	0.719859245140494
This is explained by the excellent soft tissue contrast provided by MRI.	0.5258686912267773
In addition, MRI offers the possibility of using various pulse sequences and the administration of IV contrast material.	0.513417962940453
Therefore, MRI may allow the differentiation between inflammatory changes, cholesteatoma, and tumor in those cases in which accurate diagnosis cannot be made by HRCT.	0.7591548329414674
The differentiation between a meningocele or meningoencephalocele and other entities such as tumors or cholesteatoma can be established by MRI.	0.48164960010011637

Following morphometry significant correlations were calculated between number of CD61+ megakaryocytes, including their precursors with fiber density.	0.4458408799352129
This finding is in line with the close functional relationship between megakaryopoiesis and fibroblasts regarding the complex pathomechanism of myelofibrosis.	0.37810215484894405
The latter was observed in about 28% of patients already at diagnosis.	0.7518504452907451

The (-D-galactosyl residue-expressing) Pseudo-Gaucher cells were detectable in 30% of pretreatment specimens.	0.6909269625261272

These variables are in keeping with more advanced stages of CML.	0.3975265971672381

This simplified staging system was correlated with corresponding sets of hematological data.	0.3301094242097066

The dynamics of myelofibrosis and changes of major cell lineages during treatment were readily demonstrable by calculating corresponding indices.	0.41086443016773916
These included the ratios between quantitative differences of corresponding variables at repeated examinations and time.	0.3003536832687507
Thus, in patients with complete hematological remission following IFN administration, regeneration of erythropoiesis was found to be accompanied by an increase in the total number of CD68+ macrophages, including activated subpopulations.	0.6663730231501429

This change was opposed to a numerical reduction in the myelofibrotic subtype which occurred in 17 patients (36%), but predominantly in those under HU therapy.	0.5656547848897407

The majority of complications are due to initial misdiagnoses and a delay in treatment.	0.4737985824645569
Lesions of the pancreas and duodenum are the most frequent diagnoses in the retroperitoneal space, while major vascular traumata or urogenital injuries are rare.	0.7265892514405903
Retroperitoneal hematoma are most likely due to pelvic fractures.	0.38449363653923063
The survival of patients after colon or retroperitoneal injuries depends on the severity of concomitant organ trauma, the time of diagnosis, and a situation-adapted therapeutic strategy.	0.8608578888267571
The treatment of the typical caudal retroperitoneal hematoma following pelvic fractures is conservative in most patients.	0.5647141902689349
Early pelvic stabilization, e. g., with external fixation, is recommended in these patients.	0.7034494792021998
Central retroperitoneal hematoma in the supra - or inframesocolic space should be treated surgically, as major vascular injuries are most likely in these patients.	0.7786965597314953
Duodenal or pancreatic injuries need surgical exploration in the majority of patients; the therapeutic spectrum ranges from simple sutures to pancreatoduodenal resection.	0.5599102785302895
The treatment of colon injuries depends on the degree of peritonitis and the severity of concomitant trauma.	0.5141394912967918
Early diagnosed injuries are suitable for primary repair, while deviation stomata or a Hartmann procedure with or without resection should be offered to patients with delayed diagnoses, peritonitis, or severe concomitant diseases.	0.6056607774537865
Long-lasting procedures should be abandoned in the emergency situation; in these severe cases, laparotomy should be aimed towards primary "damage control" and followed by definite surgery after stabilization of the patient.	0.7533147152079737
Surgery of the great veins inevitably began with the surgical treatment of injuries, often involving the femoral vein.	0.7382695168862421
Because of the famous case presented by Roux in 1813, the prevailing opinion until almost the end of the nineteenth century was that ligation of the vein made death inevitable, but that the only way to control severe hemorrhaging from a vein was to ligate the femoral artery.	0.5476718278299193
Zaufal's principle (1880) consisted in the ligation and resection of great veins of the body and limbs in order to prevent sepsis in suppurative processes.	0.5618316145451446
This surgical method was still being used in the first half of the twentieth century in patients with perforated appendicitis or puerperal fever.	0.6631943245076944
In the limb, the congestion induced in the vein had a positve effect on the healing process.	0.5948479830108039
The surgical treatment of leg and pelvic deep vein thrombosis was initially (1931) aimed at achieving decompression in compartment syndromas.	0.4795851443434568
The first thrombectomy was performed in 1937, but several operations with a successful outcome were reported at the 61st annual meeting of the German Society of Surgery in the following year.	0.7755781494142697
Bilateral glomus jugulare tumors are rare.	0.3322836828086569

Intoxication is the monotone reaction of the CNS to consumed psychoactive substances.	0.4218918503765824
Intoxication-like conditions may also occur without taking drugs.	0.44526928890005274
We then use the term "ecstasy".	0.2834913059548824
Intoxication can follow typical or atypical course.	0.19869276411745385
The main symptoms are disturbances of consciousness and orientation and additionally changes of mood, affect, drive and initiative, train of thought and self-control.	0.4724322561297446
The diagnosis of intoxication differs from the diagnosis of psychosis because the latter continues its own course, occurs in the absence of psychoactive substances in the organism and always lasts longer than an intoxication.	0.4809629510553132

Androgenetic hair loss is the most frequent reason for the topical application of hair-growth-promoting agents.	0.6366272202088935
Such preparations should arrest or even reverse androgen-induced hair follicle regression as well as prolonging the hair cycles, especially of the shortened anagen phase, and thus protect from increased hair loss.	0.5357609663004584
True evidence of drug effects on hair growth is problematic, since trichograms, the method chiefly applied by the manufacturers, fail to reveal every factor involved in the follicular activity, especially the duration of anagen stage.	0.6905566192329302
For example, an increase in the anagen rate does not always reflect a lengthening of the anagen stage, but may also be due to shortened hair cycles.	0.720980618183581

Paraneoplastic neurologic syndromes (PNS) are rare disorders of the nervous system that cannot be ascribed to metatastases or to destruction of vital systemic organs by the tumor or its treatment.	0.5666379485359269
Most frequently, PNS occur in association with small-cell lung, breast or ovarian carcinomas.	0.48486207933335557
The most frequent PNS is Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, which at the same time has the highest predictive value concerning an underlying carcinoma.	0.6107667568165203
PNS have been classified mostly under anatomical aspects but now are increasingly categorized according to specific antibodies.	0.37319073685207127
In certain neurologic syndromes (sensible and autonomic neuropathy, cerebellitis, limbic encephalitis, Opsoclonus-Myoclonus syndrome, Stiff-man syndrome, neuromyotonia, subacute amaurosis) specific autoantibodies are highly predictive for a neoplasm.	0.45833371114072313
Pathogenic relevance of these autoantibodies has been demonstrated only for antibodies against (1) voltage gated calcium channels (VGCC) in Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, (2) voltage gated potassium channels (VGKC) in neuromyotonia, and (3) recoverin in cancer associated retinopathy.	0.6010310190168656
