Ewing's sarcoma is a very rare tumor which has, however, attracted much oncological interest since the dramatic improvement of its prognosis under chemotherapy.	0.4351654560332163
Its histogenesis has been discussed controversially for a long time, including a possible origin in immature reticulum, myogenous, endothelial and undifferentiated mesenchymal cells.	0.6456243954921866
Repeated reports have also suggested a possible neuroectodermal genesis.	0.34871471956173256
Convincing arguments, however, have only been brought forward during recent years, since it was found that Ewing's sarcoma and malignant peripheral neuroectodermal tumor share a common chromosome translocation 11;22.	0.6089468365095235
In the meantime this hypothesis has been strengthened by numerous cell biological analyses.	0.4270759218077766
There seems to be no clear border between Ewing's sarcoma and malignant peripheral neuroectodermal tumors with definite neural differentiation.	0.4800386783494594
Histological differential diagnosis of Ewing's sarcoma has been improved by immunohistological methods.	0.4593151981825036
In most cases, they can be distinguished from lymphoma (leucocyte common antigen, B and T markers) and embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (muscle specific actin, desmin) without problems.	0.7129916566149687
Apart from that, it is possible nowadays to obtain antibodies against the MIC 2-protein, which is preferably expressed in Ewing sarcoma.	0.7239809083840975
The diagnostics of Ewing's sarcoma and the malignant peripheral neuroectodermal tumor have considerably been enriched by the fact that the specific chromosome translocation t(11;22) can be proved molecular biologically.	0.5058693716532608
In contrast to the cytogenetic evidence, it is not necessary to establish cell cultures.	0.8307361812925846

Managed care, i.e., the integration of health insurance and delivery of care under the direction of one organization, is gaining importance in the USA health market.	0.7001476553897734
The initial effects consisted of a decrease in insurance premiums, a very attractive feature for employers.	0.5614298924426091
Managed care promises to contain expenditures for health care.	0.2921500352662715
Given the shrinking public resources in Germany, managed care seems attractive for the German health system, too.	0.3939599245656442
In this review the development of managed care, the principal elements, forms of organisation and practical tools are outlined.	0.6379512416111986
The regulation of the delivery of care by means of controlling and financial incentives threatens the autonomy of physicians: the physician must act as a "double agent", caring for the interest for the individual patient and being restricted by the contract with the managed care organisation.	0.5965696845835754
Cost containment by managed care was achieved by reducing the fees for physicians and hospitals (and partly by restricting care for patients).	0.5403489395873959
Only a fraction of this cost reduction was handed over to the enrollee or employer, and most of the money was returned with profit to the shareholders of the managed care organisations.	0.4746254762200396
The preeminent role of primary care physicians as gatekeepers of the health network led to a reduced demand for specialist services in general and for university hospitals and anesthesiologists in particular.	0.5297273241228228
The paradigm of managed care, i.e., to guide the patient and the care giver through the health care system in order to achieve cost-effective and high quality care, seems very attractive.	0.7220621913477241
The stress on cost minimization by any means in the daily practice of managed care makes it doubtful if managed care should be an option for the German health system, in particular because there are a number of restrictions on it in German law.	0.6489000879899358

In the past, most scientific or routine studies on heart rate variability (HRV) were done using commercial Holter ECG devices with traditional magnetic tapes.	0.5796421172179985
All methods to calculate parameters of HRV are based on the measurement of time intervals between successive sinus cardiac beats, in practice RR intervals.	0.6040503733638309
Hence, results of HRV calculation depend on the quality of primary data acquisition.	0.5684177332382515
However, technical standards on accuracy of RR interval acquisition in magnetic tape and digital solid state Holter ECG systems do not exist as yet.	0.5210687790337193
Therefore in a laboratory investigation accuracy of HRV parameter calculation after traditional standard tape with and without real-time analysis and digital solid state data acquisition was compared in three commercial Holter ECG systems [Ela medical (E), Oxford Medilog Excel (O) and Medset Cardiolight (M)].	0.5108030636072999
A computer-based ECG simulator was used to synthesize a test signal consisting of artificial P-QRS complexes of fixed rate, quartz stabilized "sinus rhythms".	0.43391113481735233
Two channel analog tape and digital 24h recordings of the fixed rate test signal were performed simultaneously.	0.3388353900499273
The influence of recording technology on accuracy of RR interval measurement and consequently on time domaine HRV was shown by comparing five standard 24-h time domain parameters.	0.43223911906556245
As expected, in the three Holter systems the analog tape recordings showed a higher, technically induced, artificial RR variability.	0.5956337353312674
The SDNN values (E: 9.38ms vs 2.68ms; p<0.001; O: 3.89ms vs 0.97ms; p<0.001; M: 10.47ms vs 2.89ms; p=0.001), SDNN-Index values (E: 8.22ms vs 0.90ms; p<0.001; O: 3.75ms vs 0.90ms; p<0.001; M: 7.81ms vs 1.49ms, p<0.001) and RMSSD-values (E: 10.39ms vs 2.16ms; p<0.001; O: 10.05ms vs 1.88ms, p<0.001; M: 8.62ms vs 1.69ms; p<0.001) were significantly lower if acquisition was done by digital solid devices in all systems, SDANN (M: 9.83ms vs 5.37ms; p<0.001) in the Medset system too.	0.6121087089978794
The used method is a possible way to validate commercial Holter ECG systems for HRV analysis.	0.5476167044981443
Clinical significance of artifical HRV seems to be low.	0.5184293653884131

Based on the preliminary clinical and radiological outcomes of these four subgroups, the following conclusions can be drawn: labral lesions are considered to be a sign of chronic joint instability.	0.7438076375399832

Cavography is no longer needed in the era of (adaptive array detector) spiral CT and MR venography.	0.6785701681819397

The serum concentrations of glycine decreased following sodium benzoate treatment but cerebrospinal fluid/serum glycine ratio remained elevated with no improvement in clinical outcome.	0.35324629917217176
The patient with the infantile form has been treated for over three years with dextromethorphan, and is now a severely retarded child without seizure activity and continuous psychomotor development.	0.696735370954658

Amniotic fluid is a major factor of the intrauterine environment, and deviation from the normal volume is associated with an increased perinatal morbidity and mortality.	0.6868006896553129
Polyhydramnios occurs in 0.2 to 1.6 % of pregnancies.	0.8864314612354163
It may be due to a number of congenital anomalies, an abnormal karyotype, maternal diabetes, Rh-disease or intrauterine infections potentially requiring non-invasive or invasive measures.	0.5455753729655188
However, the most common indication for prenatal intervention due to polyhydramnios is the Twin-Twin-Transfusion Syndrom (TTTS).	0.5932365752544401
Treatment of polyhydramnios may focus on correction of the causative lesion, or symptomatic relief through drainage of amniotic fluid.	0.5926881276380843
Maternal administration of cyclooxygenase inhibitors represents a further, non-invasive therapeutic option.	0.4220214382044121
Indomethacin, Sulindac, or Nimesulide reduce the fetal urine output thus decreasing amniotic fluid volume over time without the risks associated with invasive procedures.	0.4399698776592959
However, potentially serious ductal constriction as well as a delay in the onset of amniotic fluid reduction have limited its application.	0.5839318977851039
Percutaneous amniotic fluid drainage may provide immediate reduction of intrauterine pressure, but is associated with a complication rate of 1 to 1.5 %.	0.803521197189765
The hemodynamic characteristics of monochorionic pregnancies complicated by TTTS have led to the development of endoscopic laser coagulation of placental vascular anastomoses as a definitive treatment.	0.3968831294555511
Treatment is only required in a small minoritiy of pregnancies with polyhydramnios.	0.5594203288872029
Mild cases can be managed expectatively.	0.5230591288147671
Intrauterine pressure increases with an excessive increase in amniotic fluid volume (AFI > 400 mm or MVP > 150 mm) leads to the elevation of intrauterine pressure.	0.5622174409407308
Complications such as preterm premature rupture of membranes and preterm labor may lead to premature delivery.	0.4157148286375212
The main goal of prenatal treatment of polyhydramnios is thus the improvement of fetal outcome through prolongation of gestation and/or the alleviation of maternal symptoms.	0.5593304314627278
With the recent developments in computer technology and the improvements in modern neuroimaging, frame-based stereotactic guidance for open microsurgical procedures has been increasingly replaced by neuronavigation, also called frameless stereotaxy.	0.4716507929938074
It allows transfer of individual patient's images onto the operative field to assist the neurosurgeon intraoperatively in defining the tumor margins or identifying functionally important brain areas.	0.45782718046422727
The different localization techniques employed are articulated position-sensing arms, infrared or ultrasound systems working with the principle of satellite navigation and robotic systems integrated with the operating microscope.	0.42857091145878007
In 200 operations performed with different systems (arm-based, robotic and infrared) the method proved to be helpful, enabling fewer invasive procedures to be performed.	0.6676388647316033
With a mean deviation of 2.87 +/- 1.9 mm for intraoperative localization, the accuracy was only slightly worse than in frame-based stereotaxy with deviations below 2 mm.	0.7635158934167132
Neuronavigation was most helpful for operations on deeply seated lesions, skull-base tumors and lesions in brain areas with high functionality.	0.44631475008103444
The major disadvantage is the use of preoperative data for navigation, leading to inaccuracies when anatomical structures are altered during the operation by resection of tumors or shift of intracranial soft tissue.	0.5226402144409862
Intraoperative magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) might be a solution for this problem.	0.4189530432469532
With the method of intraoperative MRI developed in our department it has already been possible to update neuronavigation with images reflecting intraoperative changes in anatomy.	0.5653147512651032
Therefore, neuronavigation is definitely a method with growing importance in operative routine, and it will also spread into other surgical specialties.	0.5697829392184378
Severe pain of mucositis induced by cytostatic conditioning therapy in bone marrow transplantation (BMT) patients generally requires continuous parenteral opioid treatment.	0.5392712051559966
Cognitive and psychological disturbances are frequent complications subsequent to BMT and may result from cerebral opioid side effects.	0.5203449587043366
The aim of the study was to evaluate the efficiency of continuous morphine in mucositis pain and the side-effects in BMT patients.	0.6747684393828202
Particular emphasis was placed on the question of whether reaction times, which are usually measured to estimate opioid effects upon vigilance, are influenced by pain-induced cognitive impairments in pain patients.	0.6878155731248805
Methods While in hospital, 10 BMT patients were examined daily with the aid of a mucositis scale, subjective visual analog scales (VAS) for pain and mood parameters, a German version of the McGill pain questionnaire (MPQ), and a mental performance task battery, and the morphine given was documented.	0.7365455516327808
Mental performance tests were simple auditory reaction time and choice reaction time.	0.38580685332603626
Seven patients also performed a Sternberg memory search test in which they had to use 'yes' and 'no' response keys to match visually presented test letters to a previously memorized set of letters.	0.4282897915800606
Practice and baseline data were collected within the first week before BMT.	0.7000555967385178
Results The intensity and duration of mucositis differed from patient to patient, resulting in different pain intensities and MPQ scores.	0.42359153889630485
Prolongation of the choice reaction time averaged over the period of mucositis treatment correlated significantly with residual pain intensity (Spearman rs = 0.88, p < 0.01) but not with morphine dose (rs = 0.35, p = 0.33).	0.5640799979779079
For the Sternberg memory search test greater correlation coefficients resulted between reaction time and morphine dose (rs = 0.86, p = 0.014) than between reaction time and residual pain intensity (rs = 0.61, p = 0.15).	0.49585798151129207
In turn, pain intensity, unlike morphine dose, was significantly correlated with high scores in the mood parameters for depression, passivity, and tiredness.	0.6973993887591189
Conclusions It is concluded that both pain and morphine can impair cognitive performance, but that these mental stressors seem to differ according to qualitative criteria.	0.5103815020149208
Whereas pain might slow reaction time by distracting a patient's attention, particularly in low mental demand tasks, morphine could interfere with more specific cognitive processes, such as short-term memory operations, that are required in more complex tasks.	0.6695549035255757

Brain-stem gliomas occur mainly in childhood and are localized in the mesencephalon, pons and medulla oblongata.	0.5305645321996477
Diagnosis is a domain of MRI, requiring T2, T1 and KM.	0.48504197960428674
CT shows hemorrhage and calcification well.	0.21348617603194414

Methods: Cases of invasive HI-infections were reported in a national active surveillance program.	0.5604069700086012
The case definition required the typical clinical picture and a HI positive culture from a physiologically sterile site (or throat swab or tracheal aspirate in case of epiglottitis or pneumonia) in children up to 10 years.	0.6541488666814146
All initial reports were validated with a questionnaire that additionally questioned the vaccination status, type of vaccine, therapy, outcome of the disease and characteristics of the bacteria.	0.7637348627080519
The relation between the type of Hib vaccine used on the risk of infection was analysed in a case control study with controls selected at random from a population based sampling frame.	0.6275193638652585
Results: 310 confirmed cases of invasive HI infections were reported during the observation period, 199 of these with meningitis, 56 with epiglottitis.	0.5058171879504104
The number of cases declined from 71 in the last six months of 1992, 120 in 1993, and 65 in 1994 to 54 cases in 1995.	0.6476796561845541
In 1995 the incidence in up to 5 year old children was 1.1/100 000 for all infection sites and 0.7/100 000 for meningitis.	0.7207241988216854
The reduced rates were mainly due to a decrease in the number of unvaccinated cases, whereas the number of cases in vaccinated children fluctuated between 22 and 36 per year.	0.6014285729441111
Most of these were observed in incompletely vaccinated children, who according to the German recommendations could already have received at least one further vaccination at the time of the infection.	0.852263641405277

10 % of the bacteria produced betalactamase.	0.6991153514753282

One third of these, however, received additional antibiotics.	0.4599385127523397
Conclusions: The present incidence of systemic HI infections in Germany is low.	0.7434650320174063

Intraoperative lesions of the mesothelial lining by abrasion, ischemia, dissication, and foreign bodies result in complaints, intestinal obstruction, female infertility, and problems during reoperations.	0.5530149746752215

As of today, there is no safe and efficient prophylaxis available.	0.5806101188670644

Even today the name of F. D. von Recklinghausen is often mentioned in connection with primary and secondary hyperparathyroidism.	0.4524985639451726
He was one of the first physicians and scientists to render outstanding services to the classification of structural changes of bones, and in many aspects his work remains valid today.	0.7377606332820471
He succeeded through precise and comparative studies in making the disease and symptoms of primary hyperparathyroidism known and thus distinguishing it from other known structural bone diseases.	0.5469446661607084
He also described the phenomenon of "bone remodeling" which has become relevant today again.	0.6519066250787822
Although his written macroscopic and microscopic observations include meticulously precise differentiations which make it difficult to study them today, they are still of interest in order to follow his basic ideas.	0.47080369302443376
This article does not constitute a comprehensive biography, but it contains a description of F. D. von Recklinghausen's important work on bone pathology against the background of the main stages of his life.	0.5860595409843001
Soft-tissue sarcomas (STS) of the extremities are characterized by a high rate of local recurrences.	0.7360423742078712
Limb salvage approaches using multimodality therapy protocols have replaced amputation.	0.2753341122053246
In order to evaluate isolated hyperthermic limb perfusion (ILP) in a multimodality therapy concept, we reviewed our patients treated using this method.	0.771935659233187
Between January 1982 and December 1995, 25 ILPs, using cisplatin, melphalan and adriamycin, were performed in 22 patients with STS.	0.7077827296685251
Forty percent were treated for local recurrences; histology was dominated by malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH) and synovial sarcoma.	0.5023031305437669
In all, 68 % of the STS were classified as UICC stage IIb or IIIa/b.	0.5319824166477275
Most of the cases (14) underwent wide or radical resection, 4 patients received intraoperative radiotherapy, and 5 were treated with external beam radiation.	0.9387478198473264
Complications were recorded in 32 % of the cases.	0.6999965832354754
With a median follow-up of 45 months (range 1-143), the 5-year overall survival rate was 81 %.	0.8002033584398284
The median recurrence-free time was 19 months and the 5-year disease-free survival rate 34 %.	0.6638317526581501
There were 13 local failures, and distant metastases developed in 36 % of the patients.	0.7121581036318412
Concerning high-grade sarcomas (UICC stage IIb, IIIa/b), we found local recurrences in 75 % of all cases.	0.8634598740055336
Five of 11 patients with local failures underwent perfusion after they refused amputation, and 7 incompletely resected STS received ILP without reoperation.	0.5192941077712802
All of these demonstrated local recurrence.	0.4085254257108827
This rate of local recurrence proved to be different from patients with tumor-free resection margins (p = 0.0001, log-rank test).	0.6300319907617684
The amputation rate after isolated limb perfusion was 27 % (mean 11 months after treatment).	0.7068626386545911
Long-term results of ILP showed a considerable local recurrence rate and a low disease-free survival.	0.7436316511029506
Perfusion in patients without tumor-free resection margins does not prevent local recurrence.	0.6296372255750152
We conclude that ILP with cisplatin, melphalan and adriamycin should be considered carefully and is not an additional treatment strategy of first choice.	0.6616364990350561

The bleeding after thrombolysis and coagulopathy required massive blood transfusions.	0.2655085977701035
The situation was also complicated by lesions of the liver, spleen and small intestines, which required surgical intervention, and acute renal failure, which had to be treated with transient hemofiltration.	0.8410708574454233
Twenty-eight days after receiving CPR, the patient was discharged from the ICU.	0.8288870321784678
A diagnosis of pulmonary embolism was established by clinical signs, capnometry, blood gas analysis, and electrocardiography.	0.7786366064168814
Due to the requirements of the emergency situation (ongoing CPR), further diagnostic tools were not used.	0.760989782165928
The patient survived without any neurological deficiency, despite the extended 135-min use of CPR, and despite massive bleeding due to surgical trauma, and to performing CPR in the presence of fibrinolytica.	0.6480194320740484
With the increasing use of cross-sectional echocardiography in patients with overt or suspected pulmonary thromboembolism in the emergency rooms, more and more right atrial thrombi are detected.	0.6345933208062831
These are so-called "transitthrombi" from the venous system on their way to the pulmonary arteries and they are a severe presentation of thromboembolic disease.	0.6378017561315225
They appear as an imminent pulmonary embolism and usually coexists with an already massive embolism.	0.44759726686426343
In patients were a right atrial thrombus is associated with a patent foramen ovale, paradoxical arterial embolism has been observed.	0.5404519314162917
Right sided heart thrombi have a high mortality rate and need immediate treatment.	0.5769779083706252
In our hospital we have seen 14 patients with right atrial thrombi and pulmonary embolism in a period of 6 years.	0.753072347591728
Three patients had cardiac arrest with a massive pulmonary embolism, seven patients presented with a submassive embolism.	0.6896757305089647
All patients were treated immediately after echocardiographic diagnosis without pulmonary angiography.	0.6890205408000964
In about half of the cases transesophageal echocardiography was done additionally for diagnosis and monitoring.	0.7099826834192544
Therapeutic options were thrombectomy, fibrinolysis or anticoagulants.	0.3491063089853103
We treated one of our patients with thrombectomy, eleven patients with fibrinolysis and two patients with anticoagulants.	0.6710784630139168
The era of modern anaesthesia in Germany began on January 24th, 1847.	0.43029306879885126
This day, professor in ordinary Johann Ferdinand Heyfelder anaesthetized a patient with sulphuric ether in the clinic of surgery and ophthalmology of the University of Erlangen.	0.5520434352245381
By March 17th, 1847, Heyfelder had performed 121 surgical procedures under ether.	0.3437292032207569
The operations in majority were teeth-extractions, and a few more complex operations such as the treatment of a harelip or of lip cancer or the resection of the shoulder joint.	0.7315548294708215
Heyfelder described in detail 108 of these inhalations in a little book entitled The experiments with sulphuric ether.	0.3989883788505801
This monograph published in March, 1847, represents one of the first complete dissertations on sulphuric ether in the German literature.	0.5863705443776951
In a special chapter he analyzed the development of various physiological and psychological parameters during etherization.	0.4457819922162358
Heyfelder also examined blood and urine of some etherized patients and reported that he did not find any important or specific alterations.	0.40593053553439
In 1847, Heyfelder was probably the first to apply salt-ether in man.	0.5073269197595558
After 4 administrations he concluded that salt ether acted more quickly but shorter than sulphuric ether.	0.28487285931528844
Advantageous were its application without problems and ease of induction.	0.34159105894449976
Disadvantageous were its high volatility, its price and the difficulty of getting it in a pure form.	0.46498088634546136
From December, 1847, on Heyfelder started to use chloroform.	0.5068446653945007
He was now able to perform more major operations, for example the total resection of the hip-joint.	0.7227702732992308
In his book The experiments with sulphuric ether, salt ether, and chloroform he describes a great number of anaesthetic administrations using these 3 agents.	0.441891309630245
In his summary Heyfelder concluded, that chloroform was undoubtly superior to sulphuric ether mainly because it was a quicker acting and longer lasting agent and leads to deeper narcosis.	0.4512551690351906
Moreover its application was much easier for it needed no special apparatus.	0.30900404796556885
However, because of its great anaesthetic potency, Heyfelder particularly demanded great caution in the application of chloroform.	0.6497804616482401
Explicitely he expected an assistant for chloroformizations, whose only duty was to supervise the inhalations and the patient - a forerunner of the modern specialized anaesthesiologist.	0.608943896062858
Background: To evaluate the publication rate of abstracts presented during the German Anaesthesia Congress (DAK) in MEDLINE-listed journals in comparison to the publication rate of abstracts presented during the meeting of the European Society of Anaesthesiologists (ESA).	0.5268970344778005
The uniform development of the human embryo, as described by classic human embryology, has been confirmed by sonoembryological studies.	0.7472045215090503
In particular, the embryonic brain is suitable for transvaginal ultrasound examination, because the large "cystic" cavities of the brain can easily be imaged.	0.6533370243788109
Sonoembryology not only describes normal embryonic anatomy and normal relations and proportions of organs, but also the development of structural abnormalities.	0.6141362872173113
Approximately one-third of all congenital anomalies, originate from the central nervous system (CNS).	0.35879945580225825
Based on normal sonoembryology and on recent experiences with early CNS anomalies, we recognize some sonographic signs of an early CNS anomaly: (1) Apparent dysmorphology of the brain or the head; (2) Altered appearance of the cerebral ventricles with disproportion of the brain compartments, where the amount of fluid is either greater or less than normal; (3) In the early fetal period, choroid plexuses that are too small to fill the ventricle from the medial to the lateral wall; (4) Irregular contour of the spine/back; (5) Extra-CNS anomalies.	0.6726990306110875
In the following survey, normal sonoembryology of the CNS is described, and CNS anomalies of the early pregnancy are discussed.	0.734104511903605
Telomerase is an enzyme that elongates telomeric repeats, the specialized structures at the ends of chromosomes that provide genomic stability and compensate for the physiologic process of telomere shortening.	0.4349347239643882
It has been implicated in cellular senescence, immortalization, and carcinogenesis.	0.5859161307188405
Over 85% of human tumours, and 95% of non-melanocytic skin cancers, show telomerase activity, in contrast to the corresponding normal tissues.	0.8296652861194281
This suggests that telomerase activity may play an important role in carcinogenesis.	0.40704664768548027
Recent evidence shows that telomerase is active not only in embryonal and germ line tissues, but also in some normal tissues.	0.6479103354832144
In the skin, this activity has been traced to the stem-cell-bearing epidermal basal cell layer, possibly reflecting the presence of telomerase-competent stem cells.	0.5859173341066914
These findings require a reconsideration of our interpretation of telomerase activity in tumours of the skin and other tissues.	0.586652572441831
As a causal relationship linking telomerase activity and cancer has yet not been demonstrated, some caution is warranted.	0.4898178333872053
The established criteria of auditory brainstem responses (ABR) such as JV latency, JI-V interpeak latency and interaural differences of  latency or amplitude have been found to be sensitive for detecting tumors of the cerebellopontine angle if a response is present.	0.4692003032338176
However, the ABR can be absent in cases of acoustic neuromas because of desynchronization, even though pure-one audiometry indicates that responses should be present.	0.5881264103903115
This retrospective study compared the ABR and pure-tone thresholds in 234 cases with cerebellopontine angle tumors and a control group of 181 cases with sensory hearing losses in order to quantify threshold discrepancies.	0.5590966355360197
The average deficit of the objective ABR threshold (DOABRT) to the subjective pure-tone threshold for those frequencies between 1-6 kHz was 3.6 dB for the control group (ABR and pure tone thresholds very close) and 31.2 dB for the tumor group (ABR threshold much higher than the pure-tone threshold).	0.7714439829539761
ABR thresholds 30 dB higher than the high-frequency pure tone thresholds were found in 40.6% of the tumor group and in none of the control group.	0.8529264289756754
Thus, deficits of the ABR threshold >30 dB can be considered to be an additional criterion for detecting retrocochlear disease and increases ABR sensitivity for tumor detection even if responses are absent.	0.6605325478649615

There is a characteristic predilection for the cerebellum and eighth cranial nerve.	0.5293306461303069
Accordingly, among a variety of symptoms, cerebellar ataxia and sensorineural hearing loss progressing to total deafness commonly occur.	0.4685470493786968
To date, the hearing loss has been believed to be purely neural.	0.5214270134909476

These findings make us conclude that in contrast to current opinion, superficial hemosiderosis can initially damage the cochlea alone.	0.47465768757854343

To date, at least 12 types of primary dystonia can be distinguished on a genetic basis.	0.6763276608928971
A 3-bp deletion in the DYT1 gene causes early onset, generalized torsion dystonia (TD), and mutations in the GTP cyclohydrolase I and the tyrosine hydroxylase genes result in dopa-responsive dystonia (DYT5).	0.4672206146962581

Determination of radiation exposure applied by multi-phase spiral CT. Estimation of the dose in air in the system axis of the scanner, the CT dose index (CTDI) and the effective dose for electron beam tomography (EBT) and two conventional CT scanners (sequence, SEQ; spiral, SCT).	0.7043921041470461
For EBT, dose in system axis for investigation of the abdomen was above 50 mGy.	0.5189549275885371
Effective dose for investigation of the chest and abdomen was higher with EBT (11 and 26 mSv, respectively) than with conventional CT (SEQ, 4 and 20 mSv; SCT, 2 and 7 mSv).	0.7670321673887571
The effective dose for a biphasic investigation (liver 5 mSv, kidney 4 mSv) was below, for a triphasic investigation (liver 7 mSv) above the effective dose of the investigastion of the abdomen (6 mSv).	0.726989390669703

Bone fracture, soft-tissue trauma and hemorrhagic shock are frequent complications in trauma patients, and these patients are known to be immunocompromised.	0.7818872899726771
Nonetheless, it is difficult to differentiate the effect of soft-tissue trauma plus hemorrhage from that of bone fracture and hemorrhage on host immune function in the clinical setting.	0.7257982713263386
To determine this experimentally, closed bone fracture (right lower leg) and/or soft-tissue trauma (2.5 cm midline laparotomy) were induced prior to hemorrhagic shock (mean arterial BP of 35  +/-  5 mm Hg for 90 min) in male C3H/HeN mice.	0.8043483960343536
All animals were killed at 72 h after initiation of the experiment and the spleens were collected aseptically.	0.4337680880690299
More significant depression of splenocyte IL-2 and IL-3 release occurred with the combined insult than after bony injury or tissue trauma alone with hemorrhage.	0.533299903797118
The present study suggests that different traumatic insults, i. e. bone fracture as well as soft-tissue trauma in conjunction with hemorrhagic shock, produce comparable depression of host immune function.	0.5700164452151106
Moreover, combination of closed bone fracture and soft-tissue trauma prior to hemorrhagic shock leads to even more compromised immunity.	0.5103261304861687
This indicates that different mechanisms of immune depression may be involved following soft-tissue trauma or bony injury coupled with hemorrhage.	0.4984248901711471
The markedly depressed immune function following bony injury, soft-tissue trauma and hemorrhagic shock may contribute to the increased susceptibility of severely injured patients to sepsis and the ensuing multiple organ failure in the clinical situation.	0.6817651548692044
In the management of acute major vessel occlusion, the use of fibrinolytic agents such as recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA), urokinase or streptokinase is widely accepted.	0.4796341635115878
Today, the spectrum of indications for thrombolytic drugs comprises acute myocardial infarction, lung embolism, ischaemic stroke, deep vein thrombosis and acute arterial occlusions of the lower limbs.	0.7142214473169484
In view of the histopathological and clinical features of retinal vessel occlusion, fibrinolysis aimed at early restoration of blood flow appears to be a promising therapeutic approach.	0.6732665180740404
Basically, it is of some concern that the systemic administration of fibrinolytic agents is associated with a haemorrhagic risk.	0.653076696542498
Since this includes cerebral haemorrhage or gastrointestinal bleeding, the choice of an appropriate intravenous thrombolytic therapy in a non-life threatening situation such as central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) or central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) should be based on minimising the risk of adverse events.	0.621734064711788
Furthermore, the fibrinolytic treatment of choice should be able to produce rapid and complete restoration of retinal capillary and arterial or venous blood flow and maintain patency long enough for retinal salvage to take place.	0.5869136834221089
In this article, we review several studies of fibrinolytic therapy in patients with retinal vessel occlusion to determine whether this treatment is likely to improve major clinical outcomes.	0.7399388036017013
Moreover, we review the large scale trials of fibrinolysis in myocardial infarction and acute ischaemic stroke to evaluate safety and efficacy of various thrombolytic regimens.	0.5829222630927644
Furthermore, we report on our results of fibrinolytic therapy with low dose rt-PA in patients with retinal artery occlusion and ischaemic central retinal vein occlusion.	0.8329728232052116
In light of the fact that the occurrence of bleeding complications constitutes a dose dependent problem, we conclude that the use of low dose regimens should be the ideal approach to fibrinolysis in retinal vessel occlusion.	0.6323619643608002
Although the results of our pilot studies must be interpreted with caution, we believe that the administration of low-dose rt-PA (50 mg) in a frontloaded manner ( = simultaneous administration of rt-PA and intravenous heparin) constitutes a reasonable treatment option in patients with central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) or ischaemic retinal vein occlusion (RVO), recent onset of symptoms (CRAO <= 12 h, RVO <= 11 d) and severe visual loss ( <= 20/50).	0.8203413924105277
Because of these limitations and the numerous contraindications of fibrinolytic therapy, only a limited number of patients will be suitable for this treatment.	0.7566041866671026
In view of the poor visual and ocular prognosis in severe retinal vessel occlusion, controlled clinical trials are needed to determine the benefit of thrombolysis in the management of this disease.	0.7028677604426528

infusion of 3 ampoules Prostavasin (60 µg PGE1) administered for either 1 or 2 h, once a day for 4 weeks.	0.6069471539351324
Primary variables were pain-free walking distance as well as safety, determined by the frequency of adverse events and the course of blood pressure.	0.67570748310604
The efficacy was comparable in the two groups.	0.45212690289214247
In the 1-h infusion group, the pain-free walking distance increased from 87 to 135 m, and in the 2-h group from 88 to 147 m, while the absolute walking distance increased from 124 to 200 m and from 147 to 238 m, respectively.	0.6870158142924672
The differences between the two groups were not significant, although an analysis of subgroups with initial pain-free walking distances of less than 80 m indicated a significant difference in favour of the 2-h PGE1 infusion (increase in walking distance 58 m as compared with 22 m).	0.6907956520516877
Course of blood pressure and frequency of adverse events were comparable in the two groups.	0.6881293117762637
Altogether, in intermittent claudication both the 1-h and the 2-h PGE1 infusion show comparably good results in terms of efficacy and safety.	0.677152649945732

The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) is the strongest ligament of the human knee joint.	0.7503709876806851
Its origin is at the lateral wall of the medial femoral condyle and the insertion is located in the posterior part of the intercondylar area.	0.7720029891285167
The posterior cruciate ligament consists of multiple small fiber bundles.	0.3350520215701611
From a functional point of view, one can differentiate fiber bundles with an anterior origin and fiber bundles with a posterior origin at the femur.	0.5800649065969065
The anterior fibers insert in the anterolateral part of the tibial insertion zone.	0.4756270228952553
These fibers become tense when the knee is flexed.	0.2115823691776287
The posterior fibers insert in the posteromedial part of the tibial insertion and become tense when the knee is extended.	0.47267105077560434
The main part of the posterior cruciate ligament consists of type I collagen positive dense connective tissue.	0.5632948957398055
The longitudinal fibrils of type I collagen are divided into small bundles by thin type III collagen positive fibrils.	0.41049596582467063
In the center of the middle third region, the structure of the tissue varies from the typical structure of a ligament.	0.703594768555488
In this region, the structure of the tissue resembles fibrocartilage.	0.7654102383853754
Oval-shaped cells surrounded by a metachromatic extracellular matrix lie between the longitudinal collagen fibrils.	0.38587622365183616
The femoral origin and the tibial insertion have the structure of chondral apophyseal enthesis.	0.525356939476746
Near the anchoring region at the femur and tibia there should be various mechanoreceptors which might have an important function for the kinematics of the knee joint.	0.5923830000969303
The blood supply of the PCL arises from the middle geniculate artery.	0.5804586557286618
The ligament is covered by a synovial fold where the terminal branches of the middle and the inferior geniculate artery form a periligamentous network.	0.5671960703103452
From the synovial sheath, the blood vessels penetrate the ligament in a transverse direction and anastomose with a longitudinally orientated intraligamentous network.	0.4914320412395356
The distribution of blood vessels within the PCL is not homogeneous.	0.489844736760495
We detected three avascular areas within the ligament: Both fibrocartilaginous entheses of the PCL are devoid of blood vessels.	0.42380922743604327
A third avascular zone is located in the central zone of fibrocartilage of the middle third region.	0.5083051387686955
Atrial reentrant tachycardias (ART) are a potentially life-threatening complication in survivors of congenital heart disease surgery.	0.6587839432366803
From July 1993 to December 1997, temporary transesophageal pacing was used to convert 29 tachycardia episodes in 19 patients.	0.48301096805526184
At the time of the first tachycardia episode, patients' ages were 1 month to 26 years (mean 9.8 yrs).	0.8279131843883442
Time from operation to onset of first tachycardia episode ranged from 1 day to 19 years.	0.4209539570991198
Onset was within the first 2 weeks postoperatively in 6 patients and occurred later in 13 patients (1 to 19 years after operation).	0.8122813908460789
Postoperative pacemaker implantation had been performed in 2 pts; 17 of 19 pts were receiving antiarrhythmic medication.	0.523729424527246
After placing a quadripolar transesophageal catheter, atrial and ventricular signals were recorded and atrial stimulation performed.	0.374882874830584
Atrial cycle length of tachycardia ranged from 160-380 ms with 1:1 to 4:1 AV conduction.	0.49405777557851366
Temporary transesophageal pacing was performed following an algorithm starting with 4 extrastimuli (20 ms below atrial cycle length of tachycardia).	0.45979333489274476
Tachycardia terminated in 27 of 29 cases (93%) without complications.	0.5609208008049578
In 3 cases, conversion was achieved by pacing after amiodarone 5 mg/kg i.v.	0.5428449614422661
After tachycardia conversion, sinus- or pacemaker rhythm was present in 20 cases.	0.6005024507558736
In 9 cases atrial fibrillation was recorded; spontaneous conversion to sinus rhythm occurred after a maximum of 3 min (7 cases) or persisted and required direct current cardioversion (2 cases).	0.7288698585830476
In conclusion, transesophageal atrial pacing is an effective, relatively noninvasive method for conversion of atrial reentrant tachycardias after operation for congenital heart disease.	0.507602631331222

When evaluating the literature according to the Utstein method, there were only 2 survivors (0.18%) out of 1,135 CPR attempts after trauma (Table 1).	0.6612292047185018
Differences in the study populations and levels of prehospital trauma care led us to analyse the results of a physician-staffed prehospital trauma care system in Cologne.	0.7056527815115278
From January 1987 to December 1990, a total of 49,054 emergency calls were registered using a standardised protocol.	0.5904932521145726
Among 9,595 trauma-related calls, 636 patients were found to be pulseless on arrival of the emergency team, 412 of these were pronounced dead.	0.5010136693640705
CPR was initiated in the remaining 224 patients, who comprise the study population (defined as 100%).	0.6592957508289815
All patients who were admitted to a hospital were followed using a second protocol.	0.7587245134185531
CPR in the field was successful in 68 (30.4%) patients, who were then admitted to a hospital; 42 of these died within the first 24 h. Four patients (1.8%) could be discharged from hospital alive and were still living 1 year later, 1 with a lasting neurological deficit (Fig.	0.8356928123004995
In 156 (69.6%) cases resuscitative attempts were unsuccessful in the field.	0.5702547782837364

Therapeutical options are directed either to strengthening the contraction up to an adequate magnitude or to lowering the voiding resistance or can be aimed at influencing both.	0.4109907767434979

Conservative methods should always be attempted before surgical procedures are performed.	0.4973126317388263
Depending on the degree of severity and the etiology of the disease, a combined therapy can be useful.	0.8674806096071469
In the case of resistance to therapy, intermittent autocatheterism is to be preferred to permanent deviation via an indwelling catheter.	0.5902235733394479
During long-term therapy of hyperuricaemia with allopurinol (300 mg/d) two patients developed generalized granuloma annulare.	0.5839237129457492
The diagnoses were confirmed by histology; concomitant diseases, especially diabetes mellitus, were not detectable.	0.7122229335639265

Intraarticular bleeding and muscle bleeding occur spontaneously or as a result of trauma in hemophilia A or B.	0.42943182610267544
The most common sites for hemarthrosis are the knees joints, elbows and ankles joints.	0.5057683017923471

Minor joint bleedings are treated by adequate factor substitution, temporarily non-weight bearing of the extremity, application of ice-packs and physical therapy.	0.5169288131066221

This is followed by a consequent physical therapy (joint and soft tissue techniques) and anti-inflammatory drugs.	0.6472108951251635
The goal is a sufficient muscular balance of the joint, the improvement of the coordination, and the proprioception.	0.8587810587783098

Local ice application, sytemic and local anti-inflammatory treatment support the physical therapy.	0.4225784557410775
Soft heel shock absorber, elastic and semi-rigid bandages prevent recurrent bleeding episodes by shock absorption and decrease of synovial impingement.	0.3337515661011515
Synovectomy is indicated in cases of chronic persistent synovitis.	0.5550351041398089
Radiosynoviorthesis (RSO), which is an alternative in certain cases, has been performed with great success in 12 cases in our hospital.	0.8093979501514558
In advanced arthropathy joint mobilization should be the emphasis of the physical therapy.	0.5115951081922648

A 72-year-old patient received 0.1 mg morphine by the intrathecal route and 2x1.5 mg midazolam as adjuvant therapy.	0.665037063103359
Severe respiratory depression and somnolence supervened 3.5 h later, which lasted over the next 24 h and necessitated intubation and mechanical ventilation.	0.6645178758441982
Continuous administration of >6 mg naloxone to antagonize the supposed effect of the morphine had no effect.	0.5025421796109645
The patient's condition was not normalized until a single dose of 0.3 mg flumazenil was administered.	0.7632446345786986
For the time being, especially in the case of elderly patients, we recommend that strict indications are adhered to when intrathecal administration of morphine is considered and that less than 0.1 mg morphine is given.	0.7748295301077283
Respiration should be monitored for quite some time.	0.3804882177209977
In contrast to the often debated NYHA classification, the determination of peak oxygen uptake (peak VO2) by cardiopulmonary exercise testing allows an objective assessment of the exercise capacity of patients with congestive heart failure (CHF).	0.6370676016806531
However, cardiopulmonary exercise testing is a time consuming and costly diagnostic tool, which requires sophisticated equipment and specially trained personell.	0.6359315332495192
Exercise capacity can also be determined by the 6 minute walk test.	0.5122226034936241
This test simply measures the distance covered by strong walking on a hallway level within 6 minutes.	0.381855555010967
The 6 minute walk test is a submaximal exercise test, which is associated with much smaller increments in heart rate, blood pressure and plasma catecholamines than cardiopulmonary exercise testing.	0.6569748555220242
It is characterized by a very small intraindividual variance.	0.5033738162576288
Furthermore, it can be easily performed and, due to low logistic and personal requirements, it is very cost effective.	0.6968986501446669
The results of the 6 minute walk test - as well as of cardiopulmonary exercise testing - are influenced by extracardial exercise-limiting disorders, such as pulmonary diseases.	0.6862928108105109
Independent from the etiology of CHF, the results of the 6 minute walk test are closely related to peak VO2.	0.6617508843881563
In serial exercise testing the distance covered within 6 minutes allow to predict the individual peak VO2.	0.49240265189745663
Like peak VO2 the 6 minute walk test has been shown to be a predictor of morbidity and mortality in CHF, with its predictive value being independent from left ventricular ejection fraction and other potential prognostic parameters.	0.645512477626671
In CHF patients a walking distance < 300 m is associated with a one-year-mortality of up to 50%, whereas the one-year-mortality in patients reaching a walking distance > 450 m amounts to only a few percent.	0.8457817015787332
In addition, the hospitalization rate of patients reaching a walking distance of < 300 m is several fold higher than in those with a walking distance >= 450 m. Like cardiopulmonary exercise testing, the 6 minute walk test allows to control the efficiency of specific treatments and to monitor the natural course of the disease.	0.7030427859802573
The 6 minute walk test is, thus, a cost effective alternative to cardiopulmonary exercise testing in CHF patients.	0.5720667936771253
However, neither the 6 minute walk test alone nor the results of cardiopulmonary exercise testing alone are sufficient for selecting patients, e.g., for cardiac transplantation, as each individual case requires a synopsis of all relevant facts and parameters.	0.6248699586193632
We report the first case of prurigo pigmentosa in the German literature.	0.7447308450926459

The effects of glycerol are discussed in detail.	0.4837646132238818
Glycerol can lead to a transition of crystalline lipid structures within the horny layer lipids into liquid crystalline states.	0.4227081616151203
Especially if applied in oil/water-emulsions it improves, the hydration of the horny layers better than urea.	0.4649302389226285
In addition, if facilitates the dissolution of desmosomes within the superior layers of the horny layer enhancing desquamation.	0.4782014326806055
Furthermore, by using glycerol, the mechanical properties of the skin can be influenced; long term used leads to increased elasticity.	0.8009360430992385
The roughness of the horny layer is reduced, which can be explained by the abrasive and/or the hydrating effect.	0.662291432528946
Glycerol used in o/w-emulsions also protects against the influence of tensides or noxious lipophilic agents.	0.3195839926514605
Presumably a flux from the base of the epidermis towards its surface triggers the regeneration of the barrier.	0.4596827093843364
Finally,  glycerol can lead - similarly to urea - to an improvement in active agent penetration, as has been proven for hexylnicotinate.	0.8426078820394304

Pathophysiologically, ARDS is characterized by pulmonary edema owing to injury of the capillary-alveolar membranes and increased pulmonary artery pressure.	0.46881357638198623
It is further distinguished by severe hypoxemia unresponsive to the usual methods of support for respiratory failure.	0.41341990099995046
Hypoxemia is caused by intrapulmonary right-to-left shunting due to to persistent perfusion of non-ventilated alveoli.	0.4129539118887678
Another characteristic feature in ARDS is the low thoracopulmonary compliance.	0.4216426362062515

Meanwhile more than 50.000 heart, 2500 heart-lung and 10.000 lung transplantations have been performed worldwide.	0.592836966591468
Improvements in patient selection as well as in the postoperative management have led to 1-year survival rates of 70-90%.	0.8428915255817521

In 188 out of 208 MF patients, at least one skin sample with sufficient DNA quality for PCR analysis was obtained.	0.539272987289182

In the remaining 66 cases, we performed two multiplex-PCRs, covering rearrangements of the other TCR genes.	0.7437274413369322

Metastasis formation is a multistep process that requires tumor cells to progress through many different stages.	0.41774115558165986
One of the first steps is a disturbance of the epithelial integrity through a decrease in intercellular homotypic adhesion.	0.7462152334053884
Proteolysis of the extracellular matrix, as well as increased locomotion, leads to intravasation and dissemination of the tumor cells.	0.6044279285702597
In the target organs metastasizing cells adhere to the endothelium, extravasate and form metastases.	0.3759263531162118
Finally, neoangiogenesis is required for the initiation as well as the growth of the metastases, providing the tumor cells with both nutritive agents and growth factors.	0.7322449602083348
This leads to the conclusion that anti-proteolytic and anti-angiogenic substances could provide effective therapeutic approaches for the control of metastatic growth.	0.5391932589087323

Type I and type II diabetes are the most common types of diabetes.	0.7957868795808443
The ratio of type I to type II diabetes is about 1:9.	0.6300781987155503
Type I diabetes is caused by an absolute insulin deficiency and is therefore referred to as insulin-dependent diabetes.The disease becomes manifest clinically in childhood or adolescence ("juvenile diabetes"), although manifestation in adulthood is being increasingly observed.	0.6408744958234734
Morphologically, a subtotal ( > 80 %) to total loss of beta cells in the pancreatic islets occurs.	0.7973513857404284
Lymphocytic insulitis, which disappears after the beta cells have been totally destroyed, is pathognomonic of type I diabetes.	0.6216190343946029
This insulitis is an expression of an autoimmune event that is triggered by a multitude of factors.	0.4494916357213738
An important factor appears to be a genetic predisposition (HLA DR3/DR4/DQ8) in connection with as yet unknown environmental factors (e. g., viruses).	0.6131007038023757
Autoantibodies, such as islet cell cytoplasmic antibodies (ICA), insulin autoantibodies (IAA), and/or autoantibodies to the GABA-synthesizing enzyme glutamic acid carboxylase (GAD), are already detectable in a prediabetic phase, although it is not possible to predict the time of clinical manifestion.	0.6142727148244538
The course of the disease is dependent on age.	0.9380295213114597
Young children require insulin therapy sooner than juveniles or adults.	0.23999469297932147

The prevalence of this disorder in 4-6 year old children is 0.7%.	0.7997726271692205
Leading clinical sign in 90% of patients is habitual snoring, but this is rather nonspecific, as 60% of patients investigated for habitual snoring do not have OSAS.	0.8869329137327964
Other signs such as daytime sleepiness, failure to thrive, profuse nocturnal sweating or mouth breathing are equally nonspecific.	0.33105193040419656

A follow-up study of the first 33 patients with a follow-up time of 3.5 years on average showed a good subjective result in 79 % of the patients.	0.9974026111624946
In patients younger than 20 years of age, however, the result was good in 87.5 % of cases.	0.7204330802739236
The reason for the better results in young patients is that in older patients the origin of the pain is often not the pars defect, but the degeneration of the intervertebral disk.	0.8662502803291509
Direct repair of spondylolysis is therefore indicated when pain persists after 6 months of conservative treatment or there is a progressive olisthesis of not more than 10 mm.	0.6474516091131244
After the end of growth an MRI study of the intervertebral discs should show whether there is degeneration or not.	0.5888315132303091
Direct repair is indicated only in the absence of disc degeneration.	0.5915306220254773
After the age of 25 years this procedure should not be carried out.	0.6099922630972809

Over the next few weeks, however, a relapse of the eruption and the ulcerations occurred.	0.6015020108391526

The clinical features and the immunological findings led to the diagnosis of toxic and allergic contact dermatitis to jellyfish venom.	0.6564561677857069
First aid and secondary treatment of jellyfish injuries are suggested.	0.31306046458496867

Problems in the specification of indications and in the estimation of the effective sample size cannot be solved by the inclusion of mixed populations but require the establishment of development programs.	0.5849384540782685
Further crucial points are the appropriate choice of control and the identical concomittant treatment and observation of the groups to be compared.	0.5350164415499902
Technical mistakes as imprecise definitions, arbitrary decisions during the course or at termination of a trial, unclear responsibilities or an unscheduled flow of information can be avoided if these potential problems are anticipated in the trial protocol.	0.55588953584154
A prospective approach that anticipates problems at the time the study protocol is drafted is preferable to a reluctant reactive approach during the course of the trial.	0.6078881528533281

The operative realignment of mechanical axis deviations (MAD) is necessary to prevent early joint degeneration and to reach normal load-bearing.	0.562934672865419
Modern types of external fixation systems allow an alignment of the mechanical axis to exact degrees.	0.46640308229216504
Predominantly this are corrections of angular deformities.	0.24297500549376502
In some cases the analysis of the MAD does not show any angular deformity, but a parallel staggering of the mechanical axis lines of a bone.	0.7196679009156186
Such parallel staggering of the mechanical axis lines is defined as a translation deformity of the bone.	0.5698635793535956
In combined deformities with angulation and translation the centre of deformity can be established proximal or distal out of the limit of the bone.	0.5637956002919381
In translation deformities the realignment of the mechanical axis requires a parallel re-staggering made by a translation-osteotomy or by a counterangulated double osteotomy.	0.4294797796886546
In complex deformities with angulation and translation, the translation requires a separate corrective planning.	0.4591877447292136
By using external fixator systems to perform acute or progressive corrective osteotomies the position of the Axis of Correction of Angulation (ACA) in relation to the n-CORA of the deformity has to be considered.	0.6405394878083276
If ACA position is not conform with the n-CORA position relevant geometric effects in relation of length and translation occur.	0.4190700102077897
These geometric effects to corrective osteotomies can be calculated by using simple trigonometric formulas or graphical methods.	0.35490673941975903
Possibilities to compensate translation and length effects are shown by using unilateral external fixator systems.	0.4364196528215765

Necrotizing pancreatitis is still associated with considerable morbidity and mortality.	0.4812438698927774
Formerly, surgical treatment with early and extensive pancreatic resection has been the standard.	0.8068737968669265
Improvements in our understanding of the pathogenesis of the disease and progress in the field of intensive care therapy have made conservative therapy the initial standard in the treatment of necrotizing pancreatitis.	0.7585063798384077
A considerable percentage of patients with sterile necrosis can be managed with low morbidity and mortality by conservative treatment without operation.	0.7711272448258513
Nevertheless, surgical treatment is indicated in patients with infected necrosis and in sterile necrosis if multiorgan failure persists over a limited period of time despite maximum intensive care therapy.	0.702995824559761
Pancreatic resection should be abandoned for surgical treatment of pancreatic necrosis, as results with regard to morbidity, mortality and long-term outcome are unsatisfactory.	0.7911268255574984
Today the surgical standard is careful digital necrosectomy, which must be followed by either postoperatve drainage, repeated open lavage or continuous closed lavage.	0.5059208339033706
In experienced hands, all three procedures provide similar results with regard to morbidity and mortality.	0.5654553533025618

This can be achieved by means of prospective long-term observation of the patient with regular documentation of clinical, radiological, biochemical and functional data using certain validated scoring methods (DAS, radiological score, ADL score Hanover or Health assessment questionnaire, SF36, etc.).	0.632563367688645
Long-term observation and documentation including radiographs have been performed in the rheumatology hospital in Ratingen for 20 years without even knowing the term quality management.	0.5432357611362996
Quality management in a hospital for rheumatic diseases begins with certain structural prerequisites: possibility of direct admission of a patient to the hospital by the family physician, outpatient clinic to investigate and to follow patients over a long period of time, multidisciplinary team with specialists in rheumatology, orthopedic surgery, physiotherapy, ergotherapy, special care, psychological, and social services, close cooperation with specialists in neurology, dermatology, ophthalmology, etc., department of radiology, special laboratory, facilities for internal diagnostics and treatment.	0.6595276652808063
The hospital needs a training program for the qualification of rheumatologists and orthopaedic surgeons.	0.3405405015736923
The hospital staff should closely cooperate with the doctors in private practice who admit patients and should continously support patient organizations.	0.41491250896815135
The quality of outcome is influenced by the process quality which depends on the following factors: selection, training and motivation of the hospital staff; supervision of clinical assessment and documentation by senior physicians, daily x-ray demonstrations and case reports, interdisciplinary case demonstrations at least every week in addition to daily consultation, team reports, regular education including review of actual literature for physicians, education programs exchanging knowledge with physiotherapists and nurses, and regular education programs for patients.	0.6021933996243453
Process quality can only be achieved by an interdisciplinary approach and regular communication between all participants including the patient, whose opinion must be noted and regarded.	0.5952753593373319
As far as possible, the same doctor who treats the patient in the hospital should follow her/him in the outpatient clinic.	0.708248976244819
The quality of outcome can be improved by regular reinvestigation of the patient with control of medication, side effects, efficacy, documentation of clinical, biochemical, radiological, and functional data.	0.7485443406103199
Decisions for further treatment have to be based on these follow-up data.	0.7216455882890952
A standardized follow up and documentation system for all rheumatology units with prompt feedback could definitely improve the quality of rheumatologic care in Germany.	0.4134586982139459

There is controversy about the amount and relevance of postoperative CO2 resorption.	0.4627352941885458
Without continuous postoperative monitoring, after laparoscopic cholecystectomy a certain risk may consist in unnoticed hypercapnia due to CO2 resorption.	0.4526763272949413
Studies exist on the course of end-expiratory CO2 (PeCO2) alone over a longer postoperative period of time in extubated patients during spontaneous breathing.	0.5708661404236478
The goal of this prospective study was to investigate the amount of CO2 resorbed from the abdominal cavity in the postoperative period by means of CO2 metabolism.	0.701174295101753
After giving informed consent to the study, which was approved by the local ethics committee, 20 patients underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy.	0.8327344168682188
All patients received general endotracheal anaesthesia.	0.44339291913297574
After induction, total IV anaesthesia was maintained using fentanyl, propofol, and atracurium.	0.623208962109224
Patients were ventilated with oxygen in air (FiO2 0.4).	0.5289634484060535
The intraabdominal pressure during the surgical procedure ranged from 12 to 14 mm Hg.	0.4895943247282025
Thirty minutes after releasing the capnoperitoneum (KP), CO2 elimination (V.CO2), oxygen uptake (V.O2), and respiratory quotient (RQ) were measured every minute for 1 h by indirect calorimetry using the metabolic monitor Deltatrac according to the principle of Canopy.	0.6244999913311262
Assuming an unchanged metabolism, the CO2 resorption (V.CO2) at any given time (t) can be calculated from V.CO2 (t)=V.CO2 (t)-RQ (preop) V.O2 (t).	0.7792006997634006
It was thus necessary to define the patient's metabolism on the day of operation.	0.6930555099586102
The first data were collected before surgery and after introduction of the arterial and venous cannulae for a 15-min period.	0.694541004663877
Measuring point 0 was determined after exsufflation of the KP and emptying of the remaining CO2 via manual compression by the surgeon at the end of surgery.	0.5230471757936089
Patient's tracheas were extubated and metabolic monitoring started 30 min after release of the KP for 60 min.	0.4733188659190974
Simultaneously, a nasal side-stream capnometry probe was placed and the PeCO2 and respiratory frequency (RF) were obtained by the Capnomac Ultima (Datex) and registered every minute as well.	0.6079186888452558
Values were averaged over four periods of 15 min each.	0.35322879226863085
An arterial blood gas sample was drawn at the end of every 15-min period.	0.5157961020793891
Postoperative pain was scored by a visual analog scale and completed by a subjective index questionnaire on general well-being.	0.47469044047185455
All data were analysed by the Friedman or Wilcoxon test; P<0.05 was considered significant.	0.47593478733531974
The findings do not indicate CO2 resorption in the postoperative period after laparoscopic cholecystectomy (Tables 2 and 3, Fig.	0.6686850072470351
Arterial CO2 as well as PeCO2 were elevated postoperatively (45 mm Hg vs. 36 mm Hg intraoperatively), while V.CO2 and V.O2 were unchanged when compared to the preoperative measuring period.	0.654345363658675
The postoperative RF was comparable to preoperative values.	0.41272632412133475
Calculated CO2 was lower than 10 ml/min and within accuracy of measurements.	0.7227023549674296
The postoperative pain index ranged between 3 and 4, and 3.75 - 15 mg piritramid was administered.	0.835088474088484
All patients feld tired immediately after the operation, but scores improved slightly at the end of the 60-min period of metabolic monitoring.	0.583517238561175
There is no significant resorption of CO2 from the abdominal cavity later than 30 min after releasing the KP.	0.6165499524934102
Up to this time, any CO2 remaining in the abdominal cavity after careful emptying by the surgeon has been resorbed and exhaled.	0.5648194461214079

The clinically (C1) and sonographically (C2) evaluated pretherapeutic stages were compared to the postoperative histopathologic tumor classifications.	0.5926122084428199

The sonographic staging was apparently superior with the T-classifications correct in 92.3 %, high in 7.7 %, low 0.0 %.	0.6342284974727493
The N-stages were correct in 89.6 %, high in 9.2 %, low in 1.2 %.	0.7123146749546692

For determination of training intensity, a VO2 between 40 and 70% of peak VO2 and/or training heart rate between 60 and 80% of peak heart rate was used.	0.7104283595517767
There was also a wide range for frequency (between 3 and 7 times per week) and duration of training (between 20 and 60 min per session).	0.7540786862445064
For aerobic exercise training only continuous training methods were applied.	0.32361985458086795
We have developed a new interval training method which allows intense exercise stimuli on peripheral muscles with minimal cardiac strain.	0.4006306327674591
After only three weeks of training, the improvement in aerobic capacity was similar to that reported after longer training periods using continuous methods.	0.575876324243314
To determine work rate for work phases of interval training, a special steep ramp test was developed.	0.46096373149934405
By analysis of acute physical responses to this testing procedure and to the interval training, both were proven to be tolerable in CHF patients, even if their ejection fraction is as low as 13%, or peak cardiac index not greater than 1.6 l/m2/min, and peak VO2 less than 8.5 ml/kg/min.	0.761002865992181

Small (T1) and exophytic (T1, T2) tumors are suitable for radiotherapy.	0.5544971866171158
Limited lesions (T1, T2) can be cured by functional endoscopic resection techniques or external partial laryngectomies.	0.4278848913468054
Extensive tumors (large T2; T3) are treated by total laryngectomy or by primary irradiation, especially in the case of a good response to induction chemotherapy.	0.6954622233981711

Induced hypotension is defined as a reduction in mean arterial blood pressure to 50-60 mm Hg in normotensive subjects.	0.7395613602677945
The aim of induced hypotension is to decrease intraoperative blood loss, decrease the need for blood transfusions and improve operating conditions.	0.65950150817776
Most studies indicate that induced hypotension can decrease intraoperative blood loss by 50% in many surgical procedures; however, some studies report that blood loss is not significantly reduced.	0.664829842856521
Current methods of induced hypotension are based on the use of rapid and short-acting vasodilators as primary agents (nitroprusside, nitroglycerine, urapidil), supplemented by volatile anesthetics (isoflurane) and/or -blockers (esmolol) to improve effect, reduce dosage and prevent side effects (reflex tachycardia, tachyphylaxis, rebound hypertension).	0.5861319622276449
Proper positioning of the patient and controlled ventilation aid in reducing blood loss.	0.7135404090016416
Major risks of induced hypotension are a reduction in blood flow (i.e.	0.6086041897207453
ischaemia) of vital organs (brain, myocardium) and elevation of intracranial pressure in neurosurgical patients.	0.7564371678710637
Thus, major contraindications of induced hypotension are severe coronary artery disease, hypertension combined with arteriosclerosis of cerebral vessels and increased intracranial pressure in patients with cerebral disease.	0.6460748547982176
Complications are rare in otherwise healthy patients, but may be higher in elderly patients and those with underlying organ dysfunction.	0.8457689856969258
Therefore, careful assessment and selection of patients, together with consideration of the potential complications, appropriate choice of drugs and invasive beatby-beat monitoring, are essential for the safe practice of induced hypotension.	0.6645977359134223
Abstract  Empirical results stemming from infant research have contributed extensively to the understanding of coping with psychosocial stress and vulnerability for psychosomatic symptoms in later life.	0.4091563161734543
The interaction and the emotional exchange between caregiver and child in the first months of life lead to representations of interactions that will be the base for the quality of attachment.	0.5486701444714965
The mutual regulation of the caregiver-infant-pair enables the child to acquire a psychic capacity to regulate physiological requirements.	0.3922912825766356
This selfregulatory function determines the potential of the later adult to react to distress - in a symbolic way using words or more in a somatic way by developing psychosomatic symptoms.	0.6320290387285497
First experiences with the treatment of psychosomatic patients with respect to the new findings about self-regulation are reported.	0.5878586070590239
A 31-year-old pregnant woman had to undergo emergency abdominal surgery due to acute intestinal obstruction.	0.4820542265913774
The patient's preoperative history demonstrated multiple allergies as well as abdominal trauma several years before.	0.5925773334768357
The physical examination - including sonography of the two fetuses - showed no pathological signs.	0.9145974876160455
Anaesthesia was induced intravenously with the operating table tilted to the left side, using routine precautions pre-oxygenation, and rapid sequence intubation, and was maintained unproblematically.	0.8232723232266714
About 20 min after the onset of surgery, hypotension, tachycardia, and a drop in oxygen saturation appeared.	0.7606258068420354
Volume substitution and the application of vasoactive drugs failed to stabilise the haemodynamic situation.	0.3957590102539147
Elevation of the pregnant uterus and increased left tilzing of the operating table did not lead to improvement.	0.48945695194463185
The development of eyelid edema led to the diagnosis of an anaphylactic reaction.	0.593694085462287
The patient was treated successfully with epinephrine, antihistamines, and corticosteroids (prednisolone).	0.6732429258895322
The suspicion of latex-related allergy was verified postoperatively by radio-allergen-sorbent test (RAST) and prick and scratch tests.	0.4354393106995743
The mean arterial blood pressure is decreased during the first two trimesters of pregnancy and increases to preconceptional values during the last weeks of gestation.	0.7105305738574127
The heart rate increases during the whole course of pregnancy.	0.4460191356682967
During late gestation fewer patients show an increase in diastolic blood pressure and heart rate in the standing position.	0.44585319492536285
A fall in heart rate was only seen in this period.	0.7300300203953453
A fall in mean arterial blood pressure during standing is not related to the blood pressure in the supine position during the whole course of pregnancy.	0.5741253237544552
The hypotensive symptoms are twice as frequent during early pregnancy compared to late pregnancy.	0.3184555981660565
Headaches, fatigue and cold extremities are the most usual complaints.	0.5523449975610666
The frequency and intensity of these three symptoms decrease during gestation.	0.5939288486282349
Blood pressure in the supine position is reduced in symptomatic pregnant women.	0.4035948403247024
However, the occurrence of these symptoms is not correlated to the fall in blood pressure in the standing position.	0.6947444482301471
The Birth-weight is not influenced by blood pressure in the supine position, but depends on the fall in blood pressure during standing.	0.6007314034387858
Pregnant women with a more pronounced fall in blood pressure give birth to newborns with a lower birthweight.	0.6064200047306617
These results imply a hitherto unknown cause of intrauterine growth restriction.	0.3537177906425481
The combination of saltwater baths and subsequent ultraviolet irradiation is an effective treatment for psoriasis and atopic dermatitis.	0.5327913018694135
The aim of the present study was to determine the photosensitizing properties of two commercially available bath salts, original salt from the Dead Sea and sodium chloride.	0.5216683498035689
To address this issue, test areas on the volar aspects of the forearms were soaked with salt solutions for 15 minutes prior to ultraviolet-B (UVB) irradiation.	0.4549588085782087
The salt concentrations tested were 1%, 3% 5% and 15%.	0.8093838539913305
Tap water followed by UVB and UVB alone served as controls.	0.262282904411666
Erythema was determined by visual and photometric measurement, and delayed tanning was assessed by colorimetry.	0.6180537440258743
Erythema obtained by wetting the skin prior to UVB irradiation was more pronounced than erythema induced by UVB alone.	0.3929267040326718
The most prominent erythema was yielded by tap water+UVB.	0.4168320643626898
The salts had a differing photosensitizing capacity and the strongest erythema was produced by the 5% solutions.	0.4661295933009555
There was only a moderate influence on delayed tanning by bathing the skin prior to irradiation.	0.4278588628214196
The results from the present study indicate that soaking the skin with salt solutions or tap water increases skin sensitivity to subsequent UVB irradiation.	0.5797859023743002
This may contribute to the effectiveness of salt water baths followed by UV irradiation and may account for an increased sunburn risk after bathing.	0.44363206204574196

Cor triatriatum dexter is a rare congenital malformation in which a membrane divides the right atrium into two chambers.	0.712162277397354
The membrane represents a persistence of the right sinus venosus valve (RSV).	0.4791475153077465
Normally the RSV regresses between the 9th and 15th week of gestation, as the cephalic portion forms the crista terminalis and the caudal portion develops into the Eustachian and Thebesian valve.	0.46515415440772623
Any failure in the regression process may result in remnants of RSV as a simple muscle bar, a Chiari-network or a fenestrated or unfenestrated membrane (cor triatriatum dexter).	0.4359280044878629

Apoptosis and proliferation are important regulators of normal development and homeostasis in the bone marrow.	0.5099023025891916
Therefore, dynamics of hematopoiesis is mainly defined by these two parameters.	0.4570191699374567
However, since only few data are available from previous studies, we performed a retrospective analysis to elucidate some aspects of this complex pathomechanism.	0.9025157808672304
A total of 400 patients with chronic myeloproliferative disorders (CMPDs) and corresponding reactive bone marrow lesions were enrolled into this study.	0.664716894748611

Furthermore, by determination of the proliferating-cell nuclear antigen labeling (PCNA) index, we were able to calculate the proportion of cells in the G2/M phase, because both nuclear antigens are expressed in different phases of the cell cycle.	0.6737152407370723
Patients with IMF, PV, and ET revealed a normal range of apoptosis, whereas in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) a significant increase could be observed.	0.7491117717954152
On the other hand, IMF and PV were characterized by a raised proliferative activity.	0.3879642196418084
Dynamics of hematopoiesis was assessed by calculation of the so called hematopoietic turnover index.	0.5717679304781432
In CML and reactive lesions no alterations of this parameter were detectable, but IMF and PV showed a significant increase.	0.6545974244770391
Survival analysis disclosed a relevant worsening of life expectancy for patients with reduced apoptosis and proliferation.	0.5390962929079984
In conclusion, our in-situ results confirm and extend previous experimental data on hematopoietic cell kinetics.	0.5084069096090464
In this context, a greater regenerative capacity of hematopoiesis may be reflected by an increased rate of apoptosis and/or proliferation and therefore is associated with a more favorable outcome.	0.7152825940720136

We inserted a 3-D endoscope into a jet laryngoscope and studied the pressure properties at the tip of the laryngoscope as well as intrapulmonary pressures while applying superimposed high-frequency jet ventilation.	0.5184539947368704
The studies were conducted initially using a lung simulator, and then in seven patients undergoing microlaryngeal surgery.	0.6151640745817476
Due to the rather large 3-D endoscope, the diameter of the jet laryngoscope was reduced by between 25.2% and 70.9%, depending on its size.	0.7689076957414611
The measurements on the lung simulator revealed that reduction of laryngoscope diameter leads to an increase in the following parameters: expiratory resistance, tidal volume, and peak inspiratory pressure.	0.658796786587982
The mean FiO2 was 0.74 +/- 0.1; the mean paO2 was 169.2 +/- 80.4 mm Hg; and the mean paCO2 was 40.9 +/- 2.4 mm Hg.	0.7716504129705449
The mean airway pressure was 19 +/- 5.3 mm Hg prior to insertion of the endoscope and 12.3 +/- 6.9 mm Hg after insertion.	0.7507718270811962
The mean positive end-expiratory pressure values increased from 2 +/- 0.6 to 3.6 +/- 2.3 mm Hg.	0.7893158419888346
Reduction of the working pressure resulted in restoration of the initial inspiratory pressures and tidal volumes.	0.573299392779565
