The advent of cytogenetic and molecular investigations of lipomatous neoplasms has contributed to a better understanding of the biology of these neoplasms and led to a modification of conventional classification schemes.	0.4701097669947927
The intracranial space is divided into two large compartments by the tentorium.	0.4928629087440116
The hydrostatic pressure of spinal fluid is responsible for buoyancy of the brain within these compartments.	0.5135645582005822
In patients with craniectomy this equilibrium is exposed to atmospheric pressure.	0.4008162750293378
We report on four cases of reversible herniation after either bilateral or unilateral decompressive craniectomy performed for increased intracranial pressure (ICP) and failure of conservative ICP treatment.	0.5432860046277624
All four patients had survived a severe neurological disease (encephalitis, subdural haematoma, stroke) which required craniectomy to control raised ICP.	0.569264391405802
All were successfully weaned from the ventilator and awake and CT scans showed no space-occupying lesion anymore.	0.46987810734168994
The patients showed a typical "sunken pattern" at the trepanation site.	0.6688989681782441
All patients developed clinical signs of transtentorial herniation (i.e.	0.38666876972929326
unilateral dilated pupils, deteriorated alertness, and extensor posturing) shortly after either diagnostic or presumed therapeutic lumbar puncture.	0.41891364285165517
One patient developed herniation a second time while in the typical 30 ° upright position.	0.5159407761249346
After craniectomy, transtentorial herniation is possible even in the absence of increased ICP.	0.4228658866874295
It is related to a negative gradient between atmospheric and intracranial pressure, which is enhanced by changes in the CSF compartment following lumbar puncture.	0.6687339868473984
Lumbar puncture should be avoided if possible and, when necessary, only be performed in the head-down position.	1.0025646525678342
Acute therapy in these cases is quite simple; it requires flat or even head-down positioning and early cranioplasty.	0.5747450399212782
Diseases of the oral cavity, floor of the mouth, and nervous system can be accompanied by disturbances in tongue movement during swallowing.	0.5083406345538394
These disturbances can be diagnosed by videosonography whereby the examiner has to evaluate extensive video documentation of lingual motion.	0.4699936783380719
It was the aim of this study to facilitate this evaluation by the application of a reproducible computer-assisted quantitative analysis procedure.	0.706046413500829
Video sequences of 56 healthy adults and 19 patients with dysphagias of different etiologies were analysed.	0.5078734406836222
A numerical estimation of swallowing movements was carried out in abstraction from the structures imaged (bolus, air, muscles of the tongue, floor of the mouth, hyoid, etc.).	0.4785544675480644
Intensity changes of the pixels within previously defined radial image sectors were quantified in relationship to time and depicted as sector curves.	0.36743805162857257
The healthy adults demonstrated a characteristic pattern of two motion maxima that appeared within almost all sector curves.	0.3752372638489283
These maxima represented bolus transport movements and the reset movement of the tongue.	0.4052847087915977
Patients with diseases of the tongue or neuromuscular changes caused by disturbances of the central nervous system showed pathological deviations on videosonography.	0.5310517267170685
These appeared as local or general reductions in movement, slow speed motions, repetitive swallowing or unsorted additional movements of the tongue during swallowing.	0.4617823213110263
Clinically-used ketamine is a racemic mixture of two isomers, S-(+)- and R-(-)-ketamine.	0.7852383385870056
Previous investigations showed the anaesthetic potency of S-(+)-ketamine to be three times higher than that of R-(-)-ketamine.	0.7748504449437275
It was the aim of this study to compare the effects of S-(+)-ketamine and racemic ketamine on endocrine and cardiovascular parameters, recovery, and side effects in geriatric patients during total intravenous anaesthesia (TIVA) for orthopaedic surgery.	0.7216684530221927
Forty patients over 60 years of age scheduled for elective hip or knee replacement were investigated in a double-blind, randomised design.	0.5888775232093564
For induction of TIVA, patients received 0.1 mg midazolam, 0.5 mg atropine, 1 mg/kg S(+)-ketamine or 2 mg/kg racemic ketamine, respectively, 2 mg vecuronium, and 1.5 mg/kg suxamethonium.	0.9100858164028955
After intubation and relaxation with a total dose of 0.1 mg/kg vecuronium, a continuous infusion of 2 mg/kg per hour S-(+)- or 4 mg/kg per hour racemic ketamine was administered throughout surgery.	0.7518083877988148
Blood samples were taken through a central venous catheter at seven time-points, before induction as well during and after surgery, until the 1st postoperative morning for analysis of adrenaline, noradrenaline (by high-pressure liquid chromatography with electrochemical detection), anti-diuretic hormone (ADH), adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), cortisol (by radioimmunoassay), glucose, and lactate.	0.5817898124667598
In addition, systolic arterial pressure (SAP), heart rate (HR), and arterial oxygen saturation were measured, and the time intervals between the end of ketamine infusion and the return of consciousness and orientation were protocolled.	0.6795330542271765
The incidence and assessment of dreams and other side effects were reported by the patients.	0.7113949726366531
Biometric data of the groups were comparable, the mean age of both groups being 68 years.	0.8338519198159172
Plasma adrenaline, noradrenaline, ADH, ACTH, cortisol, and glucose as well as SAP and HR increased significantly (P<0.05) during the course of anaesthesia.	0.5543060060267018
The influence on lactate levels was not significant.	0.47153970686046076
There were no differences between S-(+)- and racemic ketamine with respect to these parameters.	0.7122920589305661
Three patients in the ketamine-racemate group showed severe arterial hypertension and were withdrawn from the study.	0.5616785850144309
Recovery clearly improved after administration of S-(+)-ketamine compared to the racemate.	0.6334267984304434
Simple orders were followed after 2.0 +/- 3.4 versus 4.9 +/- 6.8 min (P=0.07), orientation with respect to person returned after 5.7 +/- 4.0 versus 14.6 +/- 10.0 min (P<0.001) and spatial orientation after 8.2 +/- 5.4 versus 17.4 +/- 9.7 min (P<0.001).	0.7556283656233052
After racemic ketamine, 1 patient remembered a negative dream and 1 patient a positive dream.	0.6413241688099407
In the S-(+)-group, 1 positive dream was reported.	0.6029508399187323
No intraoperative awareness was reported, and all patients would accept the same anaesthesia again.	0.5640051184476718
Increases in cardiovascular parameters and insufficient reduction of the stress response with respect to ADH, ACTH, and cortisol seem to require a more potent hypnotic element during TIVA with ketamine.	0.5185824977628781
With regard to endocrine and cardiovascular parameters, the pharmacodynamic effects of racemic and S-(+)-ketamine were comparable.	0.6001523979070249
Because of the significant improvement in recovery and the reduced quantitative drug load, S-(+)-ketamine offers a clinical advantage compared with currently used racemic ketamine.	0.5967210547092735
The closure of large circular defects on the scalp is technically difficult and cosmetically often not satisfying, if a free transplant is necessary.	0.5340128490854851
Following the technique of Tillmann described first in 1908, several flaps shaped like a windmill can be combined.	0.4833007020837294
We report on 14 patients (ages 41-88 years) where large defects resulting from the excision of various tumors (5 melanomas, 5 basal cell carcinomas, 1 keratoacanthoma, 1 trichilemmal cyst, 1 squamous cell carcinoma, 1 skin metastasis) were successfully closed by this method.	0.7846664213016205
The diameter of the defect ranged between 4 and 8 cm (mean 5,7 cm).	0.7346089070954552
Size and number of the rotating flaps (3 or 4) was varied according to the size of the defect and the mobility of the surrounding tissue.	0.8089318058582444
The procedure was performed with local anesthesia in all cases.	0.895120484060505
Wound healing occurred without complications except in 3 cases.	0.4579087945581315
2 patients (63 years, 70 years) developed small necrotic areas on the tips of the flaps.	0.5834963662293758
In a 74 year old man with a very large defect of 8 cm diameter, one flap of four underwent total necrosis.	0.6034832725131141
The cosmetic result was rated "very good" in 71,4% and "good" in 14,3%.	0.7475742086155593
The preservation of the terminal hair turned out to be of special advantage.	0.6447788696995447
The "windmill procedure" is an important addition to the surgical approaches for closure of large defects on the scalp, particularly in young patients.	0.8376577965215259

Hearing aids have fundamental disadvantages: (1) stigmatization of the patient; (2) the sound is often found to be unsatisfactory due to the limited frequency range and undesired distortion; (3) in many patients, the ear canal fitting device generally necessary leads to an occlusion effect; (4) acoustic feedback when amplification is high.	0.7335986051291026
Conventional hearing aids transmit sound into the ear canal via a small microphone.	0.43586353343007744
Sound has the disadvantage of requiring high output sound pressure levels for its transmission.	0.3651328806897968
This along with the necessary miniaturization of the loudspeaker as well as the resonances and reflections in the closed ear canal contribute to the disadvantages mentioned.	0.503188445661421
In contrast, implantable hearing aids do not make sound signals but micromechanical vibrations.	0.4040350263147644
An implantable hearing aid has an electromechanical transducer instead of the loudspeaker of a conventional hearing aid.	0.4944168041199836
The hearing signal does not leave the transducer as sound but as a mechanical vibration which is directly coupled to the auditory system bypassing the air.	0.3935846515794825
This implantable hearing aid is either coupled to the tympanic membrane, the ossicular chain, the perilymph of the inner ear, or the skull.	0.7715974004514983
Corneal cells are known to participate in the regulation of local inflammatory processes by secretion of cytokines.	0.4907137459767293

For the majority of patients with sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) many available hearing aids often do not achieve satisfactory results.	0.4767360324932951
For these patients partially implantable hearing devices have been developed, allowing distortion-free hearing and speech intelligibility that may be superior to conventional hearing aids.	0.6348691875682116
The external parts of partial implants, however, may result in a patient's stigmatization.	0.7597707451588555
Furthermore, they do not use the acoustic properties of the external auditory canal.	0.7213767663157524
Recently, we published the successful development of the first totally implantable hearing device for the treatment of SNHL (HNO 46 [1998] 853-863).	0.5969563048934525
Here we report the first implantations of this unique, totally implantable electronic hearing system in patients with SNHL: Implex TICA LZ 3001.	0.5596351652551997
The implant microphone is implanted subcutaneously in the outer ear canal near the ear drum.	0.3806998403614623
The signal is processed by a digitally programmable multichannel audioprocessor located subcutaneously on the bony skull behind the ear.	0.29585202951233824
A piezoelectric transducer is coupled to the body of the incus and drives the ossicular chain by vibratory actions.	0.4460031638439429
Energy is provided by an implantable battery.	0.4361534187426504
Implanted patients describe hearing as being distortion-free and transparent.	0.44075947398323584
Speech intelligibility and the hearing of music are improved.	0.30011809412176405
Patients may achieve better speech discrimination, especially in the presence of background noise.	0.5398433731420028
The aid can be used during sports, including swimming.	0.7865722392832183
To our knowledge, this is the first report of the implantation of a totally implantable electronic hearing system in patients.	0.6434924801768193
These results encourage further implantations of the totally implantable hearing system in the course of an ongoing clinical study.	0.5649367559105001

The current increase in the cost of health care must be considered as a severe threat to the prehospital emergency services system.	0.7242026572043577
Two examples have been selected - the patient with polytrauma and the patient in cardiac arrest - to demonstrate the dilemma between a need for objective data and the requirements of emergency patients.	0.9954685006107953
Study results obtained in trauma patients indicating that total prehospital time, including scene time, is correlated to patient outcome have led to the conclusion that at the scene treatment by emergency physicians may be dispensable.	0.7175039256703378
It has, however also been demonstrated that the time required for medical treatment at the scene is equivalent to 20% of the total scene time, thus representing only a fraction of the total prehospital time.	0.8433412004344909
Correlating the total prehospital time or scene time to outcome therefore appears absurd.	0.35371029105601354
The treatment principle of aggressive shock treatment in polytrauma needs critical reevaluation on the basis of results obtained by recent preclinical studies in patients with penetrating torso injuries.	0.5312593008385806
Small volume resuscitation could not be demonstrated to improve outcome in polytrauma patients, although a slight improvement in patients with brain injury may be assumed.	0.7218716201284189
Endotracheal intubation and early artificial ventilation are proven therapeutic principles in polytraumatized patients.	0.4097314078711239
Unfortunately, for ethical reasons randomised carefully controlled comparative studies can not be performed in polytrauma patients unless the patient is fully conscious.	0.7228278166362577
The importance of endotracheal intubation and artificial ventilation in unconscious trauma patients becomes apparent under conditions of anaesthesia where the application of the endotracheal tube averts regurgitation, aspiration and concomitant morbidity and mortality.	0.5443481404722847
The common causes of cardiovascular collapse and their pathomechanisms, as well as the mechanisms of cardiopulmonary resuscitation, have been widely investigated.	0.6365978742090641
Nevertheless, various aspects of their application are still controversial.	0.6556149832863857
The most recent study results have recommended initial ventilation prior to thoracic compression.	0.457973313218816
New methods of assisting mechanical cardiopulmonary resuscitation, such as ACD CPR or vest CPR, have shown promising results in animal experiments.	0.49921133473677154
However, the importance of results obtained by preclinical randomised controlled investigations in humans need to be confirmed by further studies as to outcome.	0.6537588069294185
The efficacy of defibrillation in cases of ventricular fibrillation has been clearly demonstrated, particularly with a view to the interval between ventricular fibrillation and defibrillation.	0.7299246411977125
It has further been demonstrated that basic cardiopulmonary resuscitation preserves ventricular fibrillation and thus improves the chance of survival.	0.4744234612788018
The present generation of defibrillators has been further improved, particularly by the introduction of biphasic defibrillator wave forms, which may reduce the required energy, as well as possible complications, while offering an increase in the efficacy of defibrillation and a reduction in defibrillator size.	0.7374648909788509
Scientific emergency medicine is responsible not only for the development and validation of new methods and concepts, but in particular for their application under quality control conditions.	0.7492594391669385
Politicians require an improvement in the quality of the validation of emergency measures, although the instruments available for the investigation of these measures are known to be obsolete (experimental models, experimental design).	0.6970488197898944
Additionally, the financial support of research in emergency medicine suffers from being accourded low priority by public research funds such as the German Research Fund.	0.5293314798710026
However, in view of the rapid application of experimental results to daily practice it should be emphasized that patients also support research in emergency medicine via their direct financial contributions to the health insurance companies.	0.5805614673151954

Cross-sectional imaging modalities, including sonography, CT and MRI, have increasingly been used for optimal treatment planning in gynecologic cancers.	0.8005507351823723
Their staging criteria are based on the well-established FIGO staging system.	0.618247844141048

To prevent those growth disturbances all primary and secondary (4-day X-ray control) displaced fractures of the radial condyle, i. e. those with a central gap of more than 2 mm, were prospectively treated by open reduction and osteosynthesis with a metaphyseal lag screw beginning 1974.	0.7061855601525373
Sixty-six patients (41 boys, 25 girls) with an average follow-up of 10 years (2-22 years) sustained 28 primary and 6 secondary displaced fractures.	0.8715647466168596
In 5 cases a K wire fixation was performed in view of the smallness of the fragment.	0.6544399151344804
Two children with conservative treatment following overlooked displaced fractures showed condylar overgrowth and varisation of the elbow.	0.3948559713471007
Screw osteosynthesis led to symmetric elbow angles and function in all cases, whereas fishtail deformities could be observed in 8 of 27 children, probably as a consequence of the remaining central fracture instability.	0.7355401020093336
Conclusion: Open reduction and osteosynthesis with a metaphyseal lag screw prevents condylar overgrowth in displaced fractures of the radial condyle by guaranteeing fracture healing in anatomic position within 3-4 weeks.	0.5217957781589384
However, fishtail deformity can not be prevented by metaphyseal compression only.	0.4546139379508237

Nociception is a protective system of the body which prevents it from injury and tissue damage.	0.5563909354665388
Human beings respond to noxious stimuli by moving away.	0.28050968177794255
They learn by pain to avoid these situations in future.	0.40592887667994104
Shortly after major injury, there is a limited analgesic period allowing the body to flee the area of danger, later on, emerging pain compels the body to rest and supports recuperation.	0.5362391494758597
While acute pain has a certain meaning, chronic pain does not.	0.5848359105897989
It induces a comprehensive suffering including loss of initiative, appetite and vigilance.	0.3208568342155527
It reduces life-quality, often accompanied by depressive moods.	0.5493147178060145
Acute pain causes changes in the central nervous system leading to an increased sensitivity of nociception (hyperalgesia).	0.5270737913040183
During healing, the central processing of noxious stimuli is normalised taking minutes to weeks.	0.5090108781795097
Sometimes, unknown factors initiate chronification of pain.	0.20629673998349948
Changes on a molecular level in peripheral tissue as well as in the central nervous system induce "cellular early genes" [24], a synthesis of c-fos, c-jun and other proteins favouring the chronification of pain.	0.6533368276278537
All efforts have to be made to depress or interrupt such a development.	0.5220935368343939
One of the first steps to pain prophylaxis in a hospital is an optimal surgical technique: incision, extension, limited tissue damage and minimal invasive surgery should guarantee the smallest impairment of the nociceptive system possible.	0.6811555821768854
However, nociceptive input is intense and of long duration and leads to central sensibilisation.	0.4043572496281315
Postoperative pain has lost its function as surgery anticipates healing.	0.37742355480717626
Pain induces a reduction of ventilation, circulation, digestion and increases the risk of other disorders.	0.5132907873635719
There is need of aggressive pain treatment for humanitarian reasons and for reasons of late sequelae like permanent pain and increased reduction of function [10].	0.46921125606551656
This is of pivotal importance in patients with amputations or sympathetic reflex dystrophy (SRD).	0.41892036917608694
Antinociception is best provided by regional anaesthesia technique with a combination of local anaesthetics and opioids which results in better outcome [2, 12].	0.5744040891374668
Hence, regional anaesthesia techniques are strongly indicated in those patients.	0.5760054460605668
Good antinociception may be even more important than it is assumed today.	0.44540265750388447

Anaesthesiologists have to reconsider the quality of general anaesthesia: the antinociception of their regimen.	0.5587259699602838

Before any use of this technology in combination with any cloning technology for human cell therapy will be possible, further research including animal models and stem cell differentiation approaches in culture (i. e., identification of differentiation factors, selective differentiation strategies, reporter gene assays) is necessary to understand the basic principles of pluripotent stem cell differentiation and the mechanisms involved in reprogramming somatic cell nuclei.	0.6284404254351972

However, the more complex etiology of non-traumatic osteonecrosis is multifactorial and includes chemotherapy, radiotherapy, thermal injuries, and especially coagulopathies, which are now commonly observed in these patients.	0.8027746116363325
Intravascular coagulation with fibrin thrombosis begins in the capillaries and sinusoids of the intraosseous microcirculation, and residual venous thrombosis is more likely to occur if there is coexistent hypofibrinolysis.	0.5426281603814282
The aim of our study was to investigate the influence that serum of patients with preeclampsia has on t-PA and PAI-1 expression from human endothelial cells.	0.6009229602913474
For this purpose, we cultured human endothelium cells, gained from umbilical veins, for 24 h with sera of 7 patients with HELLP syndrome and 12 patients with preeclampsia.	0.7244244103097645
The sera of 12 normotensive pregnant patients and 9 non-pregnant women were used as controls.	0.46134679455970434
We then determined t-PA and PAI-1 levels by ELISA, both in the maternal serum and in the supernatant of the endothelial cell cultures.	0.5911556968227959
While t-PA levels were significantly higher in the serum of patients with preeclampsia and HELLP syndrome than in the control group (median: 8.0 ng/ml and 6.2 ng/ml vs 3.9 ng/ml and 3.1 ng/ml), levels of PAI-1 did not show any significant disparity among the different groups.	0.7879006826748293
The supernatant of the endothelial cell cultures demonstrated significantly elevated levels of both t-PA (P<0.001) and PAI-1 (P<0.01) when stimulated with serum gained from patients with preeclampsia or HELLP syndrome.	0.5731362249928271
The increased expression of t-PA and PAI-1 from human endothelium cells after stimulation with the serum of preeclamptic patients must be considered as a sign of increased endothelial cell activation.	0.5730651132804911
Postoperative pain relief can be achieved by several methods, including the use of systemic opioids and regional anaesthesia with intrathecal or epidural opioids or local anaesthetics.	0.6682237471601009
On-demand analgesia using a PCA (patient-controlled analgesia) system is regarded as the ideal option for systemic opioid analgesia.	0.5664693859286578
While PCA devices are not yet commonly used in all recovery units, the use of repetitive boluses on demand is still the most frequent form of administration in postoperative pain therapy.	0.7020938264058797
The objective of the present study was to show if continuous infusion of the opioid tramadol could produce better analgesia than repetitive administration of boluses.	0.6232564661144122
In a study under double-blind conditions 135 ASA I and II patients were assigned at random to group I (infusion group) or group B (bolus group) when they first requested pain treatment after abdominal surgery.	0.6552393336715635
The patients in group I received an initial intravenous loading dose of 100 mg tramadol, followed by an infusion of 12 mg/h tramadol for 24 h; if necessary, repeated boluses of 50 mg tramadol were given.	0.6483123842156503
In group B the patients received a placebo infusion instead of the tramadol infusion; otherwise, the procedure was the same.	0.8481394023033317
Pain relief was monitored by means of a VAS (visual analogue scale) up to 6 h after surgery.	0.6583663045259549
We investigated the retrograde assessment of analgesia by the patients after 6 h, how often repetitive boluses were required, and the amount of analgesics administered in 6 and 24 h. Results.	0.723847153187072
The pain relief was assessed as excellent or good by 76.5% of group I and 65.6% of group B; 19.1% of group I and 26.9% of group B assessed the analgesic effect as satisfactory; 4.4% of group I and 7.5% of group B complained of insufficient analgesia.	0.8888469003895515
In group I 69.2% requested only one or no repetitive bolus, compared with 40.3% in group B, while two or more boluses were demanded by 30.8% in group I and 59.7% in group B.	0.853781449365276
The average analgesic consumption after 6 h was 223.5 +/- 53.7 mg tramadol in group I and 176.6 +/- 63.1 mg tramadol in group B, respectively.	0.6079723059151279
After 24 h it was 449.5 +/- 66.0 mg tramadol in group I and 201.6 +/- 83.9 mg tramadol in group B.	0.5455335339792424
While the consumption during the first 6 h was comparable, from then on the consumption in group I increased significantly.	0.7341920467792573
Side effects were reported by 25% in both groups.	0.8772531984874622
They were clinically irrelevant and did not necessitate termination of the clinical trial in any case.	0.5808353631497631
During the study period pulse and blood pressure remained within the normal range and did not show any significant changes.	0.7080547522377996
The fact that the patients in group I requested far fewer repetitive boluses than those in group B and the assessment by the patients led to the conclusion that treatment in the infusion group is better than that in the bolus group.	0.8519782610149704
Concerns that a significantly higher consumption of analgesics would cause unwanted side-effects have proven unfounded.	0.48054798233184265
Six hours after surgery, when analgesia was evaluated by the patients, there was no significant difference between the two groups.	0.8078825247490723
Not until the maintenance infusion had been administered for a further 18 h, was the tramadol consumption within the infusion group significantly higher.	0.619965950425992
Thus, we should consider continuing unreduced administration of the maintenance infusion 6 h after operation.	0.6836341853821585
The concept of tuberculid was introduced by Darier in 1896.	0.32005030637422455
In contrast to "true" cutaneous tuberculosis, properties of the tuberculids were explained by an hyperergic response to myobacteria or their fragments released from a different site of manifest or passed tuberculous infection.	0.5077259479650379
Key features include a strongly positive tuberculin skin test, evidence of concomitant manifest or past tuberculosis, and prompt response to antituberculous therapy The inability to culture M. tuberculosis or to demonstrate it microscopically from lesional biopsies, together with reports on tuberculid-like eruptions after BCG vaccination, supports this concept.	0.45080465470157816
Clinical manifestations are lichen scrophulosorum, papulo-necrotic tuberculids and erythema induratum of Bazin.	0.2708604485630151
The existence of tuberculids has been questioned, however, because the clinical and histological appearances are not always specific.	0.7892109042509621
An increasing number of case reports on tuberculids, new immunological tests and molecular biology-based techniques for the detection of mycobacteria have shed new light on the tuberculid concept.	0.5380181233263909
Case Report: A 20-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital because of a pneumothorax.	0.8324496762085868
A secondary amenorrhea was coexisting.	0.19436793321923987
On the abdominal wall and in the anogenital area a maculopapular exanthema was visible.	0.5438603888596555
Chest X-ray and HR-CT showed a interstitial lung disease with high probability of histiocytosis X which was confirmed by biopsies of lung and skin tissue.	0.5773347765814503
The cause of amenorrhea was a histiocytic infiltration of the pituitary stalk.	0.5005653712104844
Conventional "consensus-treatment" for adults with vinblastine, prednisone and etoposide did not prevent relapsing bilateral pneumothoraces.	0.42476992262500657
Treatment was successful with the protocol as proposed by the international study for children.	0.4933359004647039
This treatment is characterized by higher dosage and combination with 6-mercaptopurine.	0.5660081181870033
The prognosis of patients with malignant diseases requiring treatment on intensive care units is poor.	0.7839259385340059
The hospital mortality for mechanically ventilated patients ranges from 70-90% in patients with solid tumors to 75-90% in patients with hematological malignancy and up to 95% in patients after bone marrow transplantation.	0.8481992668078757
The number of patients referred to intensive care units is however increasing, due to improvements in the general treatment of malignant diseases.	0.6367156697652442
This results in controversies about the utilization of intensive care treatment in these patients.	0.5800712909374186
Since the individual outcome can not be predicted prior to initiation of intensive care therapy a general refusal of intensive care treatment seems not justified.	0.5573961228902536
A reevaluation of the patients status after initiation of intensive care treatment based on predefined criteria may however be useful in the decision about continuing intensive care measures.	0.6855650143410081
Patients requiring mechanical ventilation after bone marrow transplantation will not survive if prolonged treatment with vasopressors is necessary and/or sustained hepatic and renal failure is present.	0.5252198050055308
For these patients a withdrawal of further life support may be considered.	0.6248535988066959
Intensive care treatment should be continued in patients not fulfilling these criteria and treatment results are comparable to those in patients without malignant diseases.	0.7179276019286531
For other patients with malignant diseases the use of a new score system developed for patients with cancer can be helpful in the clinical decision making.	0.8351933268867685
On the basis of a solution-oriented marital therapy, the different within-session effects of four different types of questions in systemic therapy (lineal, strategic, circular, and reflexive), as described by Tomm (1989), were tested.	0.6517872440776856
In this single case study, the method of plan analysis (Caspar 1989) was used to categorize the client's reactions to the four types of therapeutic questions.	0.7446895464740589
Lineal and strategic questions were expected to have a stabilizing and restraining effect on the system (i.e.	0.5446799925499194
the client, the clients' interaction, and the therapeutic interaction), whereas circular and reflexive questions were expected to open the system for change.	0.7294093457863369
Interestingly this hypothesis was only supported for the wife, who had the role of the identified client in the therapy and demonstrated a much stronger motivation for change.	0.6862645351881418
For the husband, who preferred the role of a cotherapist and demonstrated only little motivation for change, results were not as predicted.	0.6210990633230614
Some of his reactions were even opposite to the expected therapeutic effects.	0.41951429710840543
Therefore, it is suggested that an interaction effect between questions and the motivation for change can be assumed.	0.7003181143366438
Prerequisites for experimental study designs are extremely difficult to realise under prehospital emergency conditions.	0.3389321371249499
Results obtained in animal experiments always need validation with prehospital or inhospital patient studies.	0.41032552229538316
Investigations related to emergency medicine are, however, an ethical obligation on behalf of the patient.	0.5243318338605394
A retrospective analysis of the available literature should be considered a prerequisite for prospective randomised and controlled studies.	0.8993006675985784
Frequently, a pilot study or feasibility trial needs to precede the actual study.	0.49024349618602503
Informed consent must be obtained for all patient studies.	0.3507599934037461
However, under emergency conditions informed consent cannot always be obtained due to unconsciousness, etc.	0.44483854283065094
Nevertheless, the following principles should be observed: (a) randomised studies are essential, even in emergency medicine; (b) they are ethically acceptable if the treatment provided for the study group is at least equivalent to the therapy for the control group; ( c) only these preconditions guarantee that the patient always receives treatment in accordance with the standard of treatment.	0.8570336555601932
If the patient is unconscious or otherwise unable to give informed consent, the principle of deferred consent is acceptable.	0.5869548436040074
The deferred consent principle should be carefully documented.	0.32930527238610935
A prospective randomized study represents the gold standard for an investigation, even under emergency conditions.	0.7231716596641229
There are different principles of randomization: telephone or telefax randomisation, etc.	0.3457750509475494
Emergency medicine investigations need to be completed within a reasonable time frame which should, as a rule, not exceed 2 years.	0.7433217940044126
Otherwise, too many items might change without being noted.	0.43408858780819276
Curative treatment and the intention to treat are terms employed by ethics committees.	0.49315323982265946
If an investigation does not bear in itself additional risk factors, it does not necessarily have to be brought before the ethics committee.	0.5693296741153598
If, however, for example, the effect of obtaining blood samples is investigated separately for research purposes, the patient needs to be informed and sign the respective agreement.	0.6578518261225068
In Germany the ethics committees have agreed to accept their respective decisions.	0.46394395624219315
For multicentre and multinational studies, however, the ethics committees also need to accept decisions made by non-German ethics committees.	0.4791708978241731
Not all therapeutic principles can serve as the basis of prospective randomized studies because they need to be considered the present standard of care (e.g., endotracheal intubation, etc.).	0.643089918164669
Nevertheless, the feasibility of a study should be assessed according to the 1-3 rating proposed by the American Heart Association.	0.7208873071235193
In principle, the overall emergency physician protocol does not fulfill scientific requirements.	0.5672615967484623
For all studies, particularly in the prehospital setting, an independent observer should be involved for documentation purposes.	0.6460934445471083
Scores can be of importance for investigating different treatment regimens.	0.4758078266677867
Biases in emergency medicine studies focus on the variability of EMS, personnel qualifications, etc.	0.45051617504198743
This is in part why it is extremely difficult to prove efficacy and efficiency in emergency medicine.	0.5590723090394863
The results of emergency medicine investigations should be published in suitable journals, i.e., journals with a reasonable rating.	0.5549212433067408
New antifungals for oral therapy have improved the chances of healing onychomycoses.	0.3948853152685559
Nevertheless, in daily practice the failure rate is 20-30% both with itraconazole and terbinafine.	0.7500129667338189
In our investigations for the fungicidal effects of terbinafine, we could show that the same strain of Trichophyton rubrum or T. mentagrophytes in the rest period needs 1000 times higher concentration of terbinafine (2,0 to 0,002 µg/ml) for complete fungal killing as in the growth phase.	0.6696470190411455
Thus resting fungi in the nail are not harmed, and if the concentration of terbinafine is lower than the MIC for the fungi, they can cause a relapse.	0.6813490156413607
Itraconazole is a fungistatic agent.	0.2025132365361857

This paper presents an algorithm for automatic switching between atrial tracking and nontracking pacing mode based on a "4 out of 7" concept: if 4 out of 7 atrial intervals are sensed below a critical value, mode switching (MS) is automatically performed.	0.569426815125878
The technical solution in Medtronic Kappa 700 dual chamber devices is explained together with an evaluation of advantages and possible limitations.	0.3776387596661076
The "4 out of 7" algorithm offers a quick MS; by the addition of a "blanked flutter search" algorithm integrated into this concept, the detection of atrial flutter is facilitated in a wider range of programmed AV intervals.	0.5977940552443811
With the increased rapidity of MS and sensitivity towards atrial flutter detection, there is also an increased propensity to switch to the nontracking mode in case of short atrial runs and frequent premature atrial beats.	0.5231725635946148
Therefore, to optimize the MS function, programming of the device (e.g., activation of a time delay before MS) should be carried out individually with respect to the intrinsic rhythm and arrhythmia of the patient.	0.6005891271618785
Possible interactions between different programmable parameters should also be taken into consideration.	0.4281426359308006
Some guidelines are presented in this paper.	0.5618891842031193

The results of ankle arthroplasty have generally been disappointing compared to other forms of arthroplasty.	0.5455327287236067
The present survey of results of ankle arthroplasty deals with the anatomical, the kinemasiological the biomechanical and the biological features of the ankle joint.	0.6960729535368513
These features all seem important prerequisites for a successful total ankle prosthesis design.	0.39232809014800146
From the study of the results displayed in the literature and those of my own series it can be stated that a modern ankle arthroplasty should respect the normal anatomy and kinemasiology.	0.7224680975680438
Biomechanically it should work as a normal ankle joint i. e. cylindrical mobility, congruency and a possibility for normal torque within the ankle mortise.	0.464809772934998
The prosthesis components should only be fixed in solid subchondral bone, and preferably without cement.	0.5118053106777496
Only compressible forces should act at the bone-prosthesis interface.	0.3843610125207538
The axis of the ankle joint as well as of that of the hindfoot should be aligned to normal.	0.8164537047286581
Meticulous surgery and special guide instruments are absolute necessities.	0.28863987513218536
Restoration of muscle power and gait postoperatively are essential for a good and lasting result.	0.6170002726899472
The indication for ankle arthroplasty is mainly cases of osteoarthritis (primary or traumatic) and rheumatoid arthritis.	0.6424411307142135

Mental disorders and neurological disorders may also be contraindications.	0.4931244489877689

Primary squamous cell carcinomas of the breast are rare, since they occur in less than 1% of all primary invasive breast carcinomas.	0.8529035569561072

The acute liver failure (ALF) is a complex syndrome resulting from loss of synthetic and metabolic functions of the liver.	0.6945836704233664
Despite recent advances in intensive care medicine patients with severe ALF have a very high mortality and the orthotopic liver transplantation still remains the only proven effective treatment of ALF.	0.66408262363499
Numerous attempts have been made to improve survival by using various extracorporeal support techniques, but none of these therapeutic approaches was able to increase the survival rate.	0.7057329043369401
Liver support systems based on detoxification procedures only could not influence the deleterious course of the disease.	0.44615281130959683
It is certain that an ideal liver support system should be capable to fulfil the liver's essential synthetic and metabolic functions as well as detoxification and excretion.	0.4022742329899298
Over the last years the development of hybrid liver assist devices has aimed at replacing these liver functions and therefore might give an advantage over earlier systems based on detoxification techniques only.	0.4948749975383251
This article gives a short review of the various liver support systems and focuses then on the hybrid liver support systems, their construction and the remaining problems after the first clinical applications.	0.7591441157327367
After a latency period of 20 years, in a 39-year-old Austrian citizen of Chinese origin, a surgically removed rectal carcinoma, as well as the neighboring chronic inflammatory rectal mucosa with various degrees of dysplasia and one positive neighboring lymph node, showed helminthiasis in the histopathological examination, convincing us of a link between carcinoma and chronic helminthiasis.	0.6012188605436981
Whereas the etiological context between chronic infection by Schistosoma haematobium and endemic frequent urinary bladder carcinoma is considered a matter of fact, whether of not the incidence of intestinal carcinoma is increased in connection with chronic intestinal schistosomiasis is controversial.	0.5264962935494374
The etiological and pathogenetic link between helminthiasis and carcinoma should be considered in the same way as for other related inflammatory large-bowel diseases.	0.5433154985254954
In the sequence chronic inflammation - severe dysplasia, the formation of carcinoma could possibly occur.	0.6471223795728268

Rupture of the carotid artery wall is a very rare postoperative complication.	0.5567198129799633
Mainly ruptures of vein patches are described in the literature.	0.40673679837213045
This paper reports on a 51-year-old patient with elective endarterectomy of the left internal carotid artery using V-Y technique.	0.6812027818488817
On day 8 after operation, the carotid bulb ruptured.	0.4993665058313072
The suture line was not involved.	0.272112833786521
The rupture was due to local wall necrosis, as verified by histologic examination.	0.5833150749408473

Postoperatively the patient showed paresis of the left recurrent nerve but fortunately did not suffer any other neurological deficit.	0.5747176394570519
Myocardial stunning (contractile dysfunction in the presence of normalized perfusion) and myocardial hibernation (contractile dysfunction matching reduced perfusion) have represented separate concepts of viable, but dyssynergic myocardium in the past.	0.6143730218453296
However, in vivo experimental and clinical work suggests that repetitive ischemia due to coronary artery disease may induce a gradual transition between stunned and hibernating myocardium.	0.5500328485454172
Myocardial hibernation itself can result from a spectrum of ischemic conditions ranging from impaired myocardial blood flow reserve to frank hypoperfusion.	0.41874843799385475
With increasing severity and duration of ischemia, degeneration of cardiac myocytes, accumulation of glycogen and cell death ensue.	0.49198974498625014
Additonally, there is an increase of extracellular matrix protein content leading to reparative fibrosis, which in turn limits functional recovery.	0.682149397494334
In the light of these structural features, the available methods for detection of viable myocardium, in particular dobutamine echocardiography and nuclear imaging techniques, offer complementary rather than contradictory information.	0.684051068360866
Dobutamine echo has satisfactory sensitivity, excellent specificity, and high diagnostic accuracy for the detection of viable dyssynergic myocardium.	0.6265106228507367
While in the past only its predictive accuracy for segmental recovery has been validated, newer data show an improved survival after revascularization if at least four viable dyssynergic left ventricular segments in a 16 segment model can be identified by dobutamine echocardiography.	0.49171284179441377
The complete (low and high dose) dobutamine protocol can elicit several types of contractile responses (sustained improvement in contraction or monophasic response, biphasic response, new wall motion abnormality) which should be interpreted in view of other clinical data including a previous infarction.	0.5962159424660826
The test protocol can be used safely at the end of the first week after myocardial infarction.	0.757836705550749
If ischemia or viability is documented, revascularization should be performed promptly.	0.4900369180291727
A similar strategy should be followed in the setting of chronic coronary heart disease with left ventricular dysfunction.	0.5248612841664799
Since the structural changes of hibernating myocardium are progressive, time to revascularization is critical.	0.5052644765497518
On the other hand, responsible therapeutic planning requires proof of ischemia or viability before initiating a potentially hazardous revascularization procedure.	0.33438511301886853
The coarctation of the aorta is a congenital narrowing of the aorta in the transitional area between the distal aortic arch and the proximal descending aorta.	0.6332935062439754
The coarctation causes an arterial hypertension of the upper half and an arterial hypotension of the lower half of the body.	0.7542426965287167
The indication for operative repair is given because of the hypertension with strain and possible insufficiency of the heart.	0.629563412113728

Successful transplantation of autologous chondrocytes for repair of articular cartilage defects requires an undisturbed matrix-synthesis of the transplanted cells.	0.5469845557143923
This, in turn, is dependent on the composition of the synovial fluid (SF) of the respective joint.	0.8554139577666675
We addressed the question whether analysis of a patient's SF can predict the rate of matrix-synthesis of articular cartilage exposed to this SF in vitro.	0.6966810174171566
SF was obtained from 115 patients with disorders of the knee, including gonarthrosis (n = 44), meniscal tears (n = 10), rheumatoid arthritis (n = 53), and reactive arthritides (n = 8).	0.5845349761971399
In the SF, the following parameters were determined: Interleukin-1, IL-6, IL-8, IL-1-RA, TNF, Insulin-like growth-factor I (IGF-I), IGF-II, IGF-binding protein-2 (IGFBP-2), IGFBP-3 as well as total proteinase activity and total collagenase activity.	0.6472025231625532
To assess the effect of SF on the matrix synthesis of articular chondrocytes, bovine cartilage was incubated in the presence of SF, and the rate of proteoglycan synthesis subsequently determined.	0.602826412594034
In some cases, a monoclonal antibody directed against IGF-I was added.	0.5621106213679147
SF from patients with OA or trauma, respectively, stimulated PG-synthesis of bovine cartilage more markedly than did SF from patients with rheumatic arthritides.	0.490454847663434
On the average, 60 percent of the SF-induced increase of cartilage matrix synthesis could be titrated out by an anti-IGF-I-AB.	0.5258336126040074
The best predictor for the SF-effects on PG-synthesis of exposed cartilage was the proportion of free IGF-I (r = 0.573, p < 0.001, Spearman rank correlation) followed by the SF-concentrations of IGF-I (with a positive sign), IGFBP-3, IL-1, and TNF (all with a negative sign).	0.6119402094070272
According to our data, IGF-I is the most important anabolic factor in human SF with respect to cartilage PG-synthesis.	0.6215327334441725
The proportion of free IGF-I seems to be of special importance in this regard.	0.6166675576740066
Low SF-levels of free IGF-I could be identified as a possible risk-factor for a sub-optimal protoeglycan synthesis of chondrocytes exposed to this synovial milieu.	0.609507235537377

Secondary outcome measures included the stiffness and physical function dimensions of the WOMAC, daily visual analogue scales (VAS) on pain and physical function, and final overall assessment by both patients and investigators.	0.6197999947385221
Results: 78 patients (39 willow bark extract, 39 placebo) participated in the trial.	0.6386109049637992

Recently, new insights into the phenomenology of transient cerebral hypoxia have been gained from video analysis of experimentally induced syncope.	0.47829047972627764
Common elements of syncope include multifocal and generalized myoclonus, tonic body extension, automatisms, vocalizations, eye deviations and hallucinations.	0.36850512926369006
Thus, it is not the presence or absence of these features but their specific character that distinguishes syncope from epileptic seizures.	0.611107948819243
Other clues for differential diagnosis include precipitating factors, premonitory symptoms and postictal events, such as tongue bites and postictal confusion, which has been identified as the single most powerful factor discriminating syncope from epileptic seizures.	0.5434927521707028
In contrast, incontinence and head injury are common in both conditions.	0.4107961658976154
Investigations such as electroencephalogram, tilt testing and postictal prolactin or creatine kinase levels may aid diagnosis but are never diagnostic in isolation.	0.31055495786330045
In rare cases, hypoxic and epileptic mechanisms may interact within one attack.	0.4106087615101965

The compartment syndrome (cs) is characterized by an increased tissue pressure in a limited space.	0.6971228959663767
Pathophysiologically, it is a multifactorial disease that is potentially induced by an initial trauma and develops according to the existence of cofactors.	0.6088348779349957
Cofactors are, for instance, the circulation of the patient and the initial treatment of the impending cs.	1.0121480059163774
In particular, the microcirculation is altered with endothelial destruction, development of a capillary leak, protein loss from intravasal space and the development of an interstitial and intracellular third space.	0.5903305542551376
An impaired drainage of the lymphatic and venous system causes a venous infarction.	0.48592239898098516
An arterial infarction results if the tissue pressure exceeds the arteriolar pressure.	0.33338561189525134
An accompanying ischemia reperfusion mechanism increases the trauma load.	0.28355183930084943
In disadvantageous cases, the patients are in danger of developing a multi-organ deficiency syndrome (MODS) by an uncontrolled inflammatory reaction, by intravasal volume loss and by a myonephropathic systemic reaction.	0.6853977036778652
Clinically, the patients suffer a disproportionate amount of pain, followed by neurological signs.	0.6342012966010643
Especially in noncompliant patients, tissue pressure measurement is useful.	0.5242844140976753
Resuscitation of the circulation as well as splitting of casts is important.	0.4309057127349272
In case of a manifest cs, dermatofasciotomy has to be performed as an emergency operation.	0.8602413997524659
Even if cs is diagnosed early and fasciotomy is carried out early, the development of sequellae cannot be avoided in every single case.	0.5097625272811684

None of the patients with penetrating injuries died.	0.9166475137431783
Mortality was inflenced by the type of liver injury and the number of associated injuries.	0.47166380178244277
The postoperative complication rate was 55 %.	0.5427401229890922
The most-frequent postoperative complications related to the hepatic injury were intrahepatic or subcapsular hematoma (12.9 %) and postoperative bleeding (9.6 %).	0.7381878063008229
Intraabdominal abscess formation was seen in 2.8 %.	0.6578102450734119
Operative therapy for liver injuries depends on the grade of the injury.	0.5687891552938755
The majority of liver injuries can be managed by simple techniques, including electrocautery and application of hemostatic agents.	0.6363157578707644
In complex injuries hepatotomy, direct vessel ligation, and debridement of necrotic tissue is the method of choice (Pachter's procedure).	0.5563453465074266
In non-controlled bleeding, perihepatic picking is a standard method.	0.5045724617180068

Urine specimens were collected from 49 persons up to 10 days after abstaining from cannabis use.	0.5363079289485669
Urine samples (n = 135) were investigated for free and conjugated 9-carboxy-11-nor tetrahydrocannabinol (THCCOOH) by LC/MS/MS and for free and glucuronidated tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) and 11-hydroxy-THC (11-OH-THC) by GC/MS prior to and after enzyme hydrolysis.	0.6763268549717005
Concentrations for free and conjugated THCCOOH were measured with reference to 100 mg creatinine/dL urine.	0.5209663435525855
Cannabis use was classified as light, moderate and heavy according to the current literature.	0.5837830841454716
In all groups chosen free and bound THCCOOH was present in urine samples on the day of the last use and on the next day.	0.6882601447339233
Urine samples from occasional and frequent users generally differed in the amount of THCCOOH and THCCOOH glucuronide.	0.3399478821934689
Within 4-6 days the concentrations of free and glucuronidated THCCOOH in urine samples of heavy users decreased to those ranges present in urine samples of moderate and light users.	0.5572995629296502
In frequent users, THC glucuronide and 11-OH-THC glucuronide could be found up to 1 and 3 days after abstinence, respectively.	0.5728077176320935
In light users, neither THC glucuronide nor 11-OH-THC glucuronide was detectable.	0.4121130097772329

Many differential diagnoses of muscular rigidity and of induration of the skin have to be considered.	0.6655614914862339

In case of malpositioning the system can be pulled back into and retrieved through the sheath.	0.4106815021524033

Using 8 different monoclonal antibodies, immunohistology was performed on 36 follicular adenomas and on 28 follicular, 34 papillary, 27 medullary and 29 anaplastic carcinomas of the thyroid.	0.5426945537590461
The panel of antibodies was directed against broad-spectrum cytokeratins (pan-CK, antibody lu-5), against basic and acid high-molecular-weight CK of types  1, 5, 10 and 14, against basic ( 5 and 6) and acid high-molecular-weight CK ( 13) and against basic ( 7 and  8) and acid low-molecular-weight CK ( 19 and  20).	0.7594700919303838
With the exception of a large number of anaplastic carcinomas, nearly all other tumours exhibited strong immunoreactivity with antibodies against pan-CK, CK 8 and CK 19.	0.44849093045826066

Thirteen anaplastic carcinomas were not decorated by any of the CK antibodies applied.	0.3801511219857369
CK 7 staining exceeding the staining of individual cells was observed in 26 papillary cancers.	0.4563017385728196
In contrast, such a finding could only be obtained with each one follicular adenoma, medullary carcinoma and anaplastic carcinoma and with 5 follicular carcinomas.	0.611690341875085
These results confirm earlier studies in that CK 20 expression among thyroid tumours is restricted to the neuroendocrine medullary carcinomas and that in a larger percentage of anaplastic thyroid carcinomas an epithelial phenotype can not be demonstrated even upon using broad-spectrum CK antibodies.	0.5192083953453256
New is the finding that there exist considerable differences between papillary carcinomas and all other non-papillary thyroid tumours regarding CK 7 expression.	0.4251051447332926

Tumor invasion of the portal vein by ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreatic head is classically known as a criterion for inoperability.	0.4667056918804063
Despite improvement in operation techniques for portal vein resection during Whipple's procedure and acceptable mortality and morbidity, in the case of uncertain tumor infiltration vascular resection cannot be recommended in general.	0.5645831375896263
The problem is the preoperative detection of tumor infiltration of the portal vein.	0.6576631638859013
Often the surgeon is confronted with unsuspected macroscopic portal vein infiltration or tumor adhesion during the operation.	0.4394939206844162
Between 1986 and 1995 105 patients underwent Whipple's procedure for ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreatic head in our department.	0.4495199857862518
In eight of these cases partial portal vein resection was performed because of macroscopic tumor infiltration or tumor adhesion.	0.5919002510598788
In all eight cases the preoperative diagnostic procedures with CT and portography did not show any suspicion of tumor infiltration.	0.5776256751587442
In four of the eight cases histological tumor infiltration of all vascular layers was found.	0.47473811285388556
In the others we found no or only adventitial tumor invasion.	0.538268560392294
The patients without tumor infiltration of the portal vein showed a survival time after surgery of 27.78 months in contrast to 6.67 months in the group with histologically proven tumor infiltration.	0.7089875034205423
Endovascular, intraportal ultrasound (IPEUS), a new diagnostic procedure, can give helpful information regarding portal vein involvement.	0.6041917971047072
Although the IPEUS is not a standard diagnostic procedure it was shown to detect portal vein infiltration with high sensitivity and specificity.	0.6932397888316719

Olfactory dysfunction seems to be one of the most frequent symptoms in idiopathic parkinsonian syndrome (IPS).	0.5625305337228612
In contrast to the increasing number of studies providing evidence of the usefulness of olfactory tests in the diagnosis of IPS, clinical assessment of olfactory function is rarely performed.	0.6380356418675452

In this study, we administered the newly developed "sniffin' sticks" test to a group of 40 nondemented IPS patients and compared the results with 40 healthy controls matched for age, gender, and smoking habits.	0.6705327394283396
In all three subtests including odor identification, odor detection threshold, and odor discrimination, the control group scored significantly better than the IPS group, yielding a specificity and sensitivity of 90% each.	0.6311416484152426
Our results indicate that olfactory disturbances in IPS can be found at early stages of the disease, appear bilaterally, and do not correlate with the dominant side of parkinsonism.	0.6349931413095345

Toxic metabolic and immunologic products in the serum have been discussed as possible causes.	0.474733979963908
For this reason we have performed plasmapheresis on these patients for many years.	0.652880966479948
Results regarding survival and healing of the lesions are quite favorable, as exemplified with two patients described here who benefited from the procedure despite their old age.	0.6179755681300347

Primary defects of skeletal growth and development can be subdivided into hypoplasias, dysostoses and dysplasias.	0.35553317943194096
Hypoplastic bones are small but otherwise normal.	0.23284064863922488
Generalized skeletal hypoplasias comprise various forms of primordial dwarfism and syndromal disorders including trisomy 21 and Ullrich-Turner syndrome.	0.2568979913878333
Dysostoses are defects of bones as organs resulting from errors of morphogenesis.	0.31194644788522835
Many of them are caused by mutations of single genes in the cascade of morphogenetic gene sequences.	0.5130602409723246
Dysplasias are defects of bone as tissue.	0.29561450529341093
Some of them (e. g. achondroplasia, Jansen type of metaphyseal chondrodysplasia) are caused by defects of signal genes influencing cell division or differentiation.	0.5087632588073573
Others result from gene mutations affecting the cellular production of matrix components.	0.32448320667529446
Examples are collagenopathies such as osteogenesis imperfecta and some spondyloepiphyseal dysplasias.	0.251240255376918
Finally, disorders such as pycnodysostosis, result from defects of chondro-osseous homeostasis.	0.46037430189080897
The study of skeletal defects helps to unravel the complexity of normal skeletal development.	0.48181996540966515
Human parvovirus B19 causes erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) and aplastic crisis.	0.44000899299944324
In pregnancy, B19 may be transmitted on to the fetus resulting in hydrops fetalis.	0.4121850073481477
B19 is sometimes associated with thrombocytopenia and vasculitis.	0.2433681093221743
In immunocompromised patients, B19 may persist causing chronic infection.	0.31806599101429983
Several methods for detecting B19 virus or specific antibodies are now available.	0.34803399961821246
B19 infection does not usually require therapy.	0.26346277630913373
Efficacy of immunoglobulins in chronic B19 infection has been demonstrated.	0.5212713729955017
In absence of significant symptoms and signs, the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE) remains difficult.	0.6741266701171708
Sensitivity and specifity of laboratory tests, chest X-ray, and ECG on their own is low.	0.6305406754831002
Echocardiography is particularly useful in critically ill patients suspected of having pulmonary emboli and can help identify right ventricular pressure overload.	0.5232181500773214
Venous ultrasonography is useful in patients with suspected PE, but normal results do not rule out PE.	0.6217490610006788
Helical CT with contrast medium can identify pulmonary emboli.	0.333793227594653
However, if the CT findings are normal in the presence of a high index of clinical suspicion, only larger pulmonary embolism are ruled out, and angiography with the focus on distal pulmonary vasculature should be performed.	0.7239367088875144
The diagnosis of pulmonary embolism should be made by combining clinical assessment, several diagnostic techniques, and finally pulmonary angiography in doubtful cases.	0.7498509211562578
Heparin remains the standard therapy for patients with stable hemodynamics.	0.7046145055321666
Thrombolytic therapy is recommended in hemodynamically compromised patients.	0.6431164419840756
In short-term dose regimes, the thrombolytic agents urokinase, streptokinase, and rt-PA seem to be equally efficient.	0.5923658797573955
So far, however, no study has proven that thrombolytic therapy significantly reduces mortality in pulmonary embolism.	0.4863777712975738

Renal tubular dysgenesis is a rarely recognized condition characterized by oligohydramnios, Potter's sequence and congenital anuria leading to stillbirth or neonatal death from respiratory failure.	0.3432709267085578
It is thought to be inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.	0.5599696500671029
Definitive diagnosis is based on renal histology, revealing the lack of proximal tubule differentiation.	0.4925638935758953
Two additional cases of affected sibs in a family with parental consanguinity are reported.	0.42231553222142354
Lectin and immunohistochemical studies confirmed structural and functional immaturity of the proximal tubule.	0.548252765890305
Further findings include bilateral renal vein thrombosis.	0.17861105795330212

Articular cartilage has only a small capacity for regneration.	0.4799426649209352
This makes the repair of articular surfaces difficult.	0.487056977567016
In 1959 Pridie described his method of resurfacing osteoarthritic knee joints.	0.21338615895240445
This operation is still in widespread use today.	0.49612256415623723
Pridie introduced the principle of drilling exposed subchondral bone with the objective of encouraging a fibro-cartilaginous repair.	0.4103439190708634
The newly formed fibrocartilaginous layer that develops over the lesion in osteoarthritis may be enough to decrease patients symptoms.	0.41795190550545025
Bone drilling into the subchondral layer is also effective in promoting healing of osteochondrosis dissecans.	0.4188821643545468

Recent immunobiological findings together with advances in biotechnology, ameliorations in clinical trial design, and MRI developments have led to a variety of therapeutical approaches in multiple sclerosis (MS).	0.47523201272218235
However, in contrast to successfully introduced new treatments, a number of therapeutical failures exist as well: despite impressive data from animal models, convincing concepts, and promising phase I/II studies, some investigated drugs and strategies showed no positive effects in clinical trials, or trials had to be terminated because of unexpected side effects.	0.6493498627370027
This article provides an overview of clinical studies that have failed or been abandoned for other reasons.	0.5008624101004329

Isolated pancreatic metastases from renal-cell carcinomas (RCC) are extremely rare.	0.53126297299511
Only 96 cases of clinically diagnosed renal-cell carcinoma metastatic to the pancreas have been reported in the world literature, and 70 of the patients (including ours) underwent a definitive surgical resection.	0.7901804075473395
In many cases the time between the nephrectomy and diagnosis of metachronous metastases is reported to exceed 10 years.	0.6067142991558381
Therefore, the initial diagnosis may be overlooked when there is a prolonged disease-free interval.	0.8368247900422108
When it does occur simultaneously or metachronously, aggressive surgical resection, when possible, seems to be the most effective treatment for this metastatic lesion.	0.7184641921008524
Surgical resection can provide long-term survival in selected cases.	0.6045142146666467
We present the case of a 69-year-old woman in whom two pancreatic metastases were treated by a left-sided subtotal pancreatectomy with splenectomy, 12 years after radical nephrectomy for a RCC.	0.6795168036099495
The patient simultaneously presented with both a mass in the body of the pancreas and a right-sided colon cancer.	0.6097573364563363
Thus, the diagnosis of pancreatic metastasis of colon cancer was suspected initially.	0.6927807787893945
Both tumors were radically resected, and histological examination revealed two pancreatic metastases from the previous RCC.	0.712426699129982
In the world literature this report represents the eighth case of multiple pancreatic metastases due to RCC.	0.47837058605379046
It illustrates a rare indication of pancreatic resection because of pancreatic metastasis.	0.4121343367236249
The need for prolonged follow-up of patients is emphasized.	0.8388882674067352
The few reports on surgically treated pancreatic metastases from RCC are reviewed after the presentation of this case.	0.5336165683479382
Delusion is understood to mean intersubjectively disconcerting convictions with a tendency toward subjective certainty that lose their disconcerting character when made the object of psychiatric analysis in the knowledge of their independence from mental disorder.	0.4104320318542695
The perceptions from which delusions arise are dynamically charged according to their role in the structural context.	0.4627503237345513
The realisation pressure that burdens the perceptions and is intensified in psychotic constitutions is a precondition for the delusion.	0.2931654049474966
The failure of derealisation brought about by the psychotic disorganisation of the structure is also a requirement.	0.544084896836337
Based on a case study, considerations arising out of the initial stages of schizophrenic delusion are extended to other forms of delusion and to the conditions for chronification.	0.7272507881862843
High-dose chemotherapy (HDCT) is a promising treatment for patients with germ cell tumours and a poor prognosis.	0.7890788921549929
The selection of patients who may profit from this intervention is challenging for the urologist, as the indication has to be carefully established.	0.7721612830158722
Exclusion criteria primarily concern impaired organ functions.	0.17568925203490743

HDCT consists of a combination of carboplatin, etoposide and ifosfamide or cyclophosphamide.	0.35527033624379334
After HDCT, haematologic monitoring and maximal supportive care are essential.	0.2800446100933
It is therefore recommended that HDCT only be administered at specialized centres.	0.4171408136742994
Pyoderma gangrenosum develops in most patients between the age of 25 and 54 years.	0.584819362034159
It usually occurs in otherwise healthy persons or in association with a systemic desease.	0.5051996955240242
Several clinical variants of pyoderma gangrenosum have been described.	0.4257561004934898
Extremely painful ulcerations are characteristic and evolve rapidly.	0.26627059653832297
Malignant pyoderma, the variant described in our case report, is an aggressive variant of ulcerative pyoderma gangrenosum, rapidly progressive and a potentially lethal ulcerative disease.	0.6670593892762291
The diagnosis of pyoderma gangrenosum depends on recognition of the evolving clinical features because histopathologic changes are not specific and characteristically serological or hematological markers of the disease do not exist.	0.5973643597502287
Histopathologic findings, however, always include vasculitis, either in form of the necrotizing cutaneous vasculitis (7), granulomatous (1) or lymphocytic vasculitis (2).	0.6312436319477749
We report on a 36-year-old male patient, who underwent surgery for repair of an aneurysm of the aortic arch.	0.8800481953551738
The aneurysm occurred two months after exacerbation of a malignant variant of pyoderma gangrenosum with nearly lethal exit.	0.5711417968866039
An association of pyoderma gangrenosum with vasculitis has been described previously, but the present report is the first to describe an aortic arch aneurysm which seems to be associated with necrotizing angiitis of the vasa vasorum caused by a pyoderma gangrenosum.	0.7357392964881573
We could demonstrate successful perioperative treatment for prevention of exacerbation of pyoderma gangrenosum with prednisone and clofazimine	0.4519835882522271
Background and purpose: To test the association of cardiac sources of embolism with territorial type brain infarcts.	0.5265962298572753
Defects of the dorsal and ventral ligament complexes of the lumbar spine results to an instability of the functional spinal unit.	0.592983164480266
For the prognosis of secondary instability due to disko-ligamentous injuries the functional insufficiency of the lasting scars is a larger problem than the primar loss of osseous stability with fast healing tendency.	0.4641720250838296
The main goal of the present biomechanical study in vitro was to demonstrate the different grades of instability in the correlation to progressive disko-ligamentous defects as well as stabilisation through dynamic and static procedures.	0.5930468714519775
With a transpedicular screw-ringband-system the segmental function was preserved and instability was abolished.	0.36736812124139884
After rigid instrumentation with a fixateur intern remained a residual range of motion due to which can result refuse to bending moments without spondylodesis in an implant failure.	0.43952092559543027
CT- or MRI-guided stereotactic procedures should be a standard in a modern neurosurgical unit.	0.6511081892841809
Analysing 71 cases the indications and results of stereotactic neurosurgery are presented.	0.4955108303194163
In 53 patients stereotactic serial biopsies of different intraaxial lesions were performed, in 5 patients a spontaneous haemorrhage of the basal ganglia was removed by lysis with r-tPA.	0.5862804602406972
In 3 patients suffering from hydrocephalus due to diencephalic cysts a cystventricular shunt device was implanted.	0.3743672835729659

A stereotactic guided craniotomy and excision of small deep-seated lesions was performed in 6 cases.	0.5529177281262702
The accuracy of stereotactic tumour biopsies was 88.7 % in our series, in accordance to other authors.	0.8610006082769673
The stereotactic aspiration and drainage of an intracerebral abscess provides accurate localization and minimal cortical damage and offers the possibility of intracavitary application of antibiotics.	0.47233348447671386
The stereotactic internal shunt implantation seems to be an alternative approach in the treatment of diencephalic cysts due to its minimal invasiveness and low operative risk.	0.610397606124432

With stereotactic guidance small, deep-seated intraaxial lesions can be well localized and removed.	0.4157782790954132
Radiotherapy of patients with prostate cancer offers an alternative to radical prostatectomy in early stages (T1-T2).	0.6631106466350202
In locally advanced prostate cancer a high dose or combined radiotherapy is more effective than radical surgery with concurrent lower morbidity and mortality.	0.5159844211247216
Recent developments in linear accellerator technique, the progress in dose calculation and planning techniques provide the means to apply higher doses to a given tumor volume while effectively protecting the surrounding normal tissue at the same time.	0.5021908530540993

In special cases with a very low risk of recurrent tumor an interstitial permanent brachytherapy alone is indicated.	0.7565410760726112

Skin is the second most common site of extranodal lymphoma.	0.3652289826797863
The significance of cutaneous B-cell lymphomas has been underestimated due to the lack of monoclonal antibodies and molecular genetics in former years.	0.5438415522090583
Cutaneous B-cell lymphomas represent a heterogenous group of entities which show variation in histology, immunophenotype and in prognosis.	0.4435379752608374
The most common entities presenting in skin are follicular lymphomas, marginal zone B-cell lymphomas, and diffuse large B-cell lymphomas.	0.614129619669683
The majority of primary cutaneous B-cell lymphomas have an excellent prognosis.	0.6039716066602053
Whereas in B-cell lymphomas with secondary spread to the skin the clinical course is dependant on the prognosis of the primary lymphoma.	0.790926154014282
It is evident that primary cutaneous lymphomas are distinct from nodal lymphomas and not extranodal manifestations of their lymph-node-based counterparts.	0.4533302117885555
In the current review the morphologic spectrum of cutaneous B-cell lymphomas comprising primary and secondary cutaneous B-cell lymphomas is discussed according to the WHO classification sheme.	0.6757173477894654
The phencyclidine derivative ketamine is a non-competitive N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonist with the thalamo-neocortical projection system as the primary site of action.	0.44300699370456154
Racemic ketamine consists of the enantiomers S(+)-ketamine and R(-)-ketamine.	0.7065977594824416
Racemic ketamine has never been considered an adequate anaesthetic agent in neurosurgical patients since  it produces regionally specific stimulation of cerebral metabolism (CMRO2) and increases cerebral blood flow (CBF) and intracranial pressure (ICP).	0.5094907075349691
However, recent experiments suggest that both tracemic ketamine and S(+)-ketamine may reduce infarct size in animal models of incomplete cerebral ischaemia and brain injury.	0.5892375876791582
This experimental protective effect appears to be related to decreases in Ca++ influx and maintenance of brain tissue magnesium levels due to NMDA and quisqualate receptor blockade by ketamine.	0.3670508548835645
Studies in dogs have shown that racemic ketamine (2.0 mg/kg) increases CBF in the presence of the cerebral vasodilator N2O.	0.6266002424009259
In contrast, studies in rats without background anaesthesia showed increases in CBF after racemic ketamine (100 mg/kg i.p.).	0.5863478409744179
This suggests that the cerebrovascular effects of racemic ketamine are related to the pre-existing cerebrovascular tone induced by background anaesthetics.	0.40269120805684366
Cerebrovascular CO2 reactivity was maintained regardless of the baseline cerebrovascular resistance.	0.3650708899824098
There are several mechanisms by which racemic ketamine may increase CBF.	0.46370204167622475
It induces dose-dependent respiratory depression with consequent mild hypercapnia in spontaneously ventilating subjects.	0.3796068408251202
This produces vasodilation due to the intact cerebrovascular CO2 reactivity.	0.4078078075339517
Racemic ketamine also induces regional neuroexcitation, which leads to stimulation of cerebral glucose consumption in the limbic, extrapyramidal, auditory, and sensory-motor systems.	0.5763547361555825
This regional neuroexcitation with increased CMRO2 produces increases in CBF that can be blocked by infusion of barbiturates or benzodiazepines.	0.4260401943010542
However, increases in CBF with racemic ketamine (1 mg/kg) may also occur during normocapnia and without changes in CMRO2.	0.8235531114148243
This effect is related to some additional direct cerebral vasodilating potency of racemic ketamine based on a mechanism involving blockade of Ca++ channels.	0.4921333616335455
The effects of racemic ketamine on CBF autoregulation have not been investigated systematically.	0.5506805054005642
However, studies in rats have shown that CBF autoregulation was maintained with low- and high-dose S(+)-ketamine.	0.8219993602038164
Infusion of racemic ketamine alters intracranial volume and ICP.	0.4050562485492515
Studies in spontaneously ventilating pigs with and without intracranial hypertension have shown that racemic ketamine (0.5-5.0 mg/kg) produces increases in PaCO2 and ICP.	0.6490770621191815
In contrast, identical experiments with mechanical ventilation and controlled PaCO2 showed no changes in ICP following racemic ketamine infusion.	0.42518141879218324
This implies that increases in ICP are related to inadequate ventilation with consecutive hypercapnia and increases in intracranial blood volume.	0.41797279006282423
However, mechanical ventilation may not be sufficient to control ICP following racemic ketamine.	0.5926690077396047
Experiments in mechanically ventilated dogs indicate that racemic ketamine (2 mg/kg) increases cerebral blood volume and ICP even in the presence of normoventilation, a response that is reversible by hyperventilation or the administration of diazepam.	0.6415850005265727
Studies in patients have shown that racemic ketamine (2.0 mg/kg) reduces CBF in the presence of cerebral vasodilators like halothane or N2O.	0.56656375784912
In contrast, studies in unanaesthetised humans showed increases in CBF after racemic ketamine (2-3 mg/kg).	0.6067576992376368
This observation is consistent with animal studies and suggests that the cerebrovascular effects of racemic ketamine are related to the pre-existing cerebrovascular tone induced by background anaesthetics.	0.41030285209909595
Dengue-Fever is a mosquito transmitted viral disease.	0.20468462111235547
It is endemic mainly in South-East Asia and Afrika.	0.2926358964323319
The clinical manifestation is divided into different stages.	0.33946948605783056
