Morbihan's disease was first reported as a distinct entity in 1957 by Degos, describing a chronic persistent erythema and oedema of the upper half of the face.	0.6346503266778115
Such conditions have been noted in the literature designated as chronic lymphoedema or solid persistent facial oedema in acne or rosacea.	0.5151434772823056
The characteristic features are a chronic course, a typical clinical picture, lack of specific laboratory and histological findings and refractoriness to therapeutic measures.	0.6904977692674555
Paediatric cardiac transplantation (pHTX) has gained widespread acceptance as a therapy in end-stage myocardial failure and some forms of congenital heart disease, particularly hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS).	0.5644134987801898
The major problems to the anaesthesiologist in these patients are induction of anaesthesia in infants with HLHS and treatment of pulmonary hypertension in the early post-bypass period.	0.9214503608888893
Objective: Thirty years ago, cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) was primarily developed for otherwise healthy individuals who experienced sudden cardiac arrest.	0.5363685430901841
Today, CPR is widely viewed as an emergency procedure that can be attempted on any person who undergoes a cessation of cardiorespiratory function.	0.5558417082245373
Therefore, the appropriateness of CPR has been questioned as a matter of the outcome, the patient's preferences, and the cost.	0.9826760866760894
The objective of this article is to analyse ethical issues in prehospital resuscitation.	0.5027324509731418
Arguments: CPR is bound by moral considerations that surround the use of any medical treatment.	0.4208787084086927
According to Beauchamp and Childress, the hierarchy of justification in biomedical ethics consists of ethical theories, principles, rules, and particular judgements and actions.	0.48761180738686927
The decision to start CPR is based on the medical judgement that a person is suffering from circulatory arrest.	0.5387486781554607
The decision is justified by the moral rule that the victim of a cardiac arrest has the right to survive and to receive CPR.	0.5768081949338844
Moral rules are more specific to contexts and are based on ethical principles.	0.42337306073539527
The principle of beneficence means the provision of benefits for the promotion of welfare.	0.33566755236223556
Talking about beneficence in resuscitation means once again reporting stories of success, as many victims of pre- and in-hospital sudden death have been saved in the past.	0.7108234845658904
Nevertheless, resuscitative efforts still remain unsuccessful in the majority of cases, involving the principle of nonmaleficence.	0.5189246876620469
There is potential harm in CPR.	0.20882310851618677
Survivors may recover cardiac function, but sustain severe hypoxic brain damage, at worst surviving without awakening for months or years.	0.5025807488593718
In particular, post-traumatic CPR is associated with an extremely poor outcome, leading to the issue of futility.	0.6357197011080881
However, futility should be defined in a strict fashion, as there might be an individual chance of survival.	0.606218545267272
The principle of respect for autonomy means the right of a patient to accept or reject medical treatment, which continues in emergency conditions and after the patient has lost consciousness.	0.7511923341198424
The time frame in CPR requires medical decision-making within seconds, and CPR is usually initiated without the patient's involvement.	0.5509370303711697
If the patient's wish's can be ascertained later on, life-sustaining therapies might be withdrawn at that time.	0.5413036563640047
Terminally ill but still competent patients should be encouraged to write a no-CPR document, which does not deny patients relief from severe symptoms, but might facilitate withholding resuscitative efforts at the scene.	0.5432658411510679
The principle of justice affects priorities in the allocation of health care resources.	0.4563542508036837
The decision made for a particular patient might delay or prevent emergency treatment in other patients who could receive greater benefit.	0.5258046999725158
Conclusions: The standard of care remains the prompt initiation of CPR.	0.6659198375808979
However, ethical principles such as beneficene, nonmaleficence, autonomy, and justice have to be applied in the unique setting of emergency medicine.	0.6656276087852255
Physicians have to consider the therapeutic efficacy of CPR, the potential risks, and the patient's preferences.	1.0294383349705793
Acting within the context of the therapeutic process is often equated with acting-out.	0.637537466119559
Subtile behaviour, too, as a part of the "complex system of sending and receiving unconscious signals" (Sandler) which serve for the patient to induce behavior of the transference object in the analyst or fulfilling his unconscious wishes is seen as acting-out or microacting-out (Treuniet).	0.6371110548087721
However, this delicate acting has no meaning, it is not symbolic or communicative action.	0.6692765944559291
It is aimed at inducing effects and interactions.	0.31492819517462284
It appears both on the side of the analyst and of the patient and is part of the unconscious communication in the therapeutic process.	0.9064761581769709
Diverse interactive means and ways will be demonstrated, how the analyst is moved to unnoticed acting and to handling the patient in an unnoticed manner in a certain way.	0.5071553735010854
The acting-reactions of the analyst may have the character of interpretations, by which he unintentionally demonstrates, in what a way he understands the patient.	0.5852144319507956

The significant legal and ecomonic ramifications of a positive drug test produce an incentive among users of illicit drugs to escape detection.	0.3557552877268686
Therefore, being the easiest body fluid to handle for drug screening urine is very often manipulated to test clean.	0.4235295877542066
Methods available to cause a negative result range from substitution of urine, adulteration of the collected specimen by various chemical agents and in-vivo manipulations.	0.48505057822365244
Among these, the preferred strategy is to increase fluid intake and urine flow so as to dilute the concentration of drugs below the threshold of detection.	0.5257915990615649
To determine the extent of possible specimen dilution the urinary creatinine concentration is generally determined.	0.48991621062478174
Based on data from uncontrolled and controlled fluid intake studies in the literature and physiological conditions of urinary excretion, the meaningfulness of creatinine concentration in randomly obtained urine samples is discussed.	0.600348441258272
A low creatinine concentration not clearly proving an intentional dilution of the sample, the application of GC/MS analysis or the concentration of the urine prior to drug screening is recommended for specimens exhibiting a "suspect" urinary creatinine concentration.	0.5731949102906608

Risk factors for development of malignant melanoma have been investigated in several case control studies during the last decade, with some variation in results, partly with geographical region.	0.7107327283944452
Four studies have been conducted under the auspices of the Central Malignant Melanoma Registry of the German Dermatological Society; these have yielded consistent results allowing the identification of risk factors for melanoma development.	0.6483586879341952
The numbers of common melanocytic naevi, of atypical melanocytic naevi and the frequency of actinic lentigines were found by multivariate regression analysis to be the most important independent risk factors for melanoma development.	0.6849770160455365
Additional factors were hair colour, skin type and a history of naevus growth.	0.4873548383081233
A classification of relative risks was established by considering the first three risk factors mentioned, without any clear improvement of classification when further additional significant factors were taken into accout.	0.5862707929524286
For example, in individuals with more than 50 common melanocytic naevi, 5 or more atypical melanocytic naevi and simultaneous presence of actinic lentigines the risk of developing melanoma was found to be 100-fold that in persons with 10 common melanocytic naevi or fewer and without atypical melanocytic naevi or actinic lentigines.	0.6387030173945598
Early recognition of melanomas may be substantially improved if these risk factors are considered.	0.4370526990510646
Furthermore, intermittent intensive sun exposure (sunburns as indicator) before the age of 20 induces the development of melanocytic naevi, and after the age of 20 it contributes to the development of actinic lentigines; both factors are associated with an increased risk of melanoma development.	0.6856921527540643

The physician's duty of professional discretion is one of the basic tenets at the heart of the doctor's profession.	0.5974396493175019
It is laid down in the physicians' professional code and determined ultimately by the patient's right to self-determination, which is regulated in §203 of the German Criminal Code.	0.7016994436792712

It is also regulated in §203 of the German Criminal Code.	0.519823278104454

This way, contiguous chest images of superior and HRCT sections of equal image quality compared to conventional CT scanning can be obtained.	0.4626494335803942

Abstract   Basis of the modern shoulder implants is the Neer II-system, a non constrained total shoulder prosthesis with conforming radii of curvature and improved protection against dislocation.	0.5978199768049346
The second generation of shoulder prosthesis is based on the geometric shaft design of the Neer II prosthesis and offers not only a variety of modular head- and shaft-sizes but also through different radii a physiologic rotation-translation-mechanism.	0.5628796156892589
The third generation of humeral head prosthesis carries the concept of an anatomic reconstruction one step further and enables the surgeon to adjust the inclination and the eccentric offset of the humeral head to restore the centre of rotation.	0.5381044639402082
The latest development in shoulder arthroplasty are humeral head prosthesis with a fully variable 3-dimensional modularity to independently adjust the prosthestic head position regardless of the individual shaft geometry.	0.5085636803020457
This achieves a 3-dimensional adaptability of the prosthetic head about the stem axis in the coronary and in the sagittal plane.	0.6734170457212761
Besides of the humeral shaft prosthesis an alternative concept of shoulder joint replacement is established - the replacement of the humeral head articular surface.	0.6690829870817646
A hemispheric surface prosthesis - cup arthroplasty - is cemented onto the residual humeral head, which eliminates the obligatory humeral head resection and the reaming of the medullary canal.	0.566386902138997
Bipolar shoulder prosthesis are humeral shaft prosthesis with a bi-rotational head system.	0.3837776225819834
Their indication is limited to pre-existing lesions of the rotator cuff and/or the glenoid surface.	0.6721040711227708
The inverse total shoulder prosthesis reverses the articular surface morphology of the humeral head and the glenoid.	0.5497552788200247
The hemispheric glenoid component serves as the centre of rotation for the concave epiphyseal proximal humerus component.	0.3674110929323325
This implant is especially used in cases of massive rotator cuff deficiences.	0.42263441756313835
The role of shoulder prosthesis in treating acute humeral head fractures needs special consideration.	0.45556985346364337
A fracture prosthesis has to restore the exact length of the humerus, the centre of rotation, and the anatomical retroversion.	0.8224240146015201
Positioning of the tubercula and their adequate osteosynthesis is most critical and fundamental to ensure a correct healing process.	0.4297507328463979
A failed consolidation of the tubercula does not lead to a satisfying result.	0.4705256232539265
The shoulder joint replacement can be sufficiently fixated in cemented, cementless or hybrid techniques.	0.46120389368799314
Today several component design variations of cemented glenoid implants exist.	0.24100728461354956
Their main distinction is the fixation system which can be divided into two main groups - the keel - and the peg-shaped glenoid components.	0.8102118132971606
The peg-shaped anchorage system shall guarantee a greater stability against shear-forces.	0.27385607065657913
Cementless glenoid components consist of a polyethylen inlay and a surface treated metal-back with an integrated fixation system.	0.4137460238644201
These fixation systems are object of intensive biomechanical research and range from conventional screw fixation to specialised cone systems and self-cutting cage-screw-systems.	0.40956154650147647
The critical area of cementless glenoid components is the transition zone of the PE-inlay and the metal-back because of high force development.	0.49228987076466374
The question of implanting a hemi- or total shoulder prosthesis is answered by the morphologic changes of the glenoid articular surface, which includes the size of the subchondral defect and the underlying etiology of the shoulder joint disease, and the age of the patient.	0.9393588287061146
Preoperative planning must consist of an adequate radiologic work-up - X-ray, CT or MRI - to accurately assess the glenoid morphology.	0.7396535248942953
G. Walch categorised the different glenoid lesions and developed a very important classification of possible glenoid deformations.	0.46928859139249973
To compare and evaluate the operative results one must consider the different shoulder prosthesis and the discrepancies between a hemi- and a total shoulder prosthetic replacement.	0.6919091174671103
Looking at the loosening and survival rate of the implant the results are related to the type of prosthesis and the preoperative diagnosis.	0.7938115487689741
The Neer total shoulder prosthesis has a 15 year survival rate of 87 %, compared to 74 % of the hemi-prosthesis.	0.648019162053054
The objective for the future has to be to further advance the development of prosthetic components, especially for primary joint replacement in acute humeral head fractures.	0.6819077185380762

In the 120 first liver resections, 82 (68 %) R0, 13 (11 %) R1 and 25 (21 %) R2 excisions were possible.	0.7056318356976358
Median survival after first liver resection was 20 months; after R0 resection a median survival of 28 months and after R1/2 resection of 8 months was achieved.	0.6080699914377574
The 5-year survival rate was 16 % for the total group, 24 % in patients with R0 resection and 0 % for R1/2 resections.	0.9518327946021893
After a second liver resection (n = 14) there was a median survival of 28 months (5-year-survival-rate of 21 %) for all patients and of 41 months (5-year survival rate 38 %) after R0 resection.	0.8633742006289734
Morbidity and mortality after the first liver resection were 32.5 % and 5.8 %, respectively.	0.9724718946792527
In patients without extrahepatic tumor at the time of the first liver resection a median survival of 32 months (5-year survival rate 25 %) and 7 months was achieved after R0 resection and R1/2 resection, respectively.	0.8010375293803341
In case of extrahepatic tumor the median survival was 24 months (5-year survival rate 23 %) for R0 resection compared to 8 months after R1/2 resection.	0.6998681925200888
These data suggest that not the presence of extrahepatic tumor but rather the possibility of a R0 resection is most decisive for the prognosis after liver resection.	0.6417878843377443
We conclude that patients with liver metastases of non-colorectal, non-neuroendocrine tumors may benefit from liver resection.	0.5413717655452983
Similar to colorectal metastases, a second or third liver resection can be worthwhile in selected cases.	0.4988379949139235
Even in more unfavorable tumor entities, several cases of long-term survival were observed after surgical therapy.	0.7532036914003576
Therefore, the indication for liver resection should be considered carefully in every single case.	0.7151007692994839
Generalizations about the outcomes of psychotherapy are essentially based on research on brief therapies with quite short follow-up.	0.38659637063484603
The present paper is a survey of some of the findings in an effectiveness study of psychoanalysis and long-term psychotherapy, typically psychoanalytically oriented, in private practice.	0.7189867602436927
The design was a three-wave panel comprising more than 700 patients.	0.4230432885008562
At the end of the third wave, 418 patients in different phases of treatment remained in the sample.	0.42139612564416523
Across a reconstructed time scale covering roughly seven years, before, during, and after treatment, the 74 psychoanalysis cases described a very positive development, whereas the development among the 331 psychotherapy cases was moderately positive.	0.6771240879707066
The findings emphasize the importance of extended follow-up.	0.41924867142915384
When therapist variables are considered, therapeutic experience had complex or mixed associations with patients outcome.	0.42985777915276446
Especially positive were high age and many years, in private practice, after licensing.	0.629085279986752
Therapeutic ideals and attitudes divided the therapist group in three subgroups, one of which was characterized by purely classical psychoanalytic views on the values of support, friendliness etc.	0.5223618857365945
Therapists in the classically psychoanalytic cluster were found to do poorly with patients in psychotherapy, in contrast to patients in psychoanalysis.	0.6609575859533147
It is concluded that psychoanalysis and psychodynamically oriented psychotherapy are qualitatively different.	0.3564296248628135
Experimental studies and open clinical trials have suggested intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) as a potentially effective treatment of multiple sclerosis (MS).	0.6609584331882568
The Austrian Immunoglobulin in Multiple Sclerosis (AIMS) study tested this assumption by examining 148 patients with relapsing-remitting MS in a randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled fashion (75 IVIg, 73 placebo).	0.49733509380696433
Monthly administration of IVIg in a dosage of 0.15-0.20 g/kg over a period of 2 years slowed the progression of or even reversed disability as evident in a total of 24% of patients and almost halved the number of relapses in comparison to placebo treatment.	0.6579130535216454
Therapeutic efficacy was noted within the first 6 months of treatment and was not correlated to the severity of disability (mild neurological sins without disability to ambulatory with assistance) at study entry.	0.6726929968085096
Overall the magnitude of treatment effects of IVIg was comparable to that reported for beta-interferon and copolymer 1.	0.551084663870547
Further ongoing studies will have to clarify the future role of IVIg in the treatment of MS, in particular in the progressive forms of the disease.	0.7232622722274514

Incidence, etiology and optimal treatment are ill-defined.	0.38316592980812586

In comparison to the remaining study population with stable angina pectoris (8 cases of spontaneous coronary artery dissection among 2852 patients; incidence: 0.3%), the incidence of spontaneous coronary artery dissection was significantly higher in the patient subgroups with acute myocardial infarction (13/450; 2.9%) and with unstable angina pectoris or postinfarction angina (21/501; 4.2%).	0.7755865534404146
Dissection was most frequently located in the left anterior descending coronary artery (19 cases), followed by the right coronary artery (15 cases) and the left circumflex coronary artery (8 cases).	0.8552866349091757
Because of an ambiguous angiographic lesion appearance intravascular ultrasound imaging was performed in 13 patients to confirm the diagnosis.	0.6012273404946067
The presumed etiology of spontaneous coronary artery dissection was atherosclerotic plaque rupture in 35 cases, heavy physical exercise in four cases and hormonal influences related to pregnancy and contraception in one case.	0.5016291114706519
In two cases, no obvious risk factor could be identified.	0.6465018951528891

Results: Complication rates and recurrence rates were similar to those after TEP.	0.6300180658454438

The most frequently used devices were ATMs in Chemnitz and ticket machines and telephone cards in Mannheim.	0.4125038548498629

Telomeres are special DNA-sequences located at the four ends of the chromosomes which are shortened with each cell cycle.	0.43385729933535017

Etiology and treatment are controversially discussed.	0.5602746415017182

Facial neuromyography is an objective electrophysiologic measurement used to assess prognosis for recovery from facial paralysis.	0.40884242000024235
In the present study variability over time of the amplitude ratio in healthy subjects was investigated.	0.7227415577659417
Twenty healthy subjects underwent four neuromyographic tests at intervals of one week.	0.31053112615658035
The study group consisted of 12 males and 8 females.	0.5384652822218251
Ages ranged from 23 to 36 years.	0.25082198970329517
The stimulation intensity required for supramaximal stimulation was 14.6 mA on average.	0.48921637117064104

The hypothesis of symmetrical evoked facial compound potentials was not supported by our data.	0.3922969789732117

This type of pin fixation is our preferred osteosynthesis in the treatment of unstable Colles' fracture because it allows immediate functional therapy.	0.5135644688723033
It represents a modification of Kapandji's dynamic KWO, compensating for the insufficient volar stability by means of the conventional static KWO.	0.4603530096284497
Clinical experience according to the anatomical and functional results, was very encouraging suggesting that a clinical concept based on the biomechanical principles of combined KWO and its single components should be constituted.	0.6901788519439874
Simulation of the unstable Colles' fracture was realized by dorsal wedge osteotomy of the distal end of the radius using cadaveric material.	0.5434319544139911
This fracture model was subsequently pinned using the different KWO types and tested by a standardized vector energy testing device regarding its stability in the four main loading directions.	0.4944537655738132
The combined KWO unifies the advantage of volar stability of the conventional KWO with the high dorsal stability of dynamic KWO.	0.5787329572689175
The main functional principle of dynamic KWO with regard to its axial stability consists in the repositioning of the dorsal bone fragmentation zone and hence the reconstitution of cortical load transmission.	0.4699787269420708
Besides its good stabilization, dynamic KWO also leads to optimal alignment of the distal metaphyseal fragment.	0.5530393098975932

In total, 12 patients (4-14 years old; 7 female, 5 male) with different grades of mandibular hypoplasia received osteochondral grafts (7 costochondral, 5 iliac crest; observation period 4-9 years).	0.752468966460238
In 5 patients (10-12 years old; 1 female, 4 male), distraction osteogenesis was performed (observation period 10 months to 3 1/2 years).	0.6887897933016749
In the results, according to the literature, the range of growth after osteochondral grafting varied considerably, approximate normal growth was noticed in only two cases.	0.549450091085225
On the other hand, all patients treated by distraction osteogenesis showed a stable increase of bone length as expected.	0.6685349014315002
After osteochondral grafts, adequate growth is to be expected in the minority of cases and it does not seem predictable in individual cases.	0.7047923253721632
Therefore, the indication for osteochondral grafts should be restricted to severe hypoplasia, where the local amount of bone does not allow the use of a distraction device, and to cases where support of the mandibula at the skull base is necessary.	0.7447308556487225

Compared with conventional miniplates this mesh is outstanding for its considerably higher stability due to its given geometry.	0.4249771516790516

Myocardial scintigraphy using thallium-201 and positron emission tomography with metabolic imaging of myocardial glucose metabolism, using fluorine-18 fluoro-deoxyglucose, are today the most widely used nuclear methods for the assessment of myocardial viability.	0.5463600956751153
Besides the prediction of reversible regional and global myocardial dysfunction following coronary revascularization, both methods have demonstrated the ability to identify patient subgroups who will benefit most with regard to cardiac prognosis and survival and those patients in whom coronary revascularization has a limited effect with regard to survival and cardiac events.	0.576300998208531

In the ankle (talocrural) joint, the lower end of the tibia and fibula embrace the trochlea tali.	0.7243826458164265
Thus, an approximately uniaxial joint is formed which permits dorsiflexion and plantarflexion of the foot against the leg.	0.5491078681354922
Due to the geometry of the trochlea tali, conjunct lateral rotation of the fibula against the tibia occurs at the tibiofibular articulations synchronously with active dorsiflexion at the ankle joint.	0.49457762227119645
Movements at the talocrural joints are mainly limited by the opposing muscles as well as by strong collateral ligaments.	0.4757455217716674
Talus and calcaneus form a functional unit connected by posterior and anterior articulations.	0.39758119488368837
The posterior articulation is the subtalar (talocalcaneal) joint; in the anterior articulation, talar facets of the calcaneus together with the posterior surface of the navicular and the superior fibrocartilaginous surface of the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament form a concavity for the talar head.	0.575267304713579
Thus, the talocalcaneonavicular joint is a compound and - like the subtalar joint - a multiaxial articulation.	0.7413843610561534
On the weight-bearing foot, the distal tarsus and metatarsus are pronated and supinated against the talus in order to maintain plantigrade contact.	0.48674071934629304
When the foot is off the ground, these movements are modified to eversion and inversion, also involving the calcaneocuboid joint.	0.5203508580161077
In addition, movements between the calcaneus and cuboid also occur during pronative or supinative changes between the fore- and hindfoot.	0.5162453059960522
Limitation of movements is due to leg muscles as well as strong ligaments.	0.3794398078831864
Finally, the cuneonavicular, cuboideonavicular, intercuneiform and cuneocuboid joints permit some additional alterations of the loaded foot in contact with the ground.	0.44991567767491725

The tumor cells are immunoreactive for endothelial markers (CD 31, CD 34, factor VIII associated antigen) and express also histiocytic antigens (CD 68, lysozyme, Cathepsin D, alpha-1-antitrypsin, alpha-1-antichymotrypsin) as well as CD 8.	0.5887544972833264

Despite major advances in knowledge and development of efficient techniques for pain control, many patients on surgical wards suffer from modest to severe pain following surgery or trauma.	0.5242227596866408
Therefore, in the University Hospital of Kiel, Germany, an anaesthesiology-based acute pain service (APS) was started in 1985 to improve this situation.	0.7165469562455895
The anaesthesiologist in training who manages the recovery unit serves as an APS for surgical wards and is supervised by a consultant.	0.4686380406813476
The anaesthesists on call are responsible after regular working hours.	0.23764687053236802
The activities of the APS are as follows: 1.	0.433413053415788
Induction of sufficient postoperative analgesia in the recovery unit for all surgical patients.	0.5649633618043403
Clinical rounds on all patients receiving epidural analgesia (EA), other forms of regional analgesia, or patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) every morning and throughout the day if necessary.	0.5860983244316685
Additional consultations for postoperative pain management for other patients on request.	0.5071584575503602
Assessment and documentation of the clinical status of the patient, quality of analgesia, and side effects.	0.8496889678965702
Writing orders for further treatment.	0.315750564935702
Continuing consultations and informal education for ward nurses, physiotherapists, and surgical staff; formal medical training for ward nurses in postoperative pain management.	0.5659107209219677
From 1985 to 1992, 1947 patients on normal wards were treated (EA: 1736, PCA: 183).	0.38882838465491104
Epidural analgesia was performed using a standard protocol with bupivacaine 0.175% - 0.25% infused continuously with top-ups if needed (mean 240 mg/day, range 75 - 600 mg; median duration 7 days, range 1 - 53, Table 1).	0.7211383034668932
Demand for further treatment was proved by day-to-day withdrawal.	0.5398449349231984
Since the introduction of an APS, complications of EA such as hypotension (1985/1986: 5.1%; 1987/1992: 0.5%, Table 3) and insufficient analgesia due to dislocation or other technical complications could be reduced significantly (Table 3).	0.6663048868412131
Dermal infections were seen in 2.6% of patients, with a significantly higher incidence in patients with arteriosclerotic diseases (4.1%).	0.9210708670990708
Epidural opioids were used in only 46 selected cases on surgical wards.	0.48451197140916624
Nevertheless, 2 cases of marked respiratory depression occurred.	0.6560768109128375
The overall risk of complications during postoperative EA could be reduced from 1 : 11 cases in the first 2 years to 1 : 20 in the last 6 years since introducing the APS.	0.6720252661218795
For other regional procedures (e.g., interpleural analgesia) no complications were recorded.	0.4723410891838846
PCA was performed using a standard protocol with tramadol or piritramide without background infusion (Table 6).	0.5556224900293774
The loading dose was titrated in the recovery unit.	0.4649455437517175
The median duration of PCA was 4 days (range 1 - 23); the median dose of piritramide was 45 mg/day (range 3 - 226 mg).	0.7308526075898195
Two cases of somnolence and respiratory depression occurred.	0.45979130478918634
In this period there were 8 potential life-threatening complications due to postoperative pain therapy; 4 occurred during standard surgical pain management (3 cases of severe respiratory depression after i.m.	0.7802374560768794
piritramide (unsuccessfull resuscitation), tramadol, and buprenorphine; 1 small child with multiorgan failure after paracetamol intoxication).	0.45329169786534357
In those cases the APS was not involved.	0.46148650278502895
There are insufficient data for comparison of the incidence of complications following standard management of postoperative pain relief without an APS, i.e., i.m.	0.6316316116150036
injections of opioids on request, but severe and sometimes lethal complications have been reported.	0.5906580559523313
Since the majority of patients used EA or PCA for several days, it is again emphasised that these techniques should not be restricted to high-dependency areas such as intensive care or recovery units.	0.5749635299674496
The introduction of an APS is an adequate approach to more efficient and safer pain management on surgical wards.	0.4586378743430991
This requires standard protocols (Table 7), standardised monitoring and trained ward nurses.	0.48171403179638833

Topical corticosteroids (CS) are frequently used to treat of allergic contact dermatitis, so that their own potential for sensitization is rarely detected.	0.674115220814066
However, increasing numbers of hypersensitivity reactions to corticosteroids have been reported during the last 10 years, and allergic skin reactions to over 50 particular compounds have been observed.	0.7115871554682842
CS must now be regarded as a rather frequent contact allergen, the prevalence being twice as high in women as in men.	0.5994777656275265
Contact allergy to CS is clinically characterized by a chronic and persistent, corticosteroid-resistant dermatitis.	0.48266548100381934
In general, hypersensitivity to CS is a type I and/or type IV mediated allergic reaction.	0.5357975439223933
Cross-sensitivity between individual corticosteroid preparations has been described owing to their closely related chemical structures (e.g.	0.39317773574576725
hydrocortisone and tixocortol pivalate).	0.1229063027937644
Contact allergy to CS can be confirmed by patch-tests, intradermal injection tests or application tests; because of the delayed appearance of positive skin reactions a prolonged evaluation period of up to 120 h is recommended.	0.4785638816859658
For routine screening the use of the patient's own material and of tixocortol pivalate and budesonide as test marker substances seems appropriate.	0.5845040369907446
The development of further marker substances is a target for ongoing research.	0.3949457024475937
The alliance concepts are defined as being the description of the dynamic interaction of all cognitive and emotional factors which promote the analytic process.	0.561883385234363
The historical significance and the development of the three predominant alliance concepts, these being the implicit "standard alliance" of Freud, Zetzel's therapeutic alliance and Greenson's working alliance, are to be described.	0.6425416523027097
All alliance concepts refer to a general, essentially reality-oriented relationship anchored in the personal and the human domain, which forms the background for the therapeutic process and the basis for the analytic interpretation work.	0.6559873482863576
Nonetheless, the dynamic force of the alliances is substantiated by factors of the transference.	0.6350070317624866
The alliances are therefore not faced with the transference, but rather with the resistance.	0.6282326493852315
We report on a 15-months-old girl with a history of recurrent phlegmones of the lower eyelid, dacryocystitides, conjunctivities and mucositis together with growth-retardation, chronic obstipation and anal prolaps.	0.5861219541153746
During a period of 19 days absolute neutropenia was observed.	0.3047500258432699
Retrospectively, neutrophil counts were between 0-500/µl from birth on.	0.3439482422400468
Bone marrow biopsy revealed an arrest of maturation of granulopoiesis at the stage of promyelocytes.	0.45171751983960035

There were no oscillations of counts of other blood cell lines.	0.5495028030131152
Growth retardation and prolaps of anus normalized, and few intercurrent bacterial infections, pneumonia and impetigo contagiosa occurred.	0.4490089444618194

A measurement system was developed that permits objective comparisons of the sound conduction of middle ear implants.	0.4369704577552003
The implants are fitted into a mechanical middle ear model which approximates the impedances of the eardrum and the inner ear.	0.41692638029497303
A defined signal within the frequency range of 0-5 kHz is provided by a miniaturized loudspeaker at the input to the model and is  measured by a probe microphone.	0.5662026989377967
Displacement of an artificial stapes footplate at the output of the model is measured by a fiberoptic probe with a sensitivity of 5 nm.	0.5209138393128323
The transmission function is calculated as the quotient of the output and the input signal.	0.45785434369431766

Intubation and Positive End Expiratory Pressure Ventilation (PEEP) is a well established therapeutic strategy for impaired lung function, particularly following blunt chest trauma.	0.6636412594882921
Complications of this regime are however also well known and pose the question why non-invasive forms of respiratory assistance such as Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) have only gained minor popularity.	0.5527838984228608
In a prospective study, 30 patients who had suffered blunt chest trauma were treated with CPAP administered by mask.	0.7575718214399138
The regime consisted of continuous administration of CPAP by a face-mask, with gradually increasing periods of spontaneous breathing.	0.46859439610522907
Initially a FiO2 of 0.33 (range 0,28-0,38) proved necessary.	0.7219538057942789
The initial CPAP level was 7 mbar (range 5-8) with an (Assisted Spontaneous Breathing) ASB of 15 mbar (range 13-18).	0.7535454846026366
FiO2 and CPAP/ASB levels were subsequently gradually reduced until no longer necessary.	0.28345877538187864
In all patients intubation and ventilation was avoided by this regimen.	0.5899071369949077
The treatment was well accepted by all patients and common ventilation associated complications such as pneumonia did not occur.	0.560404481237234
In comparison with the former standard method of treatment the average ICU stay was dramatically reduced, principally due to not having to gradually wean patients from ventilation and sedation.	0.5331122302668457
Other positive benefits include normal communication and feeding with active early mobilisation leading to faster recovery, both physical and psychological.	0.4641974660044907

Current methods for articular cartilage repair are unpredictable with respect to clinical success.	0.4222369392307364
In the present study, we investigated the ability of cells from articular cartilage, perichondrium, and costochondral resting zone to form new cartilage when loaded onto biodegradable scaffolds and implanted into calf muscle pouches of nu/nu mice.	0.5763427604337344
Prior in vitro studies showed that platelet derived growth factor-BB (PDGF-BB), but not transforming growth factor beta-1 (TGF-1), basic fibroblast growth factor, or bone morphogenetic protein-2 promoted proliferation and extracellular matrix sulfation of resting zone chondrocytes without causing the cells to exhibit a hypertrophic chondrocyte phenotype.	0.6062667236307929
TGF-1 has also been shown to stimulate chondrogenesis by multipotent chondroprogenitor cells like those in the perichondrium.	0.5122305614803174
In addition, PDGF-BB has been shown to modulate chondrogensis by resting zone cells implanted in poly(D,L-lactide-co-glycolide) (PLG) scaffolds.	0.49680944762253776
In the present study we examined whether the cartilage formation is dependent on state of chondrocyte maturation and whether the pretreatment of chondrocytes with growth factors has an influence on the cartilage formation.	0.6675896538127785
Scaffolds were manufactured from 80 % PLG with a 75:25 lactide:glycolide ratio and 20 % modified PLG with a 50:50 lactide:glycolide ratio (PLG-H scaffolds).	0.5218591009584049
For each experimental group, four nude mice received two identical implants, one in each calf muscle resulting in an N = 8 implants: PLG-H scaffolds alone; PLG-H scaffolds with cells derived from either the femoral articular cartilage, costochondral periochondrium, or costochondral resting zone cartilage of 125 g male Sprague-Dawley rats; PLG-H scaffolds with either articular chondrocytes or resting zone chondrocytes that were pretreated with 37,5 ng/ml rhPDGF-BB for 4 h or 24 h before implantation, or with perichondrial cells treated with PDGF-BB plus 0,22 ng/ml rhTGF-1 for 4 h and 24 h. At 4 or 8 weeks after implantation, samples were harvested and analyzed histomorphometrically for new cartilage formed, area of residual implant and area of fibrous connective tissue.	0.5272111506897423
Only resting zone cells showed the ability to form new cartilage at a heterotopic site in this study.	0.5357676519746577
There was no neocartilage found in nude mice with implants loaded with either articular chondrocytes or perichondrial cells.	0.39080524716895515
Pretreatment of resting zone chondrocytes for 4 h prior to implantation significantly increased the amount of newly formed cartilage after 8 weeks and suppressed chondrocyte hypertrophy.	0.585659283205814
The amount of fibrous connective tissue around implants containing either articular chondrocytes or perichondrial cells decreased with time, whereas the amount of fibrous connective tissue around implants containing resting zone chondrocytes pretreated with PDGF-BB was increased.	0.44994180517080323
The results showed that resting zone cells can be successfully incorporated into biodegradable porous PLG scaffolds and can induce new cartilage formation in a non-weight-bearing site.	0.5677619878748437
Articular chondrocytes as well as perichondrial cells did not have the capacity for neochondrogenesis when implanted heterotopically in this model.	0.46488758308914546
Bone tumors represent a group of tumors of various dignity.	0.5271681091930875
In spite of this single tumor entities may display strong morphological resemblance to each other which can in turn result in profound difficulties in differential diagnosis.	0.40313145882045043
The biological behaviour of a tumor is mainly determined by its rate of proliferation.	0.6174354845791312
In this study the rate of proliferation of 64 bone tumors (30 high-grade central osteosarcomas, 6 low-grade osteosarcomas, 8 giant cell tumors, 8 aneurysmatic bone cysts, 5 osteoidosteomas/osteoblastomas, 7 fibrous dysplasias and 5 cases of a myositis ossificans) were analysed.	0.8497607142669132
Immunohistochemistry was performed on paraffin-embedded tissue sections using the MIB-1 monoclonal antibody.	0.5449693069394602
MIB-1 recognizes the proliferation-associated Ki-67 protein which is expressed during the active phases of the cell cycle but cannot be detected in senescent cells.	0.5728998450301706
Among high-grade central osteosarcomas a significantly higher rate of proliferation (average value 30 %) was found in comparison with low-grade osteosarcomas and other benign intraosseous bone tumors.	0.8785160666286296
This approach proved to be very useful in the distinction between high-grade and low-grade osteosarcomas as well as bone-forming intraosseous tumors.	0.8279226003763253

Myasthenic crisis is a lifethreatening complication of myasthenia gravis due to respiratory failure and inability to swallow and cough up secretions.	0.4317803204849522
Frequent causes are intercurrent infections, fluctuations due to the natural history of the disease and insufficient immunosuppressive treatment prior to the crisis.	0.694517115381859
Early referral to an experienced neurologist is essential.	0.26831084096454494
Specific therapy consists of symptomatic treatment with cholinesterase inhibitors, crisis management with plasmapheresis or immunoglobulins and immunosuppression with clucocorticoids.	0.3804288136618721
Infections must be treated vigorously.	0.24321285686740382
Thymectomy in patients with previously unrecognized myasthenia gravis is never urgently indicated and should be postponed until the patient is stabilized.	0.5455140005647854
In cases of impending respiratory failure and severe swallowing difficulties, early and elective admission to a specialized neurological intensive care unit and elective intubation should be performed.	0.6033924621376517
Adequate nursing care of intubated patients and a set of prophylactic measures are essential to avoid complications adversely affecting prognosis.	0.4820493672063539
Whenever it can be achieved, the best therapy of myasthenic crisis is its prevention by appropriate long-term management and follow-up of patients with myasthenia gravis.	0.7986025140297321

After orthopedic surgery, skeletal muscle will enter the rehabilitation process in weakened condition due to the following characteristics.	0.5462603451932958

The resulting immobilization leads to muscular atrophy, with a loss of calcium homeostasis and oxidative stress being of etiological significance.	0.5279644971899619
Degeneration of muscle fibers as well as regeneration occurs in muscle while still immobilized.	0.3925988123462745
After remobilization, the muscle has impaired functional capacity and frequently shows disturbances in its innervation pattern.	0.48635008038123095
High mechanical loading should therefore be avoided, and electrical stimulation may be applied to facilitate recovery.	0.600196950904904

This analysis was based on a literature review of mostly retrospective publications.	0.6258024000479845
Data concerning the interval between surgery and radiotherapy were correlated with the locoregional control, incidence of distant metastases and prognosis of breast cancer, lung carcinoma, and head and neck carcinomas.	0.7268783901842931
The reviewed data did not show a clear relationship of the time interval between surgery and start of radiotherapy and locoregional control.	0.6254007987812221
However, evaluation of the data was difficult, because in most publications, retrospective analyses were performed and other prognostically more relevant parameters may influence locoregional control stronger than the time interval.	0.6630075884558753

In patients with breast cancer who do not receive chemotherapy, there are inconsistent reports in the literature.	0.6366658265614163

Cisatracurium (51W89, Nimbex, Glaxo-Wellcome), an intermediate-acting non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent, is a stereoisomer of atracurium.	0.5049713074438862
Histamine releasing propensities and serum tryptase level have been investigated after administration of cisatracurium (3xED95, 5xED95) or vecuronium (3xED90) in surgical patients.	0.6043597993559606
Methods: After approval by our institutional review board, 62 patients (ASA I-II) were randomly assigned to three groups to receive either 3xED95 or 5xED95 cisatracurium, or 3xED90 vecuronium as a rapid bolus.	0.5790446520217213
A prick test was done the day before by scarification of the skin in the forearm.	0.6392136980738461
After premedication with 2 mg lormetazepam, anaesthesia was induced with thiopentone (4-12 mg/kg) and maintained with O2/N2O and isoflurane (1.5-2 vol.%).	0.6865030233538202
Six minutes after thiopentone, the patients received the relaxant, and after further 6 min 0.1-0.2 mg fentanyl was given and the trachea was intubated.	0.8845120690695015
Heart rate (HR) and blood pressure (BP) were monitored every minute.	0.6610109061748038
Blood samples for histamine were withdrawn 5 min prior 3 and 5 min after each drug administration (thiopentone, relaxants).	0.46339735821972367
Plasma histamine was measured by radioimmunoassay (RIA) with a sensitivity of approximately 10 pg/ml.	0.6197771806906336
Additionally, serum tryptase was measured by RIA at baseline (-10 and  -1 min) and 15 and 60 min after the relaxant administration.	1.0092916121639934
Levels for histamine >1000 pg/ml and for tryptase >2 µg/ml were considered significant.	0.6495278961509823
Cutaneous signs of histamine release were documented.	0.3160263971193375
Results: Ten patients showed a positive prick-test reaction.	0.6315695928679543
Only after thiopentone some cutaneous signs (4 flush, 1 erythema) of histamine release were observed.	0.7563401246997717
There were no cutaneous signs of histamine release correlating with cardiovascular changes.	0.4917354384536286
Analysis of the blood samples demonstrated no significant increase in the histamine level in all three groups.	0.8616026935384716
Only in 1 patient was a significant higher histamine level (1133 pg/ml) measured 5 min after 5xED95 cisatracurium.	0.6787977634975523
All measurements of serum tryptase were within the physiological limits.	0.4424458635763212
Discussion: In this study, with the particular time course of drug administration, neither cisatracurium nor vecuronium increased plasma histamine levels.	0.7213619019446599
Only after 5xED95 cisatracurium was 1 elevated histamine level documented after 5 min.	0.3386463381468444
In several studies increased histamine levels have been described, but without clinical manifestations.	0.7645133517150551
It is known that cutaneous signs can occur without increased plasma histamine levels due to the structural heterogeneity of mast cells.	0.5381411625426338
The cutaneous reactions in this study were caused by thiopentone.	0.7545186567679252
The tryptase values were within normal limits even in the patient with histamine release.	0.6895887704921709
No relationship between the positive results in the prick test and the incidence of cutaneous reactions and/or histamine release for drugs used in the induction of anaesthesia was observed.	0.7469857624603096
Whether cisatracurium has a potential for immunologic release is unknown.	0.37420522837707393

Median radiation dose was 56 Gy (range: 45 to 66 Gy).	0.5003429352279625
Chemotherapy consisted of 4 to 6 courses of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) (420 mg/m2/d) and leucovorin (200 mg/m2/d).	0.7475645027809933
Median follow-up was 37 months.	0.6592060800732462

There were no statistically significant differences between patients treated with radiochemotherapy vs radiotherapy in terms of 5-year survival (63% after radiochemotherapy vs 53% after radiotherapy, p = 0.16), relapse-free survival (52% vs 50%) and locoregional control (69% vs 67%).	0.829655914104353
UICC Stage III disease was associated with high failure rates (40% pelvic recurrences and 53% distant metastases).	0.547703141117582
There was a statistically significant difference in terms of the incidence of distant metastases between the 2 treatment modalities for patients with Stage III disease (49% 5-year probability for developing distant metastases after radiochemotherapy vs 66% after radiotherapy, p = 0.047).	0.6767890810232793
In a multivariate analysis, the addition of chemotherapy, lymph node stage and grading were independent prognostic factors for survival.	0.6108142584277934
Severe late toxicity was documented in 5% of treated patients.	0.6515998164804907

Apnea, bradycardia and oxygen desaturation in infants with very low birth weight are common findings in neonatal intensive care.	0.4657558513032543
The prognostic significance of their intensity and frequency and the principles of treatment, however, are controversial.	0.5513280067754234
The universal aim, in order to prevent traumatization of the lung, is to ventilate infants with very low birth weight for as short a time as possible.	0.6250602060734262
Therefore drugs such as theophylline, aminophylline and doxapram and techniques such as nasal CPAP have been studied in our neonatal intensive care unit.	0.44408461067337873
In these studies we developed a treatment algorithm.	0.5535741149207245
In two clinically controlled studies performed successively we first proved that sodium acetate theophylline given intravenously has the same efficacy as aminophylline.	0.34643891611237854
As aminophylline has more side effects, sodium acetate theophylline is preferable.	0.30164299637907643
Bradycardia, apnea and desaturation were registered from the print-out of the monitoring system's trend analysis and in a polysomnographic study during steady-state conditions.	0.5134182728497663
In a historical study we were able to prove that intravenous injection of aminophylline is superior to oral administration.	0.487274498171122
We demonstrated equal efficacy of doxapram and theophylline; however, doxapram reduced the rate of apnea significantly more during the first 3 days of treatment.	0.5284721401958639
In a retrospective study we analyzed the efficacy of nasal CPAP as the third level of treatment.	0.6101588428347821
The rate of bradycardia, apnea and desaturation was significantly reduced during CPAP and respiratory rate and oxygenation improved.	0.45243025951323074
The algorithm developed established theophylline with 5 mg/ kg as bolus infusion over 20 min, followed by 3 mg/kg BID as the first line of treatment.	0.5151015351461171
Only if a quick therapeutic response was desirable was doxapram the first drug of choice (indication >=4 bradycardias below 80/min, 4 desaturations below 80% or 2 apneas of >=20 s over 2 h).	0.5605457989399052
After 48 h an additional second drug was added if we could still observe >=3 apneas, 15 bradycardias or 15 desaturations over this period.	0.4009473864991329
Nasal CPAP was introduced as the third line of treatment.	0.458607466551874
With this treatment algorithm we were able to reduce the time on a respirator of infants with very low birth weight from 4.9 to 3.4 days (P<0.01).	0.6415713195741166
An evaluation of similar treatment algorithms in multi-institutional studies is indicated.	0.3354642066453221

Sixty-four percent of patients had no, 11% had more than one complication.	0.8689822143044258
Mortality was 0 in groups 1 and 2, but 35.3% in group 3.	0.9125710164206253
The most frequent complication in groups 1 and 2 was pneumonia (13.9%) followed by cardiac complications (4.6%), and renal insufficiency (3.7%).	0.8193096674995105
In group 3 respiratory insufficiency demonstrated the highest incidence (23.5%), followed by renal insufficiency (21%) and pneumonia (17.6%).	0.6765215238912741

APC resistance was first discovered in 1993.	0.3083310470187668
It is the most frequent cause of thrombophilia in Europe and North America.	0.6851826295394393
In more than 90% of cases, the underlying cause of APC resistance is a single point mutation in the factor V gene.	0.7238983861330077
Heterozygous patients have a between five- and ten-fold higher risk of developing venous thrombosis, while in homozygous patients the risk is increased up to between 50- and 100-fold.	0.7921201985104174
Where there is a previous history of thrombosis, a careful investigation of the coagulation system, in particular a determination of the APC ratio, is recommended prior to surgery.	0.8545556038569724
In patients with APC resistance, a body-weight-specific thrombosis prophylaxis with heparin is recommended.	0.6750254947764116
Heterozygous patients only need anticoagulation when additional risk conditions are present, while homozygous patients with thromboembolic disease should be anticoagulated over a long period of time.	0.5410315410666242

Pyomyositis is an acute bacterial infection with abscess formation in the skeletal muscles mostly due to Staphylococcus aureus.	0.4726658116220401
The disease is found more often in males.	0.6984101463008274
Since the patients symptoms and the clinical and laboratory findings are relatively unspecific, the clinical diagnosis of pyomyositis can present difficulties.	0.9847433462922505
Furthermore, cases of pyomyositis are rare in non-tropical countries and some physicians may not be familiar with it.	0.6061906531582337
If not diagnosed and treated properly, pyomyositis can lead to sepsis and death.	0.4422360519105405
Although the pathogenesis of the disease has not yet been clarified, some predisposing factors of forensic interest are well known: (trivial) trauma or vigorous exercise of the affected skeletal muscles, small potentially "septic" foci in other tissues or internal organs and a preexisting immunodeficiency, e. g. in diabetes mellitus, intravenous drug abusers or individuals suffering from HIV.	0.6495334785576914
Three cases of "non-tropical" pyomyositis with fatal outcome are presented and the literature on the subject is reviewed with special reference to epidemiological and etiological factors, taking forensic aspects, histomorphologic findings and the problems of post-mortem diagnosis of pyomyositis into consideration.	0.6901437141514376

Interfragmentary movement and size of the fracture gap influence fracture healing.	0.6133288289753199
Limited movements promote callus formation and may result in increased mechanical stability.	0.4585375409693977
Although larger movements still promote callus formation, the bony consolidation of the fracture is hampered.	0.7062240802084447

A combination of large movement and large gap bears the risk of non-union.	0.5032151659246877

In recent years, however, new experimental approaches to its effects on the cellular and molecular level and the availability of pure ketamine enantiomers contributed substantially to the understanding of its complex neuropharmacology.	0.56101745748382

In view of the dismal prognosis of unresected bronchial cancer, surgical resection should be encouraged even in patients with reduced cardiopulmonary function.	0.6160229106074292

Criteria of functional operability should be based on percent of predicted value, so that patient's age, sex, and height will be taken into consideration.	0.5756654498351101
Exercise testing offers the advantage that both pulmonary and cardiac risk can be evaluated simultaneously.	0.5172440228225953
The high predictive value of maximal oxygen uptake (VO2max) in assessing postoperative morbidity and mortality is established.	0.644981101520875
The calculation of predicted postoperative lung function (ppo) is of importance.	0.6306227090942931
The postoperative values for the forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1-ppo), the transfer factor (TL,CO-ppo), and VO2max-ppo can be predicted by using the same formula.	0.6338650756217105
Patients with nearly normal lung function (FEV1, TL,CO > 75 % predicted) and no concomitant cardiac disease can undergo lung resection right up to pneumonectomy without further diagnostic procedures.	0.6622283164984556
In the others, FEV1-ppo and TL,CO-ppo should be estimated first by taking into account the number of segments to be resected.	0.5104083465999285
Patients with values < 30 % predicted are usually regarded as being inoperable, whereas values > 40 % predicted qualify for resection without the need for further diagnostics.	0.7479088375357661
VO2max < 10 ml/kg/min or < 40 % predicted are prohibitive for surgery.	0.739893021103834
If VO2max is > 20 ml/kg/min or > 75 % predicted, functional operability without limitation is given.	0.7019878532459852
For those cases where diagnostic uncertainty still remains, FEV1-ppo, TL,CO-ppo, and VO2max-ppo can be calculated by means of quantitative lung scans.	0.4928560222461529
Patients with either FEV1-ppo and TL,CO-ppo < 30 % predicted or VO2max-ppo < 8 ml/kg/min or < 35 % predicted are deemed inoperable.	0.7052348543418121

Based on a case report, we offer brief guidelines on the perioperative management of patients with Sleep-Apnea-Syndrome (SAS) who present with a high incidence of a difficult airway and a high risk of respiratory depression during the perioperative period.	0.8072392777835531
A 39 year old male patient with a body mass index of 34,22 kg/m2 and receiving continuous-positive-airway-pressure- (CPAP) therapy for known SAS was scheduled for elective plastic surgery.	0.6996478454285864
After induction of anaesthesia and direct laryngoscopy no adequate airway could be established and the patient became hypoxic, hypercapnic and developed hypotension and bradycardia.	0.6148794048439666
With the use of a laryngeal mask airway the patient was stabilized and did not show neurologic sequale after immediate awakening.	0.6535920342079918
The following fiberoptic intubation of the awake patient, still showing tendency of upper airway obstruction, confirmed the difficult anatomical structures.	0.5161875594110021
The subsequent general anesthesia was uneventful.	0.27751004963343195
The patient received CPAP therapy and was monitored during the first postoperative night in the Intensive Care Unit.	0.6541440630125503
He made an uneventful recovery.	0.1882742808514887
He was advised to have regional anaesthesia or planned fiberoptic intubation, where possible, in the case of further anesthetic intervention.	0.6154994498037817
SAS has major implications for the anaesthesiologist and whenever patients exhibiting the high risk factors (obesity, male sex, history of intense snoring, impaired daytime performance, nonrefreshing daytime naps) are presented for surgery this condition should be considered.	0.6181131665060671
Elective surgery should be postponed until after adequate examination and treatment when necessary.	0.4310594978131364
Patients with SAS should always be suspected of having cardiopulmonary dysfunctions such as hypertension, cardiac dysrhythmia or cor pulmonale.	0.44784722696008217
It is most important to avoid sedative premedication, to initiate CPAP therapy preoperatively, to encourage regional anaesthesia if possible and to ensure close monitoring over the complete perioperative period.	0.6289984728505285
Planned fiberoptic intubation, preferably with surgical personnel available for an emergency airway, is a safe method for the induction of anaesthesia.	0.7615708775045886
Postoperatively, patients are at high risk from respiratory depression, even in the awake state.	0.8610086438665946
Postoperative opioid analgesia, no matter what route, should only be given under close monitoring.	0.6146867596643798
Independently of regional or general anaesthesia there is an increased risk of respiratory depression in the middle of the first postoperative week, suspected to be caused by the catching up on lost REM-sleep, due to shifts in the normal sleep pattern during the first postoperative days.	0.7308477986226601

The indications for surgery were either proven infection or persistence of symptoms.	0.5280118028739943

There was no significant difference between the two groups regarding pre- and postoperative parameters.	0.8588260991834064
The surgical technique involved a blunt necrosectomy followed by closed packing with Penrose drains.	0.4167691193934495
This technique produced the lowest reported mortality of 6.2 % with a reoperation rate of only 17 %, demonstrating that even with sterile necrosis surgical management can be carried out safely.	0.6967907320378034

Therefore, the prevention of such episodes is of great clinical importance.	0.6732855498086388
The absorption of large volumes of irrigation fluid is a major problem in transurethral prostatic surgery (TUR-P).	0.5415901138854734
Various indicators have been tested to monitor fluid absorption with regard to continuous registration and sufficient accuracy.	0.406651373893654
The volumetric fluid balance is not suitable as a routine method because of its inaccuracy.	0.5857082789719252
Easily accessible parameters are unspecific because of surgical bleeding (haematocrit [Hct]), or are interfered with by physiological counter-regulatory actions (serum sodium [Na] concentration).	0.42284500748952286
In 1986 Hulten et al.	0.16384534449127222
suggested adding 2% ethanol to the irrigation fluid as a marker and investigated it intermittently in the expired air with an alcohol-test appliance.	0.5004654854943943
In a prospective clinical study of 17 patients undergoing TUR-P under spinal anaesthesia, expiratory concentrations of alcohol that was added to the irrigation fluid (2% ethanol in Purisole, Fresenius, Bad Homburg) were monitored.	0.7575716337286709
Gas was continuously sampled from the nasopharynx through a nasal cannula and the ethanol concentration was measured using a modified diverting anaesthetic gas monitor (Normac, Datex, Helsinki) that allows continuous as well as early detection of the absorbed irrigation fluid with reliable accuracy for clinical use.	0.5111020032479673
In addition, at intervals of 10 minutes we measured blood alcohol, endtidal alcohol (Alcotest 7110, Drauml;ger, Lübeck), haematocrit, serum Na concentration, and blood gases.	0.557288379682918
Sixty-eight measurements were obtained from the 17 patients.	0.4975998092303048
As shown in other studies, serum Na (r2 = 0.68) and Hct (r2 = 0.39) correlated poorly with the irrigation fluid as determined by serum alcohol levels.	0.5143091304303377
In contrast, the expiratory alcohol measurements with the alcotest 7110 (r2 = 0.93) and Normac devices (r2 = 0.85) were closely related.	0.6203870380298178
Continuous monitoring of the expiratory alcohol concentration with a Normac monitor closely reflects blood alcohol concentrations, and may hence serve as a useful semiquantitative monitor of irrigation fluid absorption during TUR-P.	0.5646275310234004
Between 1986 and 1996, 21 patients had a tibiocalcanear arthrodesis.	0.5736751156814102
Indications for surgery were in all cases either osteomyelitis or avascular necrosis of the talus.	0.7143046983325599
External stabilisation was used in 17 patients due to severe soft tissue damage or extensive infection of the talus, internal screw fixation was used in four patients.	0.8472449380569682
There were eight complications in seven patients, one patient had a below the knee amputation.	0.7664199235763228
The leg length discrepancies after resection of the talus was equalised in four cases with callus distraction using an Ilisarov ring fixator.	0.6879806816194131
Follow up evaluation was available in 18 patients after an average of 38 months (12-86 mo.).	0.6637200163882099
There were no infectious recurrenies during the follow up period and a solid fusion was achieved in all patients that were followed.	0.861804142372878
According to a modified Kitaoka score, results were excellent and good in 12 of the 18patients.	0.697769884711338

Mediastinal lymph-node sampling guided by the intraoperative aspect of lymph nodes is performed in 59 % of the departments.	0.7377100935043203

The known benefits of arthroscopy include better visualization of the entire joint, limited dissection, and thorough irrigation.	0.6350005589440202

From May 1995 to November 1997, 34 patients with intra-articular fractures of the knee were treated by arthroscopic reduction and fixation.	0.7546975915931987
We treated 11 patients with tibial plateau fracture type I, II and III (according to J. Schatzker classification), 20 patients with avulsion fracture of the tibial insertion of the anterior cruciate ligament (intercondylar eminence) type II, III and IV (according to Meyers, McKeever and Zariczny classification), two patients with completely dislocated osteochondral flake fractures of the femoral condyle, and one patient with a minimally displaced fracture of the patella.	0.7156166334737811
Postoperatively they were all allowed passive motion exercises.	0.2785763756682368
Patients with avulsion fractures of the ACL and the patient with fracture of the patella were allowed immediate weight bearing, while patients with tibial plateau fractures and osteochondral fractures were allowed weight bearing only after 12 weeks.	0.7462948336618785
Results: Of the 11 tibial plateau fractures, 8 were anatomically reduced, and in 2 the dislocation was less than 2 mm.	0.9597463013917317
No further dislocation of the fragment followed.	0.5542494009798662
All patients but one reported stable knees and they all had a full range of motion at follow-up.	0.43902614346776697
Of the 20 patients with avulsion fracture of the anterior cruciate ligament, 19 were anatomically reduced.	0.5768337703264894
Except in one patient, functional results were excellent (KT1000 was 1.3 mm, average loss of flexion was 2.5 °, loss of extension was 1.3 °).	0.7968435847566252
In two cases of osteochondral fractures of the femoral condyle, reduction was anatomical.	0.8878725934629581
The fractures healed, the patients were free of pain and had full ROM at the follow-up.	0.7764148122967449
The fracture of the patella healed in 4 weeks with full ROM of the knee.	0.5908513524064759
There was one case of aseptic synovitis and no other major complications.	0.673177394797994
Conclusions: Arthroscopic reduction and fixation are technically possible in certain types of intra-articular fractures of the knee.	0.5486438466780832
Provided indications are good, results of arthroscopic treatment are better than in classical surgical treatment through arthrotomy.	0.586747577431793
There is less postoperative morbidity, and hospitalization and total rehabilitation times are shorter.	0.5717857387599815
Some technical hints are presented.	0.19374740476499208

With the institution of the Protection against infection Act, case definitions will be officially introduced for the routine transmission of notifiable infectious diseases from local health departments to state and national health institutions in Germany for the first time.	0.4755748775834652
Case definitions link the disease entity with a defined description of the disease.	0.4897124321957507
The abstraction thereby required leads to the creation of nosological entities.	0.33831263281477136
The case definitions, which were developed by the Robert Koch Institute (RKI) according to the Protection against infection Act, enable the local health departments to assess and categorise reported cases, deaths and laboratory reports of pathogens according to uniform criteria prior to transmission to the RKI via the state health institutions.The quality of surveillance data will be significantly improved, as each reported case/infection will fulfil defined criteria, thereby enabling unclear cases/diagnoses to be separated from those that are confirmed.	0.5597020456775138

In the last decades back pain has reached dramatic proportions in industrialized countries.	0.6120343818990378
Disorders of the back are nowadays the leading cause of direct and indirect health care costs.	0.43819136795460306
Accurate prevalence estimates are needed to serve as a basis for health care evaluations.	0.5043250588974563
A review of epidemiologic studies in the general population reveals that back pain has reached a prevalence of 40 % for current pain.	0.7432042612823
7 to 18 % are "frequently", "often", "daily" or "constantly" affected.	0.7473988071675469
75 % of the adult population suffers from back pain during the last year.	0.7235526321646462
80 to 90 % of the adult population in industrialized countries experience back pain ever.	0.5905018386828527
Gender specific differences are only present in severe, chronic forms which are more often experienced by women.	0.5447735736243161
Back pain has a prevalence maximum at 50 to 64 years.	0.4479420456724022
Older persons display lower prevalence estimates.	0.19949729601810567
The prevalence maximum in men is one decade earlier than in women.	0.36558017789121877
There are several potential explanations for this prevalence pattern that are discussed in the article.	0.6238705761811256
Back pain can be classified by location, temporal characteristics, pain intensity and pain history.	0.5897147957240341
Currently, for none of these dimensions generally accepted, uniformly employed and validated definitions are available.	0.5483284413037749
In most of the industrialized countries back pain is one of the most expensive symptoms.	0.6862785881620295
75-90 % of the direct and indirect health care costs were caused by those 5-10 % of patients who are disabled.	0.8584168804906979
As predictors of back pain a history of back pain and job satisfaction play by far a more important role than the extensively studied mechanical factors.	0.4761403565156216
For a first episode of back pain the prognosis is favorable.	0.5199615034349936
If the pain persist for more than three months the prognosis is unfavorable.	0.6166625770346644
After six months of absenteeism because of back pain more than half of the afflicted never return to work.	0.4883158302229361
Rarely back pain is present as a single symptom.	0.6275795309989556
In more than 80 % back pain is associated with pain in at least one joint.	0.8214672692658457
It remains to be studied if back pain may be viewed as an entity or as part of a more complex pain syndrome.	0.6010110790938578
Chronic low back pain can be considered to be one of the most frequently treated and most costly diseases in modern industrial societies.	0.6683838405813995
Dysfunctions and imbalances of the spine-supporting muscles increase the risk of low back pain.	0.49302281326663727
Consequently preventive treatment and rehabilitation have to aim at preserving and restoring the full capacity of the spine-supporting muscles as well as training coordination and spine-friendly behaviour.	0.47320027893284117
In addition to various measures of pain therapy, physiotherapeutic treatment including neuro-physiotherapy, physical treatment (eg electrotherapy), balneotherapy and supportive behavioural training, medical rehabilitation therapy (MRT) ranks among the most effective ways of treating low back pain.	0.6007631964333502
MRT applies guidelines and methods of exercise methodology within medically indicated programmes of preventive treatment and rehabilitation.	0.3626283069152699
Various objectives of MRT are outlined with special regard to the stages of MRT treatment, emphasizing positive adaptation of the neuro-muscular system in the course of rehabilitation.	0.4714944745713932
Physicians are responsible for MRT diagnosis and control.	0.33516690733472615
Taking into account the base disorder and the progress of therapy physiotherapists and the physicians in charge determine MRT objectives and treatment strategies.	0.5397633825594613

Recovery from whiplash within 6 weeks could be monitored.	0.37904829489842623
Diagnosis of parasomnias in the sleep laboratory is difficult since the nocturnal behavior reported by the patients often does not show up in the laboratory.	0.5761904639814411
To test the efficacy of sleep deprivation as a tool to provoke somnambulism we investigated ten patients (three women and seven men, mean age 27 +/- 3.4) with somnambulism.	0.7032115025094055
Their standard polysomnographies and videomonitored nocturnal behavior was compared to that of sex- and age-matched controls and to polysomnography and behavior after sleep deprivation.	0.6079987548084244
Patients with parasomnias and controls did not show significant differences in sleep parameters with the exception of longer arousal duration in controls, which was nonsignificant.	0.6803339464418074
In magnetic resonance tomography, patients with parasomnias did not reveal abnormality of the brain that might explain release of nocturnal behavior.	0.7444433178568349
Sleep deprivation led to significantly reduced number of arousals, reduced arousal index, significantly prolonged arousal duration and more stage shifts from all sleep stages (nonsignificant).	0.49867673014027336
Complex behavior during sleep increased under sleep deprivation, whereas sleepwalking did not increase.	0.5297449379776916
The majority of complex behavior during sleep is triggered by stage shifts and not by arousal in the sense of the arousal definition of the American Sleep Disorder Society.	0.5162291614648462
Complex behavior in sleep is stereotypical and nonviolent.	0.27224289405991253
Its complexity seems to depend on the duration and intensity of arousals.	0.5389295193570807
Sleep deprivation can be recommended as an efficacious method of increasing complex behavior in sleep, which is a preliminary stage of sleepwalking.	0.723476687776752
Concerning the underlying pathology it seems to be important to register the quality and duration of stimuli that trigger arousals instead of focusing the number of arousals alone.	0.617367358798965

The German Society of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery was founded by Martin Waßmund in 1951.	0.35267910161526533
One of the main reasons was the need for scientific representation in the council at a medical convention.	0.6588681348584259
The Society, originally composed of 52 members, was first called "The German Society of Maxillofacial Surgery".	0.6040637285921953
In 1972, it extended its title to include the term "oral" ("Mund") and currently comprises 620 members.	0.701307207185802
A scientific conference is held annually on a specific topic.	0.3148373537830137
The lectures given there have been published since 1954 in "Fortschritte der Kiefer- und Gesichts-Chirurgie" (Progress in Maxillofacial Surgery) by Thieme Verlag; since 1997, they have appeared as a Springer-Verlag supplement.	0.623171357142562
Topics of choice are published in "Mund,- Kiefer- und Gesichtschirurgie" ("Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery"), originally by Hanser in Munich and now by Springer-Verlag in Heidelberg.	0.6579581678773487
In this manner, it was possible to completely document the scientific activities and progress in this specialty.	0.5906001942274461
Each year since 1957, a prize named after M. Waßmund, has been given for outstanding scientific accomplishment.	0.5368539199000238
The presidents, convention locations, topics, and prizewinners are listed in a table.	0.41038180480951447

The hepatorenal syndrome is defined as the development of renal failure in patients with severe liver disease in the absence of any other identifiable cause of renal functional impairment.	0.7031546860933404
The pathogenesis of this obviously functional renal failure is complex and not completely understood.	0.5035404569137726
Of importance seems to be a peripheral and systemic vasodilatation with redistribution of blood volume.	0.5673920174570336
Nitric oxide seems to play a major role as a possible primary mediator.	0.6626816313392355
As a consequence changes in several different pathophysiological mechanisms (sympathetic nervous system, renin-angiotensin system, vasopressin, endothelin, prostanoids, natriuretic peptides) lead to a functional renal impairment which is characterized by renal cortical vasoconstriction.	0.5214873929760722
Supportive treatment and intensive monitoring of the cardiovascular circulation is the main goal in the care of these patients.	0.839330284682591
The mortality is still high exceeding 90%.	0.4898531284308709
Renal extracorporeal support should be initiated using a continuous method when recovery of liver function is expected (acute liver failure, waiting for liver transplantation).	0.4852940120602936
The only effective and permanent treatment is orthotopic liver transplantation.	0.42671721577620453

After termination of the seizures there was coma without focal neurological signs.	0.35990736310578747
CT scan revealed diffuse brain edema.	0.28209149811954876
Electroencephalographic studies showed generalized slowing.	0.21295882771440514
In laboratory tests the only abnormalities were marked hypocalcemia (1.15 mmol/l) and hyperphosphatemia.	0.6306256979090437
